description:
Amazing pho and quick service too 
The spring rolls were excellent and fresh
Always packed but they serve with a smile
author: Sameer B.

description:
One word: Meh.

I get that this is northern-style pho, but the broth lacked a depth of flavor. The broth was very light. The meat's flavor wasn't particularly bold as well. And since this is northern-style pho, you won't find the assortment of toppings. Instead, the pho is kept simple with cilantro and green onion already added to the dish.  

The quest for top-notch pho continues.
author: Erika S.

description:
Turtle Tower has three locations in SF - this one is about a 10 min walk from Civic Center BART. I got your standard beef pho bowl and thought it was okay. The broth didn't have too much flavor and depth (it tasted watered down), and the beef was a bit overcooked. The noodles weren't particularly memorable either - overall a little underwhelming.

As other reviewers have mentioned, this is northern-style pho, where they don't serve greens, bean sprouts, and other toppings. They just have cilantro and green onion, which are already mixed in the bowl, so if you look forward to the assortment of toppings with you pho, I would skip this place.

The portion size was small in comparison to what you may be used to, and the prices were very SF ($10 for a small and $11 for a large). The service was quick and accommodating though, which was nice. 

I won't be back, but if you work in the area and need a quick lunch spot, Turtle Tower is worth a try.

Tips:
- They take reservations for groups of 6+.
- I arrived at 11:30 and the place was empty. By noon, it was PACKED and there was a sizable line out of the door. I recommend arriving before noon or taking out!
author: Jordan H.

description:
My order:

Pho Tai (rare beef)
+extra serving of beef

Banh Mi chicken

What I got:

Nasty smelling meat, nasty smelling broth in the Pho

Dry dry dry chicken in the Banh Mi. Pickled vegetables too wet with no flavor. Bread tasted old like 2 day old bread. It had this charbroiled taste that stuck to my breath. It's not enjoyable unless your eating off the grill.  

The beef broth should smell salty and maybe have a slight beef smell. Also should be able to smell some spices like anise star. It smelled like it's been sitting outside for a while and it has this bad smell. But hey, sometimes the broth smells weird so I continued with my prep. Had to reheat the broth (standard) but when I did the smells really came bursting forward. Anyways, added my sauces and lemon, mixed them in, and dig in. After one bite of that chewy chewy chewy meat (like bubble gum) and sallowed...You know when you eat something, then you think, this might be bad for me(food poisoning, upset stomach), but you just spent about 20 dollars and you don't want to waste it right? Well after that one bite I just stopped and threw it away. Sorry for wasting food but it's not worth the potential sickness that might come from it. 

I won't be ordering from here again.
author: Jawid H.

description:
Northern Vietnamese food vs Southern Vietnamese food. I have to say that the clear winner in my book is Southern. To be perfectly fair, this was my time trying Northern Style Vietnamese food so I didn't really know what to expect. Our server was patient enough to explain some of the differences to us but he wasn't all that friendly which rubbed us the wrong way. 

We were all feeling a little under the weather mainly from being in the car all day. My brother in particular wasn't feeling too well so we were really looking for something comforting. We all ordered some Pho Tai and a Meat Stew with vermicelli. Now, Northern Style pho doe not come with the usual array of vegetables. It comes with lemons and jalapeños. That is it. I thought that the broth was lacking depth. If you aren't going to serve sauces or vegetables, the broth should be perfect and that was not the case. The noodles were also overcooked which was a disappointment. The beef stew was better but also a tad too salty. We drank a lot of water during this meal to combat that saltiness. 

We were full and we still ended up walking out of the restaurant with a bad taste in our mouths. The restaurant charged us a mandatory tip. Now, I don't have anything against that necessarily but the service was not good during this meal. If you're going to charge me, you better be exceptional. We won't be back and will be sticking to the OC for our Vietnamese fix. 2/5
author: Michelle L.

description:
Chicken pho here is delicious! Dark meat with skin (yummy), thick noodles, and the cleanest most delicious broth. 
Vietnamese seal of approval
author: Miranda N.

description:
3.5 stars. I've wanted to come here for a while since moving here. It's the best pho in the neighborhood, so I'd come back again if I was craving pho and happened to be in the Tenderloin. 

This is Northern-style Pho, so it's minimalist. They're not going to give you beansprouts, Thai basil and sawtooth coriander like a typical Southern pho place. The only herbs provided are cilantro and green onion, which are already in the bowl.

I ordered the Chicken Pho because I heard that's their specialty. It tasted more Chinese than Vietnamese.

BROTH: Very light on typical Pho Ga spices. A clean-tasting chicken broth that had a strong chicken flavor. I enjoyed it!

My friend got the Beef Pho, and it's similarly light on pho spices and aromatics. I preferred the chicken pho because I found the flavor of the beef pho to be TOO beefy.

We also got the Cha Gio/fried egg rolls. They were $3.50 each eggroll. While they tasted alright, I felt it was overpriced considering we paid $7 for just two measly eggrolls!

I'd come back if I happened to be in the TL and wanted some hot soup!
author: Gabriel H.

description:
This is one of the few places I wanted to try when I was planning my trip to SF. It was close to our hotel so we took a Lyft there. The neighborhood is kind of sketch and not the safest, but the food is worth it if you love pho. 

I ordered the Bun Thang, which is pho with vermicelli noodles and thinly sliced chicken and eggs. It was amazing. I'm not exaggeration when I say it was probably the best pho I ever had. Ok so I don't eat pho that often, so take that opinion with a grain of salt lol.
author: Alan Y.

description:
I thought with the amount of reviews and ratings, I was in for a treat. I was intentionally looking for other Pho places but they had shut down without a warning on Yelp. So I opted for Turtle Tower. Turtle Tower is owned by Vietnamese people don't get me wrong, but I was looking for more of the pho beefy broth. Yelpers lists this place as a Northern-style pho, so if you're into that, this is the place for you. This was not the place for me also because they don't give you the normal beansprouts, basil and lemons on the side, which I was really looking forward to. 

I ordered the #4 Pho and got a side of the spring rolls. The broth was not beefy but more of a chicken broth, which is not my forte when it comes to pho. They give a great amount of scallions and the meat, chunked and scattered in the bowl. The noodles had a nice consistency, pretty much the only thing I liked. Usually, I finish the broth but this is the only pho place where I wasn't feeling it. The spring rolls, was a disappointment. I paid $3.50 for one piece that was cut into three pieces. The skin was very fried which I did not like.

Verdict: Come here if you like Northern style pho. Skip the spring rolls.
author: Rita L.

description:
O M G, the chicken noodle soup is so BOMB here! Don't expect this to taste like your regular pho ga because it's not!!! This is northern pho so it has more herbs taste to it. If you've tried pho ga before somewhere else, that was probably traditional southern pho. 

Please get the pho ya, you won't be disappointed! Ask for extra lemon to put in your soup because who doesn't love lemon?? (Add hot sauce if you like it spicy too). 

Here's what I do: 
order the chicken pho + giblets, squeeze so so so much lemon in the soup, add hot sauce, jalapeño, & START EATING!

Side note: the location might be sketchy, but this location tastes the best!
author: Ashli C.

description:
The Pho Ga is amazing. Btw, they don't serve their pho with bean sprouts, basil or hoisin sauce because they serve it northern style. They only give you lemon and jalapenos. However, the pho is very flavorful and has a strong cilantro flavor because they add a lot on top. 

The shrimp spring rolls are so fresh and served with peanut sauce. I asked for the fish sauce instead so that's always an option. 

Overall, not in the best of safest location because as I was walking in...someone was getting arrested next door. But that didn't stop me from getting my viet food fix!!
author: Winnie L.

description:
Still the MACK. I don't always want their thicker style noodles, but sometimes I do and they do those thick noodles better than anyone else. I plan to try their chicken pho soon as well. 

I do sort of wish that they gave the full herb selection that most pho places give you since the customization is always fun.
author: Misha T.

description: Are people ok? How does this place have the best chicken Pho? I'm from the east coast and was super excited to try turtle tower but man oh man was I laughing at how terrible this place was. I got the beef pho and my friends both ordered the chicken pho and for sure they used the same broth because it was both bland as h***. I'm sorry but this was the worst pho I've ever had and this is the west coast... where phos are suppose to be better, or so I thought. If you ever had fj fishball or fj wonton soup(msg water) this was basically it. It have a slight umami flavor but nothing like what pho should be. It was really just water and noods. How can people love this place? I neeed answers because I've heard so many good things about this place and it was all lies.
author: Patricia N.

description:
It's such a rarity to find northern Vietnamese food! 

Parking: Paid street parking or garages; not easy by any means

Ambience: It's an large space (with a second floor - although we have not seen people sit upstairs). 

Service: The employees are prompt and readily available. 

Order: We have been here multiple times and have ordered:

1) Pho Ga (or Chicken Pho), $9.25 for S and $10.75 for L: I definitely have a bias towards eating beef pho. While this is done well, I don't gravitate to ordering this. 

2) Bun Cha Hanoi (similar ish to a grilled pork vermicelli bowl but better), $11.50: This is my favorite dish! This dish is done so well; all the meats are grilled and you can taste that charboiled-ness of it. If you like the grilled pork vermicelli bowls, you will definitely like this. :) 

3) Chao Ga (or Chicken Congee), $9.25 for S and $10.75 for L: If you are craving congee, this does the job; however, it doesn't taste any different from other restaurants I have had it at. 

Verdict: 4 because their other dishes besides Bun Cha Hanoi stands out to me, compared to other Vietnamese restaurants.
author: Michelle B.

description: This was my first time here, and first time trying Northern Vietnam style pho! It was delicious, and hit the spot after a night of drinking. Best of all, they open at 8am, so I may frequent this place on Saturday and Sunday mornings :)
author: Michael K.

description:
Pho isn't exactly on the top of my list when I visit SF, sp Turtle Tower became another one of those places I had bookmarked for a long time and never tried before I moved away from NorCal. Well, on this particular day (i.e., recovery day lol), it made sense to get some pho. Realized the hotel we were staying at was walking distance to here, so finally came over!

Had to get the chicken pho since it's the trademark of Turtle Tower. Not everyday you get northern style pho since basically every pho place these days has the thin noodles instead of wide noodles. Pho was pretty good, the broth and meat was much lighter than the beef pho I'm used to but still quite tasty. Noodles also were able to hold a lot of flavor since they were thicker. Overall, the right call was made to come here since it was totally what we needed.

Service was pretty good, no complaints here on my end.

Not the best pho around, but definitely glad I came here. I am a fan!
author: Alexander Y.

description:
Came here on a day that was perfect for eating pho.  Walked right in with no wait and sat ourselves to any available table.  My cousin recommended this place and told us it was a northern style of pho.  I wasn't sure what to expect so I ordered the typical pho while my fiancé ordered the pho ha.  

The pho comes with no condiments other than lemon and jalapeños.  Both broths are good but I think the pho ga is something I would order time and time again.  It was clear and flavorful which accompanied the flat noodle well.  Service was also very attentive.

Highly recommend this place for northern style pho ga!
author: Rodrigo S.

description:
Best.chicken.pho.ever!!!! They are best known for their pho ga. Place is clean and service is fast. I think they just extended their weekend hours to open later too. 

I have tried their beef pho before but it's not as good as other pho places. I believe it's because they serve northern pho instead of the southern style.
author: Denise J.

description: Their pho is delicious, but it's a different style pho than what you may be used to. I got the pho ga, which is a chicken/chicken broth pho, and it's basically a better version of chicken noodle soup. I also like how they use thick noodles.
author: Tiffany H.

description: Turtle Tower is definitely a different Vietnamese cuisine experience than most of the other places you'll go to in the City. However, it's quite delicious, and there's always room for a change of pace. I would say that you should go with their two most famous dishes - pho ga (chicken pho) and bun cha ha noi (pan-fried pork patties with dipping sauce and noodles and veggies). You've probably seen the latter dish on Bourdain's Parts Unknown, and you won't be disappointed with this dish overall. Yes, you're going to be getting flat noodles instead of the usual thin, circular ones you're used to in your pho, and the broth is much more simple and clean than other pho places. Skip the appetizers though, because imperial rolls are almost $4 per roll (not worth the price for so little food), so you don't really want to waste your wallet or stomach space on that when large bowls of pho or rice plates are about $11-13 (great deal for the portion sizes, and noodles are never overcooked). Parking is pretty easy on Sundays because no one really drives all the way out to the TL to eat. The #4 (pho bo dac biet) will also cure whatever ails you. Again though, you're going to get something much different than you're used to with large pieces of flat, tenderized beef instead of the beef balls and tougher cuts you might get elsewhere. The tripe in this bowl though is absolutely killer. You'll thank me later.
author: Danny C.

description: The description for a 2 star rating is exactly how I felt: Meh, I've experienced better. The place where I wanted to go was closed so I opted to come here. Then I read the reviews after I ate and I'm with everyone else, northern pho is not preferred. The thicker style rice noodles are overcooked, broth is really light, and you really don't get much more than that. I'm always open to trying new foods but I won't be coming back here. Service is the only thing saving this place.
author: Abe K.

description:
Quick take: Really good Pho Ga


Really great service by the whole staff. Really enjoyed the Pho Ga. Delicious clear broth. They use the thicker rice noodles which I like very much. They are very generous with the cilantro and green onions. If you are not crazy about cilantro and green onions I would ask for it on the side. The chicken was chopped up into smaller pieces which I liked!

Thumbs up and highly recommended.
author: Nancy H.

description: I didn't like this place. It's probably popular Vietnamese place in the area. But I had to give only one star because they didn't handle the situation in the way it is supposed to be. In this case, customer service experience. I ordered pan-fried beef noodle soup and I expected it to be like a decent Vietnamese noodle soup, but the soup was fatty, oily and hard to swallow. Probably, the worst Vietnamese meal I ever had in SF. When I went to the counter and explained that the soup was fatty, they gave me only 20% of my whole bill which is around $9 off the whole bill (there were 3 of us). I learned my lesson and I won't ever recommend going there.
author: Rimma D.

description: Came from Ga and was told this place was THE place. I'm not a huge chicken eater but OMG -- hold the phone-- this chicken pho is AMAZING. I wish I could explain how perfect the broth was and the tender chicken. I'll be back in my next trip to San Francisco.
author: Morgan D.

description:
Some may disagree but this is my go to for pho in SF. Whether it be a cold rainy day or a hangover cure, it comes through for me. I especially like how light and non oily the broth is. It's very clean tasting which is what I like when I eat pho. 

I usually get the grilled beef and vegetable pho but this time I decided on the brisket and rare beef on the side. I was coming back from a trip and needed some comfort food. Tired and feeling under the weather, Turtle came through and I'm always thankful that they're around! 

They get busy on weekends but weekday lunch isn't too bad.
author: Andrew S.

description: In the 8 years I've lived here, I had yet to visit Turtle Tower. In a quick escape from the office for a weekday lunch, my co-workers and I stopped in here on a rainy day. Nothing feels as good on a rainy day like a good bowl of soup, and Turtle Tower did not disappoint. We all ordered the Pho Ga and it was SO delicious. I'm normally a Pho Tai girl, but at the behest of my co-worker, I went with Pho Ga and I'm so glad I did. Don't expect anything fancy, minimal amount of interaction with your servers, and prepare to eat as soon as you put in your order. I will absolutely be back here again!
author: Lisa I.

description:
I'm not sure I align with all the glowing reviews of this place because my experience with the food was just mediocre at best.

My friend took me here and insisted that they had the best pho. I beg to differ. I'm from San Jose where there's a plethora of pho options around town and most are competitively priced and offer a good viet selection for your taste buds.

We walked here and keep in mind it's in a sketchier part of town but it isn't so bad during the daytime, just be aware of your surroundings. 

I ordered my usual Pho Tai (rare beef) since I don't eat all the other cuts of meat. The pho is hanoi style, meaning the beef is cut up and pulverized into smaller pieces instead of thinly sliced. The noodles are also wider. Also, this version of pho didn't come with hoison sauce/sriracha or a side of fresh veggies to add.

All in all, the pho was okay. It didn't light my world on fire but hey, maybe I'm just not used to this version. I prefer my traditional skinny pho rice noodles and my slices of meat. 

We also ordered the Cha Goi and fried squid appetizers. They're so tiny! They ask you how many pieces for each. I've had much better elsewhere. Skip these options!
author: Connie M.

description:
I wished I lived in SF! I go here every time I'm in town visiting and it always hits the spot.

As others have said this place serves northern style pho, specializing in chicken pho aka Pho Ga. Coming from SoCal where beef pho is the norm, I was initially surprised at the contrast. The flavors here are more subdued and earthier. Less of a salty kick than other pho restaurants and yet still very fragrant. The noodles are wider and very soft. 

I didn't grow up a chicken pho fan, but Turtle Tower changed my mind. And great, now I'm auper hungry
author: Joshua M.

description:
Its a Sunny Sunday in San Francisco.  And its slightly chilly.  Thanks to my sister-in-law for introducing my mom and I to Turtle Tower.  The hot soup definitely hit the spot.

1.  Yes, you might have to wait a bit.  We visited for lunch on Sunday, 11/5, and there were groups of people waiting outside.

2.  Yes, make sure you're present and around when your name is called or you will be passed over.  There was at least 1 name called, and no one (who was waiting directly in front of the restaurant) responded.  

3.  Yes/Maybe, I think all the members of your party must be present before you're seated.  I overheard someone explaining to a staff member outside that they were still waiting on two people to show up (I think the staff came out to call their party that the table was ready).

4.  Yes, the menu is extensive.  There are noodles, rice dishes, sandwiches, and appetizers to choose from.

5.  Yes, I was hungry!  And so was everyone else I was with.  We ordered an appetizer to start, while I debated between a small or large pho bowl.  Since I felt my appetite was ravenous enough, I ordered the large bow of the #5 pho:  stir fried beef with celery, carrots, and onions.  Apparently, I was the lone person that did not order the pho chicken noodle soup (#9).  We all loved the pho!  So good!

6.  Yes, the restaurant is called Turtle Tower, but the staff move with the speed of a hare.  The staff was polite, but very direct with the ordering process as well as delivering the food to their customers in the most timely manner possible.  As we ate our food, the staff swiftly moved to turn around tables and drop off hot bows of soup to diners ("hot soup coming thru!").  

BOTTOM LINE:
So good pho you.  Good soup.  Efficient service.  Thanks for a good meal, Turtle Tower!
author: Michael C.

description: Am finding that I tend to review noodle restaurants. I've never ordered anything aside from the chicken pho here because it is really the best! The broth is authentic and obviously made from real chicken and bones because it doesn't make you parched afterwards. Worth the trek to this dicey neighborhood and other restaurants on the same street are worth trying too.
author: Shaw L.

description:
Turtle Tower is the perfect place to visit when you're feeling under the weather (or slightly hungover). The chicken pho here is the best in town and I just love how clean the broth is! Beware that this place gets pretty packed on weekends so try to come early!

I always opt for the Pho Ga with Chicken Gizzards and it's amazing! The broth really gets the job done and simply tastes comforting. I always love to add siracha and fish sauce too. It's the best combo!

If you need a quick pick me up, then you definitely need to get the Cafe Sua Da (Vietnamse Coffee too). It can get you wired real quick!
author: MyTien P.

description:
I typically don't get Pho Ga (Chicken Pho) but I had to try it at this venue based on the reviews and like most places I would have to agree that it's pretty darn good.  I think the small plate was around $8 and the larger around $9. 

I really like the flavor of the broth , the texture/taste of the noodles and the chicken was good as well. Throw in the fact that it was a rainy day in San Fran / San Pancho and we have ourselves a winner.

Rod's Pho Rankings for SF Bay Area:
1 Ly's Vietnamese Cuisine
2 Turtle Tower
3 Rang Dong Restaurant
4 Golden Star Vietnamese Restaurant
5 Pho Huynh Hiep 2 - Kevin's Noodle House
6 R&D Café
7 Mai's Kitchen
8 Noodles Pho Me
9 Chopsticks Pho & Grill
10 Rice and Spoon Vietnamese Cuisine
11 Pho VN Vietnamese Restaruant
12 Pho 2000
13 Pho Vi Hoa
14 Bistro Viet House
15 Pho Ty II
16 Pho Pasteur
17 Kim Huong
18 Pho 99
author: Rod M.

description:
Finally ate here after 11 years in the city. I got the pho which is northern style. The noodle texture is amazing, and the broth has a fresher, less rich taste to it that I love. Normally I feel kind of sick 3/4 of the way through a bowl of pho but I destroyed it and feel great. Also the service was much friendlier and nicer than the average Pho restaurant. PLus, the place is very clean, modern and has large clean bathrooms. 

Will return to try their famous chicken pho.
author: Jordan C.

description:
Order the Pho Ga (chicken noodle soup #9) and ask for the (relatively unknown) lemon sauce to dip the chicken in! The sauce is a game-changer. 
Happy about the evening hours until 9 pm Friday - Sunday.
author: J Y.

description:
Chicken pho that warms your soul in Little Saigon! 

My parents took me here after raving about their chicken pho noodle soup for a while. Finally came this Saturday around 1pm with no wait. 

Relative to the other Vietnamese restaurants in the area, this one is surprisingly more spacious and seemingly newer. I think this is reflected in the price you are paying for their noodles (about $9 for a small bowl and about $10 for a large). 

I settled on their chicken pho, which was comforting, flavorful, and surprisingly light. Tasting the broth, you can tell it has a lot of chicken flavor without too much of the salty MSG flavor typical of most pho places. The medium-sized flat rice noodles were also fresh and soft. The chicken they use is already pulled off the bone and very tender. While I think it lacks some salt, it tasted great once I  ate it with some of the saltier soup. They don't give much chicken, but if you happen to want more, you can add on a small side of it for about $5. 

If you hate cilantro, this chicken pho probably isn't for you, however. The soup is super yummy because they put it in the soup for flavor. 

I also happened to try some of my mom's rare beef pho. Their rare beef is interestingly made--it's more of a flattened rare beef patty than slices. However, it still is very fresh. I could definitely taste the beef flavor and it was still super tender. 

Overall, both the chicken and rare beef pho here is pretty awesome. You can tell their soups are very fresh and made with great ingredients; they're surprisingly light too. I think they're great for a cold day or a post-hangover meal. For $9 it's a bit pricey for the smaller portion size, but I guess you're paying for more quality ingredients and the more comfortable/uncramped seating in the city.
author: Clarissa C.

description: Okay this is a different style of Vietnamese. I really like the style of food. Easy menu and really delicious Pho Ga with the thicker noodles. It's very sketchy area so catch Uber or Lyft to get in and out of here.
author: Juan V.

description:
I discovered Turtle Tower a few years ago when I was visiting the Asian Art Museum and wanted lunch nearby (before my Yelping days! :O). One of the staff members recommended going here and I visited their old location and remembered tasting one of the best chicken pho I've ever had! Flavorful broth, plentiful flat noodles, overload of cilantro and green onions, and lots of chicken meat and giblets (order the giblets!! Don't be scared of 'em).

I'm happy to see that they're doing well after all these years ago and got to renovate. However, the news legendary chicken pho has spread and now I know I need to budget at least 30 minute waiting time when I want to pop in for lunch on a weekend. I typically come back when I am visiting the Asian Art Museum for new exhibits or if I have other activities in the Civic Center area.

Besides the chicken pho, my boyfriend also enjoys their combo beef pho. The broth is also flavorful and meat is tender. We like coming here as a traditional lunch before Asian Art Museum and it's nice to try northern Vietnamese flavors once in awhile.

Price is a bit higher due to SF standards and their increasing popularity. But I'm still happy paying ~$10 for a heaping bowl of delicious chicken and/or beef pho to support a local restaurant.
author: Bonnie Z.

description:
By far the WORST bahn mi I've ever had. And I ordered two. The size is a joke; it's like two thirds smaller than any bahn mi I've ever gotten. The carrots are sparse and flavorless. The cucumber is thin. Barely any meat, and I couldn't taste seasoning. The bread is very stale. I just gave both sandwiches to my dog. 

I WANT A REFUND OF MY CAVIAR ORDER!!! This is abysmal. The restaurant is closed, but I'll call tomorrow.
author: Paulina F.

description:
We've been coming here for years and it's always a treat since we live in San Jose.  It's definitely gone down hill.  The broth was so bland and lacked of any flavor.  We had to add tons of fish sauce and that still didn't help.
What a disappointment.
author: Ai C.

description: My first time at this location. Con: the neighborhood is sketch af. It took so long to find parking too. Definitely would NOT come when it gets dark. Pro: didn't have to wait at all to get seated, as opposed to my usual Richmond district location. I ordered the chicken pho and it was delicious per usual. I did notice that they gave a lot more chicken than I'm used to. So yeahhh.. not sure if it's worth it to come to this location due to the neighborhood.
author: Annie H.

description:
It's high time I review Turtle Tower, one of my favorite pho joints in the city. I'm basing this review off of the one dish I've tried: the pho ga. If you're ordering anything else, what's wrong with you?!

I never thought I would choose pho ga over beef pho (I love me some tendon and meatballs in my bowl!), but Turtle Tower's pho ga has the best broth and the noodles are the perfect texture. I crave this all the time. It's northern-style pho, so don't expect a side of bean sprouts.

Portions are great too -- the small portion ($9.25) is plenty for me. I do need to try the version with chicken giblets! Unfortunately, it's not a hidden gem so be prepared to wait, especially on the weekends. But #worthit.
author: Valerie L.

description:
Worst pho I've ever had. 

I've heard of Turtle Tower before and finally decided to pay a visit on a Tuesday when my favorite pho joint Pho 2000 was closed. Huge mistake! 

Apparently this place serves northern style pho which is very different than what I'm used to. It's a clean joint I'll give them that. I ordered the rare steak pho but they were very stingy with meat. I only had maybe one piece in my bowl. Broth was not too bad. Noddles were much thicker than southern style pho. Blah. AND there was no garnishes on the side and hoisin sauce?!? Mind blown! It also cost more than Pho 2000 for a tiny subpar bowl. Epic fail. 

Would I come back? Hell to the NO!
author: Angela F. W.

description:
Authentic and very delicious Vietnamese food! The Vietnamese cuisine is one of my favorites, and I always feel delighted with a good Pho.. Turtle Tower is, no doubt, one of the better places I've tried.. 

I had the Pho with rare meat (#2) with extra meat - meat on the side.. Having the meat on the side gives me the opportunity to add it myself, little by little, when I eat it.. In addition we also had a side plate of pork and the fresh spring rolls.. 

The service was great - and the food was SO good and fresh! Everythjng was well prepared, very tasty and I taken back to Vietnam while enjoying the food! The food is super cheap (Pho - 11.50$ for a large, spring rolls - 6.25$ for 4 pretty large pieces) and I'd definitely recommend this place if you're into authentic and tasty Vietnamese food!
author: Nadia S.

description:
I love Vietnamese food and after my trip to Ho Che Min I fell in love with the southern pho style - simple; broth, noodles and your choice of meat. 
Since I switched to no carb diet I still found a way to enjoy my favorite dish: just hold the noodles. 
The broth was simple and tasty, chicken filled me up.
It felt very honest and filling.
author: Anelya S.

description:
Cute eaters: don't let the $1.50 difference inspire you to order a large Ph. I can EAT... but it was so large I thought the waiter was going to curse me out for not coming close to finishing ;__;.

AMBIANCE is cool. A bit crowded at times- and I sometimes have to sit at tables with strangers, but the homemade feel makes up for it (and the TV in the corner allows me to tune conversations out).

ORDERED previously Pho Gà (chicken noodle soup) and Com Thit Nuong hoc Gà Nuong (Grilled chicken with steamed rice). Most recently: Pho Bò Áp Chao Nuoc (stir-fried beef with celery, carrot, onion, and leek pan-fried noodle soup), and Gi Cun (fresh spring rolls).

FOOD is solid. I'm actually not a huge fan of the Pho Gà, which seems super popular (a little bland in my opinion), but the Pho Bò Áp Chao Nuoc was amazing. Full of flavor and the beef was nice and tender! Also recommend the Com Thit Nuong hoc Gà Nuong.

RATING is a super four. I'll be coming here many more times, especially since it's so close to my casa.
author: Nicholas G.

description:
Very delicious chicken pho, the broth is clear and flavorful, accompanied by chicken pieces.

Great to see that they offered other foods than pho, and also takes credit card. Location is a bit sketchy to get to.
author: YY M.

description:
The northern style pho is really quite a refresher. I've been on a pho kick, and eating it everyday on all my weekend trips that I've made to SF this year from Chicago. Usually I've been going to Pho Tan Hoa and Pho 2000 and after indulging so frequently in the darker and more intense tasting broth, what I had at Turtle Tower was such a nice welcome. I truly enjoyed every bit of the delicate tasting broth here. The noodle is also different, wider and more reminiscent of the "hor fun".

One of my friends in Chicago who is of Hmong heritage visited SF and Turtle Tower on a separate occasion. She said it felt and tasted exactly like how her mom would make pho at home. Light and delicate broth.
author: Teri Y.

description:
TLDR - Yes to the chicken pho! Their broth is amazing, but prices are more than what I'm used to paying for pho

I've always been loyal to variations of beef pho and have never really ordered chicken pho before, but since Turtle Tower is known for their chicken pho, I obviously had to go that route. If you usually stick with the beef version at pho spots, I'd definitely recommend switching it up. Their chicken pho is amazing! And you know it's their specialty because it's more expensive than their beef phos.

Unlike most pho places you might be used to, they don't serve the usual plate of bean sprouts and basil and there's no hoisin or sriracha on the table. Instead, they're known for their Northern/Hanoi-style pho, which has wider rice noodles and is served with just jalapeno and lime on the side and chili sauce on the table. The menu says you can order the pho with the better-known thin vermicelli noodles (bun) or egg noodles (mi), but when one of my friends tried to order hers with the thin noodles, the man taking our order (whom I assume was the owner) was VERY insistent that she get the wide noodles, up to the point that my friend gave up and another friend decided to porridge instead of pho. Why do they give the option of ordering other noodles if they actually won't let you do it?!?

I was originally going to order just the normal Pho Ga ($8), but one of my friends ordered the Pho Tai Lan (beef pho with veggies) and asked for chicken instead of beef, which I didn't realize you could do. If you want veggies other than just green onion in your pho, ask for #5 with chicken! Just know that it does cost an extra $1 for chicken instead of beef, which I didn't know until we got the bill. Their pho in general is a little on the pricey side for pho ($8-10 for a small), but still much more affordable than the average lunch you'd find in SF.

* PHO GA LAN (small $9.75, large $11.25)
[chicken, celery, carrot, onion & leek noodle soup]
Definitely one of the better bowls of pho I've had. I can't really compare their chicken pho with other places since I've never ordered chicken pho elsewhere, but it was better than a lot of beef pho I've had. The broth was light but sooo flavorful and addicting! There had to be MSG in it, but I didn't find it dehydrating - and I drank my entire bowl of broth plus maybe half of one of my friends'. In fact, I finished my broth before finishing the chicken or the noodles. The chicken was boiled and tender and there was a decent amount of it. The noodles were on the soft side though and a little too silky for my liking. 

They DO take credit cards here (not sure if there's a minimum). The location isn't in the best of areas (helloo Tenderloin), but don't let that deter you from coming here! Everyone who lives in SF knows all the good hole-in-the-walls are in the TL.
author: Jessie L.

description:
I had been wanting to go here since my friends and family have been raving about this place for their chicken pho. My boyfriend got their chicken pho with gizzards and I got grilled pork with the chicken soup. He shared some of his and I honestly don't know why it's so loved. It tasted like any other chicken pho to me, which is usually bland for my taste. But maybe it's just because I usually add a lot of sauce that I couldn't get on board with the chicken pho. Although I must say the rice with the soup was really good. 

The pork was I would say mediocre. I've had better grilled pork at Kevin's and other places. The meat was more on the dry side and didn't have much taste. I had to pour all the sauce that comes with it to give some taste to the dish. Also, the amount of pork that comes with it was very little. I LOVE rice and I usually have a lot of meat left over because I eat more rice than meat but this time, I had more rice left over. 

The service, however, was awesome. I was about to get the chicken w gravy and my waiter was very honest with his opinion of it so I got the grilled pork instead. The other waitress was also quick to refill my water cup. One of my biggest pet peeves in a restaurant is if I have to track down a waiter just to refill my water cup. So that was a big plus for me. Although the service was friendly and helpful, I probably wouldn't come back here since the food was alright for my taste.
author: May O.

description: Really loved their chicken porridge. I thought the chicken pho was great, but not as great as the chicken porridge was. Wish this was in a more savory location.
author: Emily M.

description:
A Turtle Tower review, in haiku form:
I am hungover.
I need pho and a coffee.
Eat Turtle Tower.
author: Carl M.

description:
Turtle Tower is the place to go for pho ga/chicken noodle soup in the Tenderloin! This location outshines the Soma one by a lot so do make sure you come to this one.

The pho ga/chicken noodle soup is their specialty here so don't miss out. The soup tastes clean and fresh. They use wider rice noodles which are different and usually softer. They are very generous with cilantro and onion here.

Only the Soma location does Uber Eats unfortunately, which makes it harder if you're looking to get take out. Overall, it's a pretty great spot.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
The first time ever me trying Pho Ha Noi Style was here. It is pretty unique and it's the perfect spot for you to visit when you're feeling the weather or just want to try a different type of pho style. 

I was born and raised in San Jose so that means I've had plenty of Pho and this one is definitely one of my tops for sure. The broth, the noodles, and the flavor makes it super unique. I usually opt in for the Pho Ga or Pho Pho Bo Dac Biet. The fish sauce for you to dip the chicken is very good too!
author: Danny L.

description: The best  Pho in the city. nice owner! she is always so welcoming with a big genuine smile. but oh the hood the restaurant is in:(...and the delivery is never the same.  other locations don't deliver the same pho!!
author: Souris L.

description: My friend saw this place on yelp and wanted to come here for lunch. We walked through the Tenderloin to get here. Got here and was seated immediately. We didn't look at the menu and felt rushed to order. I ended up ordering a pho ga, and it was okay. Nothing special, I usually like Saigon in the East Bay. My friend ordered some beef noodle. It came out pretty quick, wasn't that hot, but definitely not cold. He found hair in his food which was terrible and he refused to tell the restaurant staff. Wasn't the best location, food, or service. Would not recommend this place if you are looking for pho.
author: Amy Y.

description: Don't understand why there was even a line for this place. They're supposed to be known for their northern style viet food but everything just tasted weird. I don't know if it was just my tastebuds that day, but my friend and I both were craving some good pho and we were disappointed by the quality and taste of the food. we got the pho ga, which seemed to be popular on the menu, but the broth just tasted like salty water. I made the mistake of adding their siracha and fish sauce to the soup without tasting each of them first since I thought it would add more flavor, but it made it even saltier! Their fish sauce and siracha did not taste like regular fish sauce and siracha that you would normally get at pho restaurants, especially the fish sauce. Usually fish sauce has a sweeter taste but theirs was just too salty. And when I asked for hoisin sauce, they said they didn't carry any. Not to mention the price of just a small bowl of pho was $10.50 and only one fried egg roll was $3.50!! I've never had pho so expensive before. I've tried way better and cheaper pho restaurants in SF. Not worth trying again.
author: Valerie C.

description:
This is more noodle house than restaurant but it is airy, bright and clean. They do northern Vietnam style cuisine which is not as widespread as the usual southern Vietnam pho joints most people are familiar with.

Order the regular Pho Gà (chicken pho) but adventurous eaters order Pho Gà Lòng (pho ga with giblets: heart, gizzard, liver, and other organs). I normally don't eat these chicken parts but do so here!

The Pho Bò Xào (khô) is stir-fry beef with pan-fried thick noodle. I thought it was okay, as it had flavors but was burnt tasting at times and bland. Not great enough to recommend nor avoid altogether.

Good fast-casual spot, or as a recovery spot. There's a TV showing something at all times. It's too bad they close at 5pm or I'd go more often. The surrounding area is sketchy-ish but most of the time it's fine to walk around.
author: Peter L.

description:
Hungover? Turtle Tower. Munchies? Turtle Tower. Homesick? Turtle Tower. Working late in the office? Turtle Tower via Caviar delivery. 

The understated broth in Northern Vietnamese pho is perfectly done at Turtle Tower. The flavor is rich and almost creamy, with silky thick noodles to compliment the heaviness of the broth. Aside from the delicious food, the service at the restaurant is always friendly and efficient. Turtle Tower is a staple in my SF diet.
author: Le D.

description:
I had read the reviews, heard the praise, and had this spot bookmarked to try for some time.  Trying Hanoi style pho was on my to do list for some time, but I didn't want to try it anywhere, oh no.  Turtle Tower was going to be my spot to represent that style of Vietnamese cuisine.

I ordered a small bowl of the Pho Ga with chicken giblets (and heart and liver).   The noodles come with a small dish of jalapeno peppers and a wedge of lemon.  The noodles were garnished with cilantro and green onions.  The broth was clear and light, and tasted of chicken (not bouillon), but was a bit on the salty side.  I found no hint of MSG. However, I thought it was very one dimensional so added a few drops of fish sauce, a squirt of lemon and a dab of hot sauce to see if that would make a different.  It did.  

The shreds of chicken were silky and tender.  It was definitely cooked well.  I just wish there was more of it!   I thought the noodles were a bit overcooked and soft.  Normally a bowl of this size is more than adequate but I wish I had ordered the large.  The portion size was on the small side and I left a bit hungry.  The person next to me ended up ordering additional food halfway through his large bowl of pho.

The restaurant is very clean and tables are spaced with some distance from one another.  However when it gets crowded parties of 2 may be asked to sit right next to other parties of 2, where the tables are pushed together.  It's not a big deal unless you are having a confidential conversation (thinking of all the attorneys and gov. employees working nearby).  

The staff seem to like to ask about your order as soon as you are seated, even before one gets settled in their seat!   I can only assume from this that they have a lot of repeat customers that know what they want.  In general the staff do a great job of moving people along to accommodate the crowds during the lunch rush.

If I were in the area I would be open to trying their pho again but I don't know that I would make a special trip.  Or perhaps I should try one of their other locations.
author: Melissa L.

description: Came here with friends based on the raving reviews. The wait wasn't too bad (approx. 10-15min) environment was clean. I ordered the pho gai which was a simple clear broth with wide pho, slightly oilier than the other types of pho I've tried. Never had northern style pho before so probably not the best one to judge on the quality, but it was just not really my thing :(
author: Johanne L.

description:
The chicken pho here is amazing. Broth is clear and comes with bits and pieces of chicken. I like to add some spice by adding some hot sauce, additional deep flavors with the fish sauce, and a splash of lemon juice along with jalapeños to my broth. 

Another plus: cleanliness of the restaurant.
author: Monica L.

description:
Although their noodles were great, the flavor isn't there. You really have to appreciate the taste of the noodles over the broth. It needed more ingredients/sauce to make the dish which it had little of on the table. 

The spring rolls and the egg rolls were delicious though.
author: Mo R.

description:
I'm not a huge lover of pho, but this place was recommended to me so I came to try it out and was not disappointed. I had the chicken pho and it was absolutely delicious. The soup was light yet very flavorful. The chicken meat was all dark meat, which was a perfect complement to the delicate taste and texture of the rice noodles.
One tip is that the large size is a lot of noodles. I usually can finish any dish put in front of me, but I couldn't finish it here. Then again, I also drank a lot of the pho soup because it was so delicious, so that might've filled me up!
Additionally the service was very good with the waiters very attentive and polite. I'm a tourist so the neighborhood was a bit of a surprise as it's a little bit gritty, but not an issue since I was there during the daytime.
In any case, next time I'm in SF again, I'll have to come back.
author: David D.

description:
This used to be my favorite breakfast spot, you'll find me here at 9am on weekdays, two or three times a week. The Pho Ga always made me feel so glowy! The noodles are always fresh and the soup clean and nourishing. My happy spot.

Anyways on my visit today I ordered the usual. The noodles were still perfection, the toppings the same. The only change I could tell was the soup. It was too salty, I couldn't finish it like I used to. Either they changed the brand of fish sauce they used to use to or added more in the batch today OR I came at a later time today than I used to (1pm) which means that water has evaporated from the pot hence a saltier broth. Honestly most people would not be able to tell the difference or care but my tastebuds are hyper sensitive. I left with a scratchy throat because of the saltiness.

Funny interaction: So I asked the cashier who I recognized from way back when, if they added extra fish sauce before serving out of curiosity because of the excessive saltiness. I did this with a big smile and sweet disposition, no bad vibes here! But damn I could see her nostrils flare as she dodged my question and made THE statement "We've been here 18 years and the ingredients are the same!" Lol calm your tits woman, that Viet coffee (aka liquid cocaine) got her wired!

The restaurant still smells exactly how it used to even though it moved a couple buildings down. Freaked out a little cause they changed location since my last visit 5 years ago! I thought they were gone from Larkin!

Perhaps I'll give it another go if I have the chance next time; I would definitely go very early in the morning. And I know not to make conversation if it's too salty! Hahaha
author: Cheryl I.

description: Not as good as the hype might suggest. The beef pho broth lacked flavor and tasted like chicken broth overcompensated with fish sauce. The wider noodles got mushy very quickly and were very bland.
author: Tony P.

description: Great pho! Excellent service. This place was packed during lunch. Our order came out fast and hot. Would recommend this place.
author: Melissa T.

description:
Customer service here is awesome!   All the girls work super hard to please their customers.  

I like Pho Gà (chicken pho) but Pho Gà Lòng (pho ga with gizzard, liver) is my absolute favorite!  You can tell the soup is good when the broth is clear and without fat floating on top of the bowl.  The traditional soup style is from the North of Vietnam so there won't be any hoisin sauce, bean sprouts, and basil leaves.  The most important ingredient for this soup bowl is the lime juice, so make sure you will get the most squeeze of your lime into your soup bowl!   The pho tai ( rare beef pho) is good too.  If you are under the weather, this soup bowl will help you to be a super man or a hercule!  Haha. 

The egg rolls are quite tasty but super small.  I like that the rolls came out super hot and super fresh.  You can get a single roll for $3.50 or a plate of three for $11.  I knock out one star for the service and for the small portion of the egg roll order.   

The rice plate with beef and the beef pan fried noodles taste just like my mom cooks!   Must try!   

I'm a FAN!
author: Ivory B.

description: One of my favorite places to eat. Broth is done so well. The owner is always so nice. Not sure if anyone has tried their sandwiches. But very underrated.
author: Anthony S.

description:
Came by for snacks the other day and it was surprisingly decent! There is a host that greets dining room customers upon entry and take out orders are taken at the cashier.

Ordered 2 pieces of imperials rolls that were heavenly, although a tad pricey at $2.95 a piece! They were tiny and quite similar to the ones I had in Ho Chi Minh City! :) The wrapper they use is very light!

Their Iced Vietnamese coffee was tasty too! Strong and not too sweet!

They take credit cards too! :)
author: Derek S.

description: It's ok place. I just didn't like one thing. Food was decent. But the spring rolls we ordered was old and hard. I know spring rolls. And I asked server can we have fresh she was keep doing it's fresh. Which is I know and she keep doing. Other foods are not bad. Spring rolls was hard and not fresh ask first. I just like people that say sorry. And she's saying it's fresh which is obvious.
author: Melody A.

description:
Man these guys know how to make a good bowl of noodles. I came here expecting regular Pho but got something way better! My buddy told me about this place and was raving about how good it was so we decided to give it a shot. I believe we ordered a large chicken noodle and some egg rolls with the soda egg yolk. 

The broth of the soup was soooo good. It was light yet flavorful and there was no trace amounts of msg (or at least it tastes that way). I hear if you want extra broth they charge you.
Turtle tower is a great alternate to Pho. They're so proud of their broth that they don't even have sriracha or hoison sauce. 

They do take credit cards which is nice for an asian place. For any soup noodle lover, this place is a must!
author: Milton F.

description: Great spot for dinner before a show at Great American music hall.  Fresh, delicious Northern Vietnamese food.  I only wish that the wrappers for the imperial rolls were a little thicker.  Minor quibble.
author: Amber B.

description:
NORTHERN Vietnam style pho, i.e. a super light, clean soup untainted by sauces, with wide-ish soft noodles and pounded, rare beef.

Yeah, I honestly didn't know what I was getting into when I got here. But the line was actually super short for a group of 2 on Sunday brunch so my friend and I dove right in. The reviews were great and I thought hey, why not try it. I've had a good track record with liking wide noodles.

Impressions: 
-Not sure if the pounding of the meat helps the tenderness or texture. 
-Not sure if the noodles should've been THAT soft or THAT stuck together
-Not sure if the soup was flavorful or just salty

Growing up I never ate much sauce, like the only thing I dipped up until high school was dumplings, so I didn't think I'd ever miss sauce until I tried the soup here, which really missed that little extra something. You can do clear and light and FLAVORFUL soup, just not sure thats what I experienced here.

All in all, the location is clean and bright and service was decent. Come try out this northern style pho for yourself!
author: Robin Y.

description:
I felt like getting pho for lunch and was feeling northern style noodles for a change so I decided to make a trek to the Tenderloin since Turtle Tower was renowned for their northern style noodles. When I got there, it was pretty crowded and there was a line, as expected since it was during Sunday afternoon. Ten minutes later, I was seated and I ordered the Chicken with Chicken Giblets Noodle Soup along with the Iced Fresh Soy Bean. 

The broth was pretty good, had a clear taste and the flat noodles complimented them. The chicken also had a very tame taste, as expected, and went great with the broth. I think I could have done without the giblets since they were still pretty tough when I bit into them. The dish was pretty flavorful and I finished the soup. The iced fresh soy bean drink was not overwhelmingly sweet and paired nicely with the pho. Overall, I enjoyed my meal here and have my eye on the Ph St Vang (Beef Stewed in Wine Sauce Noodle Soup) the next time I come back.
author: Nelson X.

description: The place to try Northern Vietnamese cuisine in SF! The name of this resto is based on a famous lake in Hanoi and a historic legend of a turtle that once visited it. Fun fact: now there are turtles inhabiting the lake to preserve tradition, and even one named "grandfather turtle"! The type of food served here is different from the typical dishes around the Bay that you will find originating from South VN, i.e. the pho is not served with a plate of fresh herbs and the broth is made with additional ginger. It's SO delicious and fills you with warmth and comfort, not unlike the feeling of sipping a warm hot chocolate by a fire :) I will come back for u 'n eat pho ga, Turtle Tower!!
author: Vicky N.

description:
So we were told it's apparently the "best chicken pho" in town. And it just happened to be a 2 min walk from our hotel so hell why not. We came around noon and there was already a line forming outside but we were lucky enough to get the last open table without a wait. Ordered the chicken pho because I wanted to see what this bowl of pho had to offer and ... it failed pretty miserably. The broth tasted like the can of an American chicken noodle soup, tons of oil visibly floating, and barely any chicken. And I mean close to none chicken chunks. The only thing I did enjoy was that the noodle wasn't your typical pho noodle. Instead it was the fat noodle like a pad see ew dish uses but still who cares. 

We were probably the only Asian customers at the restaurant, so I'm not sure if my taste buds are different from the others. But there was nothing special about the pho here. Yikes sorry =/
author: Jennifer K.

description: This is the best chicken noodle i ever had, especially the chicken meat dipping with diy sauce (fish sauce,chili,sriracha,lemon)
author: Jamie W.

description:
The food here is mediocre at best. We ordered the vermicelli soup, vermicelli with imperial rolls, and rice with chicken. All dishes were underwhelming. The spring rolls were just awful. Filled.with only lettuce and 1 small.piece.of shrimp. My dish came 30 min after everyone's. Pretty sure they forgot my dish. The service was non- existent as there were no apologies.

I live in the south bay so it may be that we are spoiled.with very good Vietnamese food. We also parked in the tenderloin to eat here and it was very disgusting to say the least. Trash all over the street, will be avoiding the area and this restaurant.
author: Eating And Living Well U.

description:
Maybe i came on an off day? It had been awhile since ive gotten my pho fix from here. I came in 30 minutes before closing.

Ordered #4 with tendon. Tendon was still hard and the soup was lukewarm. There was also really loud spanish music playing from the kitchen. 

At least, Service was really really good.
author: Lynn C.

description:
I always heard great things about the food from this place from coworkers, and they were right.

I came on a Sunday afternoon and there were many parties waiting outside on the sidewalk for a table. I would say the wait was about 30 minutes. 

I ordered the chicken pho, which I believe is their specialty. The chicken pho is different than any others I have had, but they serve it based on the Northern style so I have heard. The noodles served with this dish are also thicker than the normal "pho" noodle. Nonetheless, both the soup and noodles were exactly what I needed after a night out in SF.

The fried imperial rolls however were not as crispy and fresh as I was hoping for. I wouldnt recommend ordering those.

Overall, great place for chicken pho. My only setback is the location. We ordered an uber directly here and back due to the unsafe neighborhood it is located in. There was a lady blocking our ride as she was driving her "invisible car" in the middle of the street. Oh, tenderloin... perhaps this is why the place closes at 5pm on weekdays.
author: Claire W.

description:
There's no better way to hydrate your body than slurping on a bowl of pho after a night of heavy drinking!  Turtle Tower is special because they serve Northern style pho.  Northern style pho consist of a bowl full of fresh thick noodles.  The broth is simple yet very comforting and satisfying.  Don't bother to ask for hoisin sauce, bean sprouts, or basil here because they do not have it.  It comes with a simple side of jalapenos and lemon as garnishes.  

I usually order the beef combo and my friend likes to order the stir fried beef pho which is very tasty as well which I might try that next time.  The pho here is wonderful and service is quick and efficient!  You will often see the bald owner here, he looks intimidating but if you smile and say hi, he will smile and say hi back! =)
author: Melanie N.

description: They don't know how to make Pho. The broth was plain. I don't know why they put fresh ginger in Pho.
author: Violet L.

description:
Came here today for lunch and would definitely recommend! It's different than your typical pho as this place is northern style. I ordered the chicken broth pho and noodles were slightly thicker. The chicken was tasteful and didnt need any sauce. 

The broth is also good and didn't make me thirsty like how it usually does as no msg was added. Definitely will be back.
author: Galen W.

description:
Great chicken pho and Vietnamese coffee.
Came here for lunch with my co-workers. I was feelings but under the wether and one of my work peeps suggested chicken pho! I said "why not"

We took muni to civic center and walked down to the tenderloin to taste this awesomeness.

They sat our party of 9 right away. Most of us ordered the number 10 chicken pho with the chicken hearts and gibblets. 

It was soooo good! The noodles were soft and soup was just right. 

I would definitely try this place again!
author: Rommel Q.

description:
Mmmmm one of my favorite pho places. I wish they had a location in the east bay. 
Service is quick and friendly. I've never really had to wait for a table, maybe 15 mins on a Saturday. 
I always get their filet mignon pho. Doesn't need any extra sauces and they serve it simply with a side of lemon and jalapeños. 
Add an iced coffee or salty plum lemonade and it's a perfect quick, easy lunch stop in San Francisco. 
Parking can be difficult in the area. The location is in the TL but I've never had any issues.
author: E D.

description:
I am so addicted to this place for their northern style pho . And, unlike many other phos I tasted at Vietnamese restaurants, I don't taste MSG. The broth is so authentic and delicious.  

If you like northern style pho, this is the place to go !
author: grace k.

description:
Came here 20 mins before closing and there was no wait. 

I ordered the chicken pho and it tasted like chicken soup. The noodles are flat and thick, very different than normal pho noodles. I prefer it thicker cause it tastes more filling and soaks up more flavor. Chicken was tender and the pho would be perfect on a cold day. 

Girlfriend ordered the beef pho. Meat quality was good, but the broth was way too salty especially compared to the chicken broth.

Restaurant has a TV for sports and takes credit card.
author: Edward W.

description:
Order a small (because I am fatty and this was my second lunch) Ph Bò Ðc Bit and my second venture into northern style of pho which in this interpretation has wider rice noodles, a lighter broth and fewer veggies (only jalapeno and lime) and it was delicious!  I still miss the additional textures of the added veggies of southern style and prefer the richer depth of the broth but still very solid. The lighter (almost oily, but not in a greasy way if that makes sense) really compliments the wider noodles, everything just seemed to flow so nicely.

Didn't know chicken was their specialty at the time but would return to try that. 

They took credit card.  Super fast service as well.
author: Johnson L.

description:
Restaurants that offer Northern style Pho are always hard to find even in Vietnamese hubs like San Francisco! I accidentally found Turtle Tower while I was eating dim sum at Geary Bldv. Of course, I decided to check this place out right away. 

Turtle Tower was a busy place, we as a party of 4 had to wait for 25mins to get a table at 1:30pm on Sunday. I chose the Chicken Pho with giblets and was satisfied with my choice. The highlight of the dish was the Pho noodle itself. This was the only place that served the authentic noodle- the flat and wide type instead of vermicelli. I was so fed up at all Vietnamese restaurants that substitute vermicelli for Pho but Turtle Tower didn't disappoint me. The noodle was so on point! Love it. The broth was clear and sweet. I'm pretty sure this place uses bome broth instead of MSG to sweeten the broth! The chicken meat was good, containing both lean meat and chicken skin. The chicken's organs remind me of the Hanoi's street food as I always order a side of chicken's heart, gizzard,egg, giblets when eating Chicken Pho in Vietnam. Everything about the dish was lit! Oh, and don't forget to order raw egg yolk as a side order. It went so well with Pho Ga. 
I had Thai Tea for drinks and it was tasty too! It wasn't overly sweet. 

The staff here was friendly too! Although, I feel like the owner wasn't impressed at the fact that I'm from Northern Vietnam lol. He seemed a bit cold towards us.
author: Nhi D.

description:
If you are a Northern Vietnamesd, this is the place to find Northern Pho in San Francisco. 

Not everyone can be a fan of this place due to the different taste bud. Northern style of food is eater picky. The broth will be a bit different, no condiments whatsoever accompanied with your bowl of Pho. A lot of foodies will think it's weird. But I LOVE IT! Fresh noodle, and full of meat, the closest to home that I could ever find here in San Francisco. 

Shitty part is this place close at 5PM (understandable since it's in the Tenderloin).
author: Thao P.

description: No flavor. No sides. No hoisin, spicy, or vegetable sauces. Table smelled like mold. AND There was literally a large chunk of PLASTIC in my noodles. The waiter seemed indifferent and tried to shake it off as your typical 'oops'. Knowing he screwed up, he was too nervous to attempt to make the situation any better.  Don't come here if you want decent pho and decent service. No clue how this place has 4 stars. Don't fall for the conspiracy.
author: Shiqi L.

description:
It was my first time coming here. Usually I would pass by this place and there would always be a line of people waiting by the door. So one day seeing that it wasn't as busy I decided to drop in and I am glad I did. 

The soup was very savory and everything in the soup taste very fresh. I actually got the number 11 on the menu which is vermicelli noodle soup which has shredded chicken and pork with very thinly sliced eggs. 

Honestly, I would love to come back and try the other soup bowls on the menu.
author: Chinda O.

description:
I'm normally a pho bo kind of guy, but figured I'd get the pho ga here since that's what they're known for.  Their chicken broth is on point, but everything else was just ok.

Pho Ga: This is apparently the thing to get here.  A rich chicken broth that could rival your grandmother's.  The chicken itself was less impressive, just boiled meat which was pretty darn bland.  The rice noodles were thick and silky compared to the typically thin pho noodles; both have their merits.  Part way through I found myself just getting spoonfuls of the broth since I had enough of the other stuff.

Fried Imperial Roll: Can't even compare to the imperial rolls at Tu Lan.  These were small, thin and a bit skimpy on the meat.  A nice crispy exterior though.
author: Adam B.

description:
Came here for a team lunch recently. We ended up coming fairly late (around 2) due to annoying lunch time meetings, and when we arrived this place was maybe only 20% full. 

I've heard so much about Turtle tower and was really excited to try their pho ga (chicken pho) that they're famous for. I recently tried it for the first time in Oakland at Huong Que Cafe and absolutely loved it there, so I was curious how this would compare. 

Ordering was pretty straightforward, pretty much everyone ordered a large pho ga (#9). I asked for mine to not have cilantro and green onions. I'm really glad I did, because here the cilantro already comes shredded in your broth and not on the side with the jalapenos like most pho places do. 

Within a couple minutes, 5 giant hot steaming bowls of pho ga were placed before us in rapid succession, and we eagerly dug in. 

My favorite part of this dish was the broth, it had a very nice rich chicken flavor that I really enjoyed. As someone who grew up drinking a lot of chicken soup, I absolutely adore good chicken broth. The noodles are thicker than the usual vermicelli noodles you find in normal pho but still thinner than the ho fun noodles I had at Huong Que Cafe. I thought they were pretty good, but actually preferred the thicker ho fun noodles (though of course this is all personal preference).

I was disappointed by how little chicken there was in the dish though, especially since I had ordered a large pho ga. Also, the chicken is pretty bland and you're given this lemon based sauce to dip it in, but it was way too sour for me and I ended up pouring some fish sauce into dipping sauce dish and using that as my dip for the chicken. Here I really missed the bomb ginger/scallion dipping sauce they had at Huong Que Cafe.

Ended up paying ~$11 for my large bowl of pho ga.
author: Dianna H.

description: A Londoner in SF! Came here after reading the reviews and needing some noodle goodness after the long flight. I had the spring rolls and famous Pho Ga. Food was good but lacked a punch. Not as good as Pho in London. Staff friendly however, it's gotta be about the food!
author: Ratnesh S.

description:
There are a fair number of pho places in this area, heck, on this block, and while some of the others will give you a little more meat in your pho, there is a reason this place does not give you hoisin sauce like the others.

Their pho doesn't need any help.

The broth here is by far the best of the area. period. 

We did a blind tasting of this place, the one on 6th and Market, Pho 2000 and the Ha Nam place on the corner for fun the other day at the office.

4 out of 5 public servants for your fine City of San Francisco prefer Turtle Tower*

*Steve is crazy. No one likes Steve. We're not even sure why we invited him. ;-) jk.
author: Mike V.

description:
Vietnamese food snob here  because nothing ever tastes as good as Mom's home cooking but when Mom's in a idgaf mood about me and my pho ga craving, this is the go-to. The original Turtle Tower in the Tenderloin has been around for ages but with the long line and crappy location, I never gave it a real chance. Now that there's one within walking distance from my office and hardly ever a line--despite always being crowded--it's now my fave spot for a bowl of piping hot bowl of pho ga.

The clear broth is seasoned just right and perfect on a cold rainy day. The flat wide pho noodles are also cooked to the perfect soft but not soggy texture and the chicken is also always moist and never dry. It's so good that I'm not sure I'll be able to try any of their other dishes. Pho Ga ftw!
author: Ivy Z.

description:
I must have ordered the wrong thing because everyone is saying to get Chicken Pho, but I decided to give another dish a try. I ended up getting rice with grilled pork. It was not that great at all. The meat was dry and flavorless because not only was it cut into small pieces, there was minimal sauce and it was cooked too much and was just bland and hard. I really do appreciate the concept of Northern style Vietnamese cooking though. It gives you insight on how different the food culture is in varying parts if Vietnam. There is a significant difference in appearance and taste of dishes between Northern and Southern style Viet food. I want to try the Chicken Pho because everyone is raving about it in the reviews. 

The service was great. Our waitress was so sweet and was completely attentive the whole time.
author: Jenni T.

description:
---Cash Only---

Finally tried Turtle Tower after my buddy has been talking about it since the day I met him (no, not really but it sure felt like it). To be fair, if i'm going all the way to SF and I can probably afford to get something other than pho. Little did I know, my friend wasn't talking about the typical beef pho, he was referring to their pho ga. Oh shit, that makes all the difference because I've only had good experience with "chicken noodle soup" of any variety. 

The bowl itself was a good proportion and I really enjoy the "wide" noodles (I expected ho fun style but these were about 1/3 the width). The broth itself was super flavorful and we joked to ourselves about "not tainting the soup" by putting in sriracha or hoisin but a shit ton of lime would be okay. 

Definitely a great place to stop by if you're looking for an affordable and hot meal. Would definitely come back to try the beef pho!
author: Wiseley F.

description:
If I could give no star I would. Probably the worst Vietnamese food I've ever had and I've eaten at many.  The broth is nasty and meat lacks flavor.
Would HiGHLY recommend continuing your search.  If you can, try Le Colonial.
author: Darius M.

description:
This is the 2nd visit to Turtle Tower.  The 1st visit was with my parents who are from Haiphong, near Hanoi.   My parents were really disappointed with the broth quality and lack of flavor, and disagreed with the no sprouts, herbs, etc. approach.

I decided to give them another try to see if there are improvements.  Again, the beef broth completely lacks flavor and depth.  I cook my own Pho broth from scratch with oxtail and beef bones simmering overnight and as a American-Vietnamese woman, would like to think I know what good Pho broth is since I've been eating it for over 40 years in Vietnam and various parts of the world.

The worse part is the service.  They have inexperience servers who have standard, canned answers.  Here's the example.  I ordered as an appetizer the Goi Cuon (spring roll with shrimp and pork).  It came with the peanut/Hoisin sauce mix.  My dining companion has an allergy to peanut so I asked for just Hoisin sauce.  The young male server said "we serve our Pho Hanoi style, so we don't offer Hoisin sauce".  I replied, my friend is  allergic to peanuts so we need just the Hoisin sauce.  He said "we don't have any Hoisin sauce".  My reply, what do you think is in your peanut/Hoisin sauce mix?  You have Hoisin in the kitchen.  It was so frustrating, that we ended the conversation altogether.

My suggestions to Yelpers, find another place for your Pho as this is not worth the wait.  I am a big advocate of supporting my community and people, but don't think their Pho is good at all, especially for the price.
author: Cookie D.

description: This place is known for their chicken pho and it is great. It used to be on the corner and recently moved down a few doors to where it is now. They have been around for a long time and they have 2 other locations, one in the SoMa district and one in the Richmond district. Very good food. It gets crowded sometimes and sometimes a line, but worth it.
author: Peter K.

description:
Features:
-Oh my! I may come here every two weeks for the amazing pho!  This place is widely known for their Pho Ga and Giblets (chicken and intestines).  This Northern style pho is probably one of the best and most tasty noodle soups I have had.  The noodles were soft and the soup?  Amazing, delicious and really flavorful.  
-The Imperial Rolls were a bit expensive ($2.50?) for a roll but definitely really delicious.  Not only was the pho good, the rolls were well worth the amount you pay for.  Trust me, I eat a lot of noodle soups and this place really is just that good.  
-Good customer service and fast service!  

Improvement:
-Two bathroom stalls only.  

Tips:
-If you come here, make sure you at least try something with chicken because it is what they are known for.  
-Found meter parking within 5 minutes of getting there.
-Cash and credit cards accepted.
author: Kristy L.

description: I was not a fan of this place at all.  The broth was very bland and the neighborhood is horrible.
author: Kelly C.

description: Just thought I'd write an update... the pho here is still amazing!
author: Clifford T.

description:
This is my go to spot for pho in the City. The TL location is definitely the flagship of the franchise. Their service could be better, but honestly who cares when their chicken pho is arguably the best in SF. I grew up in the area but moved out a while ago, so it's always rare for me to make the trip into the TL. When I do come through though, Turtle Tower is usually a must-go.

You gotta know when to go and see who's working in the back though because the broth can sometimes come out hit or miss.
author: Zhi L.

description: Love it! Enough said.... Broth is the best! The Vietnamese sandwiches are perfect! Clean spot! Good service! Over all LOVE IT! And it's a must to cure the hang over!
author: Alfredo G.

description: Hole in the wall restaurant in a tough neighborhood. Awesome beef pho and chicken pho - the broth is light and flavorful, the noodle fresh, just like how it is in Hanoi. Bun Cha was the bomb. Fresh soy milk is very much watered down, and ice coffee is generally weak.
author: Ruby D.

description:
I ordered #13 fried spring roll and noodle (NO meat comes with it), $11.50. I can have meat with big tasty spring rolls and noodle under $10 in SF.

The portion was very minimal. Somehow the noodle was half the size than my friend #12 beef bbq and noodle, cause I was the last person of the day?

Two or three(?) fried spring roll were crunchy and fresh, but the size was shortest small hotdog, and it tasted like old dried veg burger without vegetables.

The dipping sauce was good, no smell of fish and taste was mild. Slices of garlic and carrot were in it.

Since I got only hand full, actually less, noodles, I asked for to-go pack for the spring rolls.

They didn't include the dipping sauce in the pack, which was another disappointment.

If I'm hungry and enjoy eating time, like more than 5 min, I'll definitely go to somewhere else.
author: Mut M.

description: I grew up eating Hanoi style Vietnamese food both from my relatives' own cooking and also from traveling throughout Vietnam. I can say the pho here is good! Broth is subtle in it's beef flavor and they always use fresh noodles. May not be for you if you're used to the southern style of pho where the broth is sweeter and has more anise/cinnamon. My mom and aunt really enjoy having their bun Cha Hanoi, with the grilled meats place in the dipping sauce along with picked carrots and radish. You take some rice noodles and veggies and dip it into the bowl of goodness and eat. However, they are quite stingy with the noodles so that you're always left with too much meat and sauce. Today, the grilled pork was way too tough. Was disappointed but will return if I'm craving some northern style Viet food.
author: Susan T.

description:
My girlfriend and I woke up from a night of drinking and realized we didn't really eat the day before. Starving, we were both craving soup. Ended up going to Turtle Tower last Saturday, March 26th around 9:30am as they were one of the only pho places open that early.

I've always loved the chicken broth here, but I was craving red meat as I had given it up for a little while. This was my first chance to eat some beef! Decided to get the number 4. Pho Bo Dac Biet: Combination of Rare Beef, Tripe, Well-done Beef Noodle Soup (Small $7.75). The broth was super flavorful. They only gave my gf and I one dish of jalapenos and two lemon slices to share, so we asked for an extra dish as I love extra lemon and jalapenos. Added some sriracha and I had an awesome breakfast! A small is perfect for me I love drinking all the soup and leaving the noodles. My bowl had a good amount of toppings.

Perfect meal after a night of drinking. I love digging into a giant bowl of pho. So comforting!
author: Elena N.

description:
This is the 1st time I've tried TT at this location. The interior has been remodeled and looks nice. Staff on a weekend are all youngsters who are friendly. 
They do a lot of takeout business on weekends. Hubby had the beef egg noodle and complained it was mostly broth. I also ordered a large but had the chicken pho which I liked at the Geary location. Didn't like the chicken skin so picked those out. 

It came with a dish of sliced lemons instead of lime and chopped pieces of jalapeños which strangely had no heat.  The entire lunch came to $24 with tip. It was good for a cold day to have soup. I gave Hubby quarter of my pho because I couldn't finish but 3-4 hrs later I was so hungry because the carbs just don't hold you.
author: Ry T.

description:
I'm giving this place 5 stars bc it gave me back life when I was dying. BEST PHO I'VE EVER HAD!!

F'real tho, this isn't just a normal pho place to go to when you're hungover. It's an amazingly clean and flavorful chicken broth that has the perfect slurpy thick noodles that just hits the spot without feeling bloated like ramen does.
