As much as I love ramen, this pho ga actually might come as a close competitor =X! 

Can't get over how great the #9 chicken pho was. I've had pho ga in Oakland and this was MUCH better. It's so simple too: broth, noodles, chicken, green onions, and cilantro. It was delicious enough that I didn't need to add any hoisin sauce or sriracha. Just added some jalapeños for a spicy kick and you have the most comforting chicken noodle soup you'll ever have. 5 STARS!!! You betcha I'm coming back.
author: Raquel Y.

description:
We ordered the large stir fried beef in rice noodle soup and the vermicelli with spring rolls as well as the three bean dessert drink. Portion sizes were small and prices were comparatively high. There was almost no meat in the noodle, and, for a large size there were very few noodles. The broth was watery. But the worst part was the stir-fried beef and vegetables that they had added to it--they were obviously cooked in a dirty pan and all of the burnt oil flavor had made its way into the soup, making the flavor terrible and adding a bunch of disgusting grease.

The spring rolls were small, mushy and flavorless and were served with a clump of rice noodles, a handful of mint, and some lettuce all in a plate. Again portion size was small and the price was high.

The bean drink dessert tasted alright but the yellow beans were undercooked and still hard. So sad.

Overall the food was poor quality and not well prepared. If you're looking for good pho or a real vermicelli bowl, look elsewhere.
author: James C.

description: If you are tired with oils and fats, come here. Its pho is the best choice for your busy healthy lunch. If you are into spicy food, also nice to add jalapeño.
author: Jun O.

description:
I have been going here since I was eight or nine and stopped going since they opened the new one. (I'm twenty now) The food just went downhill and the service is roughly the same. They portion off the food now and actually weigh how much chicken to give you instead of just grabbing a hand full and estimating. That already speaks alot. The place use to be packed with vietnamese based FOBS (shoutout to Eddie Huang and Fresh Off the Boat) and families. The atmosphere was very different from it is today. 

The place is now jam packed with hipsters, techies, and millennials. You rarely see a family there. 

Food: Food taste the same before but it is now mostly noodles and less chicken. The cuts of chicken are pretty bad mostly fat. They jacked about the prices by like a gazillion fold from what it used to be. 

Cashiers: The cashiers are the owners daughters and run a very good operation. 

Difference: You now have to ask for a fork or spoon and napkin with your to go order. They only give you ONE napkin which is ridiculous. Everything is portioned off and doesn't really have that same feeling as before.  The interior is pretty nice.

FYI I go to eat Pho ga on Noriega now,.
author: Brian C.

description:
I never thought I'd love pho ga until now! I am usually a beef pho noodle soup kinda gal, but because the reviews keep mentioning the chicken pho, I decided to stray from the norm and get that instead. My boyfriend got the beef pho which I actually thought was just okay and I LOVED their pho ga here! 

Service is super friendly here and they seem to always have business. Out of most Vietnamese restaurants in the TL this is probably one of the cleanest ones I've been to. They have other soup noodle options and bun bowls but they're most known for their pho ga. The noodles they use here are a little wider than the ones you have probably seen most commonly around SF and have a lighter broth taste to it, also known as the Northern style of pho. Prices here are fairly reasonable; around $8-$9 for small, $9-$10 for a large. Not bad!
author: Kathleen S.

description:
To my fellow Angelenos, if you go into Turtle Tower expecting the good old fashioned pho you're used to, you will be sorely disappointed. The pho here is Northern Vietnamese style and these are the key differences:

1. Less flavorful broth - broth is by far the most important element of a good pho to me and sadly, this broth tasted just like water. No powerful star anise or beef flavor punches! But I've learned this is just the style of cooking. A much more simplified flavor profile, which was sadly too lacking for me.
2. No garnishes - they will not give you the mounds of basil and bean sprouts that you might be used to. They don't even have hoisin sauce! Again, they're going for simple (aka bland to those of us used to the other style) flavors.
3. Flat thick noodles - a very big textural difference from the thin noodles I'm used to, but probably the least offensive to me. Still didn't like the slimier, softer texture of a thicker noodle, but not terrible.
4. Cut of meat - I'm a rare steak pho eater and I only later found out this place specializes in chicken pho. Sadly that was super evident in the fact that their beef was tiny and pretty much non-existent again in flavor. Naturally, I prefer the thick rare steak slices found in southern pho. 

So all that being said, don't get the pho if you're used to the Southern Vietnamese style found in LA. Also, don't get the egg rolls - they're tiny and expensive, but not very good. The thing that was good however was their banh mi! Highly recommend the pate and fancy pork mix - delicious. My friends also had a couple meat/rice dishes and those are definitely a better bet too. 

Different strokes for different folks!
author: Nadia K.

description:
I really hate to give this place only two stars but this is my review and my review is based on my personal preference.

I came here around lunchtime and although there are separate tables I was seated sharing a table with another solo diner. No problem since I'm used to my Pho place back home doing communal seating. But I did want to point it out since not many people may be familiar with this.

I read up on Turtle Tower and I came in well aware this type of Pho is different than what most of us are use to. It's Northern Vietnamese style, which means the broth will taste different, there are no condiments such as sirracha or hoisin, and the noodles are wider. 

So I started off with an order of two egg rolls, they ask you how many you want. An order only comes with one for $3 and some change so two came out to be over $6 which I think is fairly expensive for average sized egg rolls. There was nothing special about the egg rolls, they were good but average. One would have been enough per person but I was feeling fat so I had two to myself. Per my friend's recommendation I ordered the Chicken Pho. Normally I like beef but she said the chicken was amazing and that they use free range chicken and "it's sooo good" so I had to give it a try. The size of the noodles didn't bother me much and I used to eat Pho without any condiments anyway because I didn't like how it changed the flavor of the broth. It's all about the broth and it should be eaten pure. So here's my take on Turtle Tower's broth - not good. I wouldn't consider myself a good chef but I have made my own chicken stock. This stock tasted super plain, and looked plain, clear, not much character, as if it was just shelf stock you could buy from the store, however with a huge amount of SALT (msg?). My mouth is dry and craving water just thinking about it. Good broth to me has depths of flavor, not just salt. The broth didn't taste or even look like it had bones simmering for hours to develop a rich flavor, all I tasted was salty water. People seem to enjoy the broth but to each their own.
author: Debi N.

description:
More or less the same Turtle Tower before the move. This is the renovated location with more seating which helps with reducing wait times for those weekend hangovers.

Chicken pho, northern style is continuously lighter tasting than the myriad of Southern style pho shops throughout California. This one has the right amount of spice and isn't too watery or overly msg laden. Dip your chicken into some fish sauce mixed with peppers for some added kick.

Spring rolls are of your average kind, but a nice starter to your big bowl of pho.

Cleanliness, about a 6/10, tables are kind of sticky and there was some moldy looking lid on my table's chili sauce jar. Service is quick and to the point. Expect your standard quick eats pho shop.
author: Steven C.

description:
After gym, hungry again, looking for something light that wouldn't kill my workout effort by too much. Chicken noodle sounds good!

* * * EXPERIENCE * * *
Pros:
- No wait (Saturday ~1:30pm)
- Food came quickly
- Generally clean
- Appetizers (e.g. spring rolls) can be ordered by each piece so if you come alone you don't worry about having too much food

Cons:
- Not in the best location (always try to avoid it while I can)

* * * FOOD * * *
On the top of the menu there's a little paragraph stating this place serves Hanoi (Northern Vietnam) style noodle dishes and there will be no bean sprouts served. 

Pho Ga: A-.
I am not a Vietnamese food pro but I could tell the soup of Pho Ga here was a lot more clearer and less oily than other places. More importantly, I did not feel thirsty at all after having a lot of the soup so they didn't really put MSG in it I believe, yet it was flavorful enough. 

Free range chicken is another point the menu advertises to set this place different. And it's easy to recognize the chicken meat here having very strong "chicken" flavor in it. Small size cost $8 and it fed me well.

Fried Egg Roll: A-.
The size of the egg roll was on the small side, but it was deep fried well and the meat inside was quite flavorful.

I will come back again, next time probably I will try their steamed chicken!
author: Simon C.

description: I came here after an early morning hike so I was starving by the end of it all. One of my friends on this hike started to rave about the chicken noodle soup here so we just decided to go here. When we got there, the wait was about 10 minutes on a Sunday and it was definitely busy when we got there. There's a variety of options on the menu so you got plenty of choices. Everyone at my table got the chicken noodle soup (Pho Ga) and we ordered egg rolls on the side for the table. We got our food in a respectable time and from there, I added sriracha and jalapeños. I tried it out and it wasn't spectacular like my friend was telling me. It's not something I would rave about to my other friends. I ended up finishing my noodles but wasn't satisfied at all. I think it was the broth that wasn't good. If you're a big eater, I would get something else. I was still hungry when it was all said and done. Everyone has different taste buds so feel free to try it out yourself and judge it.
author: Steve H.

description: Turtle Tower has the best pho in the city (though pho2k down the street comes close).  They have the best broth - it's flavorful but not too heavy or oily. The flat noodles are cut relative short and you can easily put the noodles on the soup spoon.  Highly recommend the combination beef pho and the coconut juice. Pack your patient coz this place gets busy.
author: Andrew S.

description:
My friend said this spot was popular, so we came by despite the other two pho spots right next door. There was a 20 minute wait or so before we were seated. I was not very hungry, so just shared some of the pho with my friend. I have to say that this is one Americanized pho spot, which was not to my liking. They didn't have the usual sriracha, hoisin and chili sauce. The noodles were also a flat-thin version and the broth was pretty clear. To say the least, I was not impressed..

Edit: Apparently this is the original Northern Vietnamese version of pho, but still not to my liking..
author: Cindy Z.

description: Worth pho I have ever had ,chicken is so old and so little,customer service is bad .before when first open is was very ok ,since they are busy they are cut back a product of meat..
author: Hung T.

description:
Larkin yes; Geary no. It might have been the same ownership, I am not sure about the current situation, but there is a big contrast between the two Turtle Tower in quality and service. 

Too bad because the Geary branch is two blocks away from me, and for Larkin, I must get through the Tenderloin... no fun.
author: Janos G.

description: Best tasting broth and homemade noodles.  The beef brisks is yummy.  Ordered mine with raw egg on top.  Kind of expensive just for the egg....mayb next time I'll bring my own egg....jk.
author: The Batman Of S.F. V.

description: The pho here is pretty solid, but the resturant is a bit dingy, consistent with the location.   Other turtle towers are a bit better maintained.
author: Michael E.

description: Pho restaurant in SF is good. But the spin roll is so dry look like make not really fresh. Thai tea is so small glass. So test is good for Pho.
author: Somphop S.

description: did not remember how it was, so I guessed it is not too impressive ;) Honestly, it is so hard to find a pho that is impressive.. perhaps I will be able to find one one day...
author: Jane D.

description: I've been meaning to try this place for a long time and finally got to visit today for lunch. The area is super sketch, I had to dodge several zombies to get in. After all of that when I arrived the service was just OK. No one was friendly or came by to check on if I needed a refill or not. When I got my food the broth was meh in the beef noodle soup. It was bland and the meat was fatty. I was not impressed at all especially considering the amount of way better pho places in the city. I would definitely not be coming back here
author: Lovejoy K.

description: Good northern pho. Clean broth and clean flavors. The chicken was really tender and so were the noodles. The chicken Rita was really good and crispy too.
author: Dustin T.

description:
My all-time favorite restaurant HANDS DOWN on the block. No matter what kind of food it is, this exact location and restaurant is my favorite. One, because the owner is always here and always remember my girls and I face and always welcomes us with a nice smile and a "how you been" which is so important in this world because to me, that is one of the biggest things that brings your true customers back. Two, you can always expect a the same DELICIOUS flavoring in their Pho. It's a different style of pho, with the thicker noodles, which to my knowledge is how they do it in the specific region or Vietnam where they serve this style of pho. It is always so promising, and very generous with their portions. They offer both small or large, and every time I come back I always have to second guess myself getting the large because it is always so filling. Lastly, their food and their service is at the level where I feel like every long standing restaurant in SF has to be at. The kindness of their servers, runners, and cashiers are always so nice and polite. Also their food will never disappoint or ever shock me because of the consistency of their dishes. 
Thank you very much Turtle Tower TL, you'll forever have my service till the day I die!
author: Nick A.

description: This place was clean and service was quick.  Pho soup broth was awesome.  Was in the area and decided to try their pho.  Thumbs up.  Recommend to try if you're in the area.
author: Joseph L.

description: Simply put, this is the best pho in San Francisco. Family-owned and operated, Turtle Tower is incredible - rich broth, delicious noodles and high-quality chicken and beef. This is a must-try for anyone and everyone!
author: Darius T.

description:
This place always MAKES MY DAY! Their noodle soups with chicken or raw beef is fantastic and the price is really amazing: 7.25$ for a small
Soup which is not small at all! also really quick good service: as a side note, they accept cash only! But really best deal around the area for best Vietnamese! Yum yum!
author: Irina P.

description: Turtle Tower? More like Turtle Power! One sip of the Pho Ga's ooze pumped me from being a hung-over shell of a man to a hero ready to take on his villains. The chicken pho here is easily the best that this dude has ever had. Flavorful and clean bodacious broth paired tender pieces of white and dark meat had my taste buds feeling far-out. The radically shaped noodles seem to be handmade and shredded. $2.95 for one imperial egg roll is also a bogus price. An area of improvement would be the painfully slow bummer of a service.
author: Alexander W.

description: This place is unbeatable.  I order the large pho ga #9 every time and have been for the past 12 years.  I don't know how it can be beaten. Not joking. Clean flavor. Perfect. A+.
author: Leman B.

description:
I came to Lil Saigon hoping for Southern styles Pho. I just walked in assuming (oops) and there was a long line waiting for lunch so I wanted to give it a try. Their pho was good not as great as the restaurant (Broth in Torrance) in LA I go to for northern Pho.

Overall, it is a homey delicious Pho. You can taste the hours spent on the broth with all the fat/oil trimming. We also order spring rolls, their peanut sauce has more hoisin than I preferred (I like it for peanutty with actual nuts inside).

Tip: make sure you want northern style Pho when you come here haha. Also, there most likely will be a line if you go during normal meal times.
author: Shyann C.

description:
Turtle tower is known for their chicken broth instead of the usual beef broth. I was unsure about it at first but after taking a sip of the soup, I was sold. It was really pleasant and refreshing. I'd love to have this on a cold gloomy day and will be cheered up. Also perfect for when I'm sick. Now I'm glad caviar delivers turtle tower. 

Next time I'd like to try their chicken porridge(congee). That would be even more perfect when I'm sick.
author: Rohenne L.

description:
We often make pho at home.
Preparations of this place were all wrong
Our family had noodle soup here 
Noodle soups were lukewarm. Waitress offered to warm via microwave but noodle will screw up when microwaved
We have been here twice and they screwed up twice
author: GQ G.

description: I've tried tons of Vietnamese restaurants in the city over the last decade and Turtle Tower is hands down BEST pho in the SF.
author: Austin G.

description:
Northern style pho. It's the best pho outside of Vietnam. 

Get the classic pho ga. You won't find anything better.
author: Sara H.

description: My go-to pho in SF for 15 yrs!  just landed at SFO and straight here...N. Vietnam pho perfection in a bowl.  I have kept quiet but clearly word is out.  Thanks Steven, keep the good pho phlowing:)
author: Scott P.

description:
Fantastic!  but I only order the chicken noodle soup why try anything else?  I have wanted to try other thing but the Chicken Poh is soo good!

We have been going here before my kids were born. Many may not know it but the Chicken Noodle soup is the way to go! You have to try it!. Brothy, not oily with a lot of flavors. I also add a Vietnamese coffee. Yes, it is slow drip at the table but it is so good. Let it most of the coffee drip from tabler brewer then stir to combine condensed milk, then pour over ice. 

It is an adventure getting there because of the area but worth the risk. There is really not much of a risk just a lot of homeless so stay on the opposite side of the street and watch where you step.
author: Brian W.

description: Best Chicken Pho I've ever had! Great atmosphere. Luckily we didn't need a reservation, but the place was quite packed.
author: Aaron D.

description:
I've been many times to Turtle Tower.  Went again Sun 8/30/15 and got there before 11am, no wait for a table.

I got Pho Tai Ga Small $8, not on the menu, secret dish you can ask for.  Very tasty.
Cafe Sua Dua $3.45 - slow drip at your table, I like

Saw a bunch of Older white ladies - none got the famous chicken noodle soup.  One even asked for soy sauce.

One white guy came w/ an Asian guy and he could not get his dish.  Had to send dish back because he wanted "crispy" chicken - I'm guessing he wanted Fried Chicken. He doesn't know it's not known for Fried chicken in Northern Vietnamese cuisine.  Then he wanted Pan-fried noodles (a Chinese dish!) - Still not what he wanted.  So much drama.  Just eat the food or leave!!  Aiya.  Was painful to watch, glad I was done quick and didn't have to listen anymore.

Randy F. said they take credit cards even AmEx, I've been paying cash!  Oops, next time, Charge it!!

2 unisex bathrooms in the back - no key needed, someone's in there if taking forever.
author: Ann L.

description:
Meh...the food was aiight...staff super friendly.

Ordered #2 Pho Tai - Rare Beef Pho. I love flat rice noodles, so that's a plus. The broth was warm and mild in flavor. The temperature of the broth probably helps when they are super busy and people need to eat quick. The beef confused me. It looked and tasted like it was pounded together, more tender than regularly sliced rare beef but fully cooked and not rare at all.

It's known for their chicken pho and that's why we decided to come here. The other person I was with prefers chicken pho over beef pho. He thought the chicken broth was delicious but preferred the regular pho noodles.
author: D V.

description:
First time to this location - been to the other TT several years ago and remember it was some of the best pho I've ever had. 

Yup, location is a bit sketchy being in the Tenderloin. I wonder if this is why they close at 5pm. We drove around and found a metered parking spot - hoped my car would still be intact when we got back. Walking in - the restaurant was more open than I expected and overall seemed clean. Ordered the pho ga (they have small/large sizes) - food came pretty promptly. It's served with a few slices of hot pepper and lime on the side. Don't think bean sprouts are part of this style pho.  Besides the fat white noodles, it comes with chicken, chopped cilantros, and onions. The broth is what sets this place apart - it's tasty with just enough flavor. That plus the noodles and the cilantro/onion garnish make it a go-to comfort food. 

Paid $8 for a small. They do take credit cards, though I am not sure if there's a minimum spend. Service was alright. I'd come here more often if I actually lived in SF.
author: Laura C.

description:
I love the heartiness of the chicken pho here. Lots of green onions so ask to be put separately if you don't like it that much. 

My boyfriend and I go here every time we're starting to feel under the weather and the pho always hits the spot!
author: Vi T.

description:
You have to come here knowing the difference between Northern style Pho and Southern style pho. This is the former. The broth will be different and you don't garnish with condiments. This broth has a stronger fish sauce flavor vs. the south is more centered in bone marrows. They're different and delicious in their own ways.

Anyways, back to TT... I had the chicken pho and it was deliciously flavored. A little bit on the oily side but that adds depth to the broth. I also had the spring rolls and they tasted fresh as the first day of spring!
author: Thao T.

description:
No stars for this place. If I can take away that one star, I would. 
I see a lot of people waiting outside to get in for lunch. I don't know what all the hype is about. So I had to try it. 

I brought my nieces here for lunch. The place was really busy. The service was fast, but I felt like they where rushing us. 

The food was so bad. I took some pictures of our lunch but ending up deleting them because I didn't want to remember the food. 

My niece ordered a Thai iced tea. There was a little dead fly in her tea. I complained to the server, and he didn't seemed like it was a big deal. He brought her a new one. But we felt like he just scooped the fly out and refilled the glass. 
My niece was not going to drink it. So the server said he needed to check with the manager and came back to say they will not be charging me for the tea. Needless to say, we will not be coming back to this restaurant. 

If you want good Vietnamese food, go a few doors down to Golden Lotus.
author: Edie G.

description: Pho was awesome! The noodles were sooooo good! Prices were on point and the restaurant was clean. Definitely coming back when I can!
author: Katie G.

description:
Love this place! My brother took me here because he's a regular and won't stop talking about this place! My brother moved out of the house a couple of years ago, so he doesn't get to enjoy my moms homemade chicken broth whenever she makes it. This place takes that void away because the food feels like moms cooking! 

The workers there are all so nice and since my brother is a regular, the owner gave us an extra order of their delicious egg rolls because she knew my brother was treating me out and it was my first time so she wanted to make it special. 

The parking is terrible but if you're lucky, someone will be pulling out of their parking spot right as you drive by!
author: Jamie C.

description:
Probably the best and most authentic Northern style Pho Ga (chicken pho) in the city. Most pho restaurants serve Southern style pho. The Northern style is very different; the chicken is prepared with the skin still all (adding more flavor to the broth), and there's no basil leaves or bean sprouts traditionally served with the pho, just slices of lemon and spicy green peppers. There's also no hoisin (sweet plum) sauce at the tables, but they've now added Sriracha sauce to the table condiments.

FYI: the fresh spring rolls come with shrimp and pork inside (not vegetarian).
author: Audrey L.

description:
The pho was made with Chinese rice noodles (ho fun).  This means that the noodles were too soft for pho.

The quantity of food was also kinda skimpy.

I will stick with my favorites in San Jose.
author: T Y.

description:
They moved to the next door building for more room and modernized the interior of this place!

Their classic favorite of mine is their chicken noodle soup!  Ask for extra jalepeno slices and lemon wedges!  I love it zesty!

It's a great comfort meal - especially during the cold days!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Note this review is from a Caviar delivery. I've only been to the Turtle Tower in SoMa, which was delicious. 

I was craving for some chicken noodle soup because I've been having a miserable cold all weekend. After 3 hours from making my order on Caviar, I finally got my food delivered to the front door. (It was Pride weekend, so I understand the delay, no biggie) But upon excitedly opening up the bag of food, I found that Turtle Tower was missing half my order. Whyyyy...

So if you ever order delivery, there's no point ordering a large. Why? Because they only end up giving you a large container of soup. No more extra noodles, meat, or veggies. You get the same portion of everything as a regular sized order. Just more soup. Ugh. Totally gipped.

Second. I ordered extra chicken for $2. Did I receive extra chicken? Nope.
Third. I ordered extra egg noodles for $2. Again, missing. All of them were in same portions in their take out boxes.

Caviar refunded me $5 but I honestly think I deserved more than that. What a waste of 3 hours waiting for food only to get my order wrong. I do admit the Pho Ga (chicken pho) is really good and I love all the veggies they add to the mix. Sadly, I'm very disappointed in Turtle Tower and probably will never order delivery from them ever again.
author: Janet H.

description:
This review is only for this location. I've never had the bahn mi at any other turtle tower. I wanted the sandwich to be everything. I got the chicken and pate on my one. It's not very flavorful and I wish there were more, and fresher, vegetables.
I'm going to stick with the Bun cha ha noi that has delicious flavor and tons of food in the dish.
author: Alexandra R.

description:
I'm a fan of this style of pho! It's noticeably different than the other pho restaurants I have tried. The wait can get pretty long at this place. On a Saturday afternoon it was about a 30 minute wait. It's not in the best part of town but worth the visit. The service is very friendly and were attentive to us. They used to be cash only but they take credit cards now.

I ordered the small #1 well-done flank and brisket beef pho ($6.75). The bowl was so good I actually wish I had ordered a large. The soup is very flavorful I didn't need to add any sauces to it. The noodles are a lot wider than the pho I've had in the past. The soup is lighter and full of green onions. There's also no bean sprouts and basil to add but trust me you won't miss it.

The rest of my table ordered the popular pho ga (chicken pho) which they all loved and have been raving about. I thought it was tasty but I actually liked the beef better. My friend said it was the perfect hangover dish. We also got thai iced tea and three color bean dessert (each $3) which were both pretty good.

Overall I highly recommend that you try this place out! You can't compare it to the other popular pho restaurants since the style is so different.
author: Linda X.

description: Hands down the best Pho in town. You can taste the care that they have taken in each dish. The flavors are wonderful and fresh. I am so happy that I found this little gem in the Tenderloin. I recommend getting number 1 with fresh spring rolls.
author: Asa H.

description: Best pho I've ever had. Worth the 30 minute wait. Every ingredient is the highest quality. Broth is perfectly balanced. Noodles and even sriracha is house made. All the beef is very tender and high quality.
author: Jasper P.

description: Soups are amazing, so simple but soooo good but do not order appetizers simply rip off..for 1 not 2 just "1 imperial" cut into 3 pieces was $3.25 n not even worth it...
author: Kam D.

description: I love this place. This is where I want I eat when it is cold and Rainy. I was introduced to this place with in college and fell in love. It really helps keep you warm and cozy.
author: Nicole C.

description: Horrible pho and the soup was too greasy and plain. The noodle wasn't fresh and the meat quality was bad. The cost was expensive but the overall quality was bad. I think they use the chicken broth for everything cuz all their soup taste the same. There's not different if it's beef or chicken pho. Not coming back here, there are better pho place.
author: Lexie H.

description:
Has that home-cooked chicken pho taste. I remember when this used to be farther down and I personally think it used to be better when I was a kid. It's definitely now overhyped by all the yelp reviews. I didn't really see anything super special about this place, since my family makes chicken pho about once a week. (Personally, I don't think it's worth the wait for chicken pho, there are many other places that will give you the home-cooked chicken pho feeling.)

Give it a try if chicken pho is your go-to. I didn't really try anything else from here but will definitely do that if I ever come around here.
author: Polly L.

description: Is there a way to give negative stars? By far the worst culinary experience I've had in the Bay Area. If you want to line up in the Tenderloin for tiny portions of bland noodles with no meat and no vegetables, this is the place for you!
author: Guo Jie C.

description: Been to this location 3-4 times in the past three years, and every single time the waiter/waitress got our orders wrong one way or another. And the cashier or manger ended up fixing the order. Other than that, foods is okay here.
author: Jessica Z.

description: The pho size is generous. Lacks a little flavor. The pork rolls were fantastic and the peanut sauce pretty incredible.
author: Aj P.

description: Ha Noi style pho. Was good and flavorful but when I eat pho I expect the bean sprouts and basil and hoisin sauce and you cannot get those items here. What you can get is fresh egg yolks in a bowl that is VERY hard to find in San Jose. Definitely a plus. Friendly service and helpful staff. I did not expect that at a pho joint and was pleasantly surprised. I had the chicken pho and joe had the beef pho (tai). I think the beef was a tad bit more flavorful then the chicken broth but maybe it was just an off day.  I do appreciate the fresh pho noodles though. They were yummilicious. The spring rolls looked awesome from the table next to us. I will have to give them a try if we ever decide to come back.
author: Janet D.

description:
In the mood for authentic Northern Vietnamese cuisine? 

Bring some time for the wait and study the extensive menu. You'll find PHO, BÚN, COM ÐĨA, and BÁNH MÌ, with the STIR FRIED BEEF PHO ($9) being my absolute favorite. The beef is stir-fried, the noodles pan-fried, and together with celery, carrot, onion, and leek they make for an extremely flavorful composition. If you're a fan of rich noodle soups, this is it.

I need to try more of their menu next time.

This location on Larkin is one of three but the original one. According to the reviews below it has the best flavors, and I definitely can't argue with that.
author: Sebastian F.

description: I love this place! I come here 1-2 times a week for their chicken pho.  They are fast and food is consistently good. You should def check them out!
author: Kim H.

description:
I can't help but love this place. The first time I went here I ordered some beef pho as a benchmark item and I wasn't impressed at all. I only come here for the chicken pho (pho ga now). I never order chicken pho anywhere and don't ever prefer chicken over beef pho, but this place has got it right. I've tried to replicate their broth very unsuccessfully at home... this place know's what's up with their chicken broth! Can I have your secret recipe, please?

It's like comfort food now - like the chicken noodle soup or whatever your mom made you growing up. Except now this place is my ultimate comfort food for a hangover cure or when I'm sick. I also like the version of noodles they use here too ("northern vietnamese"); it's not the pho noodles you may be used to, but it sort of kicks ass. I'm a sucker for wide noodles. Yum yum yum. Also, this place moves extremely fast. Served pho for here or takeout in 10 minutes or less.
author: Joanne Y.

description:
We are staying at Union Square and were craving a hot bowl of pho. We came here because they were one of the few noodle places that accept credit cards

I was a little skeptical when we first sat down. The tables didn't have plum sauce, siracha, or green pepper slices - staples of vietnamese pho places of my childhood. And the chopsticks they laid down for us were noticeably sticky. The menu is a lean selection of the classic pho bowls - primarily beef with some chicken choices (no vegetarian or seafood options). When our bowls came (beef combo and chicken), I was surprised to see that the plate of fresh greens that usually comes with pho bowls (mint, basil, beansprouts, and lemon/lime), was merely green peppers, and lemon in a sauce bowl. 

However, when we tried our bowls, the noodles made up for our misgivings. Fresh pho are hard to get right. Put the noodles in too early and they cook too much and break in your chopsticks before you can get them into your spoon. Too late and the soup is cold, or the noodles are tough. This place got the noodle texture right. We were also pleasantly pleased that our order came exactly as requested, and in a very timely manner. The soup itself was not too salty, though I would have preferred more spices (but my personal preference). R loved his bowl - pretty much inhaled it. Service was wonderful. We were in a rush, and they were accommodating about processing our payment early.
author: Elaine T.

description:
Nothing can beat TT ever. Best pho ga everrrrr. One sip of their broth and it will cure all your sicknesses and hangovers. 

Ok ok real talk tho. Their chicken broth is so deep in flavor - chicken is tender and they aren't stingy with how many pieces they give you - ample amount of cilantro yum - and all you gotta do is mix your own fish and chili sauce to dip that chicken in. 

Talk about heaven in your mouth.
author: Ava F.

description:
225. Heard about the hype so I popped in.  I don't like to jump on the bandwagon, but I have to agree with everyone else about the chicken noodle soup-- it's the best you can get around here.

They don't throw in a lot of ingredients, which is nice because chicken noodle soups should be simple, yet flavorful.  And Turtle Tower does it right.  The soup is not super salty.  I don't have to chug water after I eat!  Yummy comfort food at a bargain.

I do wish they put the soup in a container meant for hot fluids.  When I order to-go, it's always in a plastic container, which bugs me because of potential carcinogens.  But I'll sacrifice that once in a while for good chicken noodle soup.
author: Katherine C.

description:
I always get the Number One in all pho places. You know, the pho with basically everything on it - tendons, flank steak, and beef balls. So I like to consider myself a Number One connoisseur. For this place, I foolishly went here based on the stars alone and not reading the reviews. So I ordered my typical Number One and was somewhat disappointed. Sure it was good; the broth was flavorful (and tasted really fresh), but I've definitely had better Number Ones with more of a kick to the broth. It was just OK in my opinion, definitely not four star quality!

Somewhat disappointed, I went back on Yelp after lunch to read what the fuss was all about. Apparently the fuss is all bout the chicken pho, which is a dish I've actually never thought of ordering at any pho places because I think that the broth would overpower the chicken. Intrigued though, I decided to go back and give this place another chance (also brought a couple of co-workers for me this time for company). We all ordered the chicken pho, and right from the moment our waiter brought out our soup, you can smell it. The aroma was so fresh and inviting, as if its as made out of all fresh ingredients! And the broth was perfect for the chicken; it was flavorful, yet not strong enough to overpower the taste of the chicken. In other words, the broth really complimented the chicken nicely. 

Service here is always top-notch. They are polite, attentive, and speedy. I definitely recommend this pho place out of the thousands (OK, not literally "thousands) of pho places in the Tenderloin. But don't forget to get their chicken pho rather than their Number One!
author: KJ S.

description:
Are you one of those people who love the whole ritual of submerging the bean sprouts in the broth, tearing up a few basil leaves, adding a bit of Hoisin and Sriracha into your pho? 

Sorry to disappoint you, but none of that here at Turtle Tower.

Rightfully so: the broth is supremely flavorful, whether you go with the popular pho ga, beef pho or the stir fried beef pho version. All you need is a few squeezes of lemon to brighten it up and then dig in and slurp the perfect chewy rice noodles. 

Like Kathleen U, my pho gha didn't have that much chicken in it. And do not linger at the table, the servers will come by several times to ask if you need everything else. Turtle Tower remains popular as ever and you're not the only one who's hungry for a bowl of their lovely soup.
author: Janice C.

description:
If I had to choose one SF restaurant to eat all future meals from, this is probably it. Thank you, Turtle Tower. You're a beacon of light in the deep Tenderloin.

Dreaming of bathing in a tub of pho ga
author: Juliette W.

description:
I was in the mood for pho ga...where else to get some but Turtle Tower.  Honestly, I thought it was great before but now it's just eh okay.  I got the pho ga with gizzards and stir fried beef with rice.  Stick to the pho.

I used to be a huge fan, now I'm just a medium fan.
author: Lyn C.

description:
Went several times and different locations.
Beef and chicken pho everytime tasted so good.
Especially I love thick noodles inside.
The place is clean and runs well by their owners.
The location is in Tenderloin district, which is not good for walking, but it's worth the taste of food
author: Sergey S.

description:
Don't bother.  I ordered a large bowl of Pho that was gross... filled with a large amount of fatty tripe, that is listed as flank steak and brisket.  The "Owner" is rude and unaccomodating, most likely because I am white, and not Vietnamese.  She said that I could eat it like everyone else, or she could make it to go.  I will never come here again.

Go to Kevin's Noodle House on Irving for Pho... you won't be disappointed.
author: Pete S.

description: Chicken pho here, is amazing!  Cold weather necessity.  This recommendation is backed by the FD staff of HI City Center.
author: Isabel G.

description:
I was going through some major pho withdrawls until my job moved to the area. I called up my girl Mariela D and we met to have lunch here one day. It's a popular lunch place, but we were able to get a table before we could even write down our names. 

We both ordered the Rare Beef Pho with an extra side of Rare Beef. They were served with jalapenos and lemon - no basil or sprouts, which is new to me. The large bowl was big, but they also come in small if you want just a little of this and that. 

The broth was pretty good, I made my soup extra spicy with extra jalapenos and sriracha. I was determined to eat the whole bowl, but could not. It was so filling that when I got back to the office, I wanted to take a nap. Loved it.
author: Rebekah T.

description: I eat out all over San Francisco and have eaten at many "grouchy Asian restaurants" but that was in the distant past. Not really it was just a couple of months ago  Pho 2000, ha. Turtle Tower is typically busy dishing world class pho yet they maintain a friendly attitude of customer service for all.
author: SF T.

description: Came to try the chicken pho (pho ga)! Not the pho most people are used to, but different isn't bad! It tasted very similar to chicken noodle soup. The broth had a deep flavor to it, and the noodles are flat and thin to go with it. It was a familiar taste, but nonetheless tasty.
author: Jeana Y.

description: Yes yes yes i love this place and try to come as often as I can.  How can something be so simple yet so flavorful and delicious? The broth is to die for I have not found a pho place in the city or anywhere that has even come close to turtle tower and trust me i have tried. To top it off they just started offering a loyalty card that will give u $10 off after 10 purchases. I know i will fill that up quick...if you haven't tried this place you are seriously missing out.
author: Krystal S.

description: This is one of my go to places for pho. I enjoy the chicken pho with giblets. The amount provided is not too small nor too much. It definitely made me full during lunch. It's best to arrive before maybe 11:50am before the crowds rush in. I've always biked here and haven't gotten my bike stolen yet. I definitely recommend this place.
author: M L.

description:
This review is based on my TO-GO experience.

The boss was at an important meeting at Turtle Tower that I wasn't invited to, but I was lucky enough to have one brought back to me! Yay! 

The boss was leaving the office and I asked him where in the world he was going. He said he was getting Vietnamese food and I demanded for a sandwich. Because c'mon, Vietnamese sandwiches are super bomb no matter how long it's been sitting around and who knows how long his meeting will take. Then he tells me he was going to Turtle Tower and my eyes widened and I screamed for the chicken noodle soup!.... AND a sandwich (hey, my stomach can commit to multiple!) If I know my boss well enough, he definitely ordered everything all at once, meaning his food, my food and a couple other lunches for the office. So I expected it to come cold and soggy as my stomach was eating it's insides.

When it came, it was surprisingly a smaller portion than I had expected, but it was the perfect portion (I'm sure they give more when you eat in shop though). I opened the Chinese take out box and I salivated as the smell of the chicken and rice noodles burst into the air. The chicken was extremely moist and flavorful and the broth...OH LAWD. The broth is amazingly salted and chicken flavored. It was a bit oily but you can tell they cooked a farm of chicken in their kitchen. I immediately dumped my noodles and chicken into a medium sized bowl and drowned my ingredients with my soup. It was warm but I had no patience to heat this baby up so my chopsticks just began to dig for treasure. The mix of the chicken and noodles eaten together was AMAZING. I just... I can't... I don't know how else to explain it!

Honestly if you don't like the hole-in-the-wall, mom-and-pop-shop, oily-but-delicious, and super-hyped-but-I-totally-agree kind of food then... You should come and try it anyway!
author: Linda K.

description: Great tasting comforting bowl of chicken noodle soup.  Service is usually good. I usually get the chicken with the gizzards. Easy a good lunch spot for under $15 a person.
author: Jason L.

description:
I was craving pho and stumbled upon this place based on my housemate's recommendation.

Location is sketchy, but at least the interior was clean. That's a plus and change for a Vietnamese restaurant (no generalization intended)!

I ordered #4, which was their pho noodle soup with rare meat, tripe, and something else...beef-related. Service was quick and attentive! I got my order in less than 5 minutes, which was phenomenal.

Then it starts going downhill....
My soup was relatively hot, which was good. However, the broth was a bit bland and I wished it had a stronger flavor. 

Unlike most other pho restaurants, this place served a different variety of pho and used flat white noodles instead. Can anyone say yummy? Yum! However, the rice flavor sadly overwhelmed the bland soup, which was a disappointment to me.

The beef .. was another let down. I usually like my beef rare-ish, but their meat felt like it just came out of the fridge. It was cold and that did not match up well with the warm broth.

I also really tried to like the broth, but I couldn't convince myself. After a few sips here and there, I eventually gave up and called it a day.

Will I come here again? Debatable, but mostly not. I paid about $9 for a large bowl.
author: Chinsin S.

description:
+ Food
The Pho Ga (Chicken) and their Hanoi-style (Northern) Beef Pho were probably the best in San Francisco before they moved to their new location on the same block a few years back. I used to come here almost every week for lunch with my family, and we loved it! But for some reason, I have started to dislike or to not appreciate their Pho as much as I used to when I was a kid. The soup isn't as rich and tasty as I remember it, and every time I have eaten here recently, I just left unsatisfied. 

Some people have stated that their meat feels awkwardly cold when ordering Pho Tai (rare beef noodle soup). The way I was taught to eat it was to allow the rare beef slices of meat to actually cook in the broth. Just wait a few minutes before pigging out and TA-DA, no more cold slices of meat.

Their noodles are different from most other places. They use flat white noodles. You also do not add bean sprouts and all those vegetables you usually get at other places. Just squeeze some lemon/lime juice to add some tang and you're golden.

+ Ambiance & Location
Still on the same block but much cleaner and much more modern than their previous location down the block. I like how they managed to improve so much more over the years.
Service is relatively quick, especially when there is still a huge line waiting outside to slurp the same noodles you're probably eating at the moment.
Note to myself: Cash Only.

Overall, I will still come every now and then, but probably not once a week. Their Pho Ga and Tai are still relatively good and for sure on the better side of most Pho restaurants in the Bay Area. I just wish it tasted as good as it used to be back in the day. Or maybe, I'm just getting too old and I can't taste good food... Go figure.
author: Alex L.

description: The second best pho restaurant on Larkin street. I like the pho bo (beef) at pho 2000 better. The pho to get at this place is pho ga (chicken). It is very good.
author: Karl K.

description:
There is a lot of places in the TL that you can go to for pho. This can possibly be the best one. This restaurant looks a lot bigger once you go inside. There is plenty of seating for different sizes of parties, and the wait time here for a Saturday lunch was negligible. The place is well lighted and the restrooms were clean and well-maintained. 

My friend told us that this place is known for their #9, the Pho Ga. I decided to get the large size as I was very hungry. The Ga was pretty good and tasted different than the other soups I get in LA. The broth was full of flavor and the portion size was perfect. We also got spring rolls which tasted pretty good with the peanut sauce. I was well satisfied with my selection.

The service here is pretty good. The spring rolls and the soups arrive in a orderly fashion. The wait was not too long. The people working here were respectful and kind. I enjoyed my time here, and my friend that lives down the street told me that he's going to make this his go-to pho place. I definitely see myself coming back here when I'm in the area.
author: Jason P.

description: Vietnamese coffee here is always so strong I love it. This location has a lot of seating...clean restaurant. Ordered the chicken pho with the giblets. I was expecting the chicken eggs but got none sadly. The broth was very flavorful. I drank the soup up. There was plenty of noodles and chicken also. Service is quick which was perfect since I was in a rush!
author: Christine N.

description:
What the hell happened to Turtle Tower? I remember when this was the platinum standard against which all other pho houses aspired (previous review: http://bit.ly/1upHpMs). I still remember that subtly flavorful Hanoi-style broth I had when it was in the raggedy corner location that Golden Lotus now inhabits. Did their pho mojo get lost in the half-block move? It could very well be as they are just two doors up Larkin in a roomier space where the service feels a bit more uptight than it was before (photo: http://bit.ly/1qDkhse). I came on a late Saturday afternoon when they were about to close at 5PM, a particular pain point for me since I usually don't get the craving for pho until the evening hours. I'm not sure if a lack of motivation at that "late" hour had anything to do with the diminished quality, but I just wasn't feel the love.

I ordered the $8.50 bowl of Pho Tai Chin, the combination of rare and well done beef noodle soup (photo: http://bit.ly/1qnESC7). First, the noodle count was paltry. More importantly, I didn't think the beef was marrying well with the broth which tasted surprisingly thin like it wasn't in the pot long enough. I squirted the siracha in the bowl to give it more bounce, but despite the tender flank steak, I was marginally disappointed that this was the Turtle Tower from days of yore. Afterward, I saw the clip about Turtle Tower on a recent episode of "Check, Please! Bay Area" and felt somewhat vindicated by the lackluster reactions from the two diners who tried it as part of their assignment. I don't think it was horrible by a long shot, but something was sure amiss and I am rather pho-lorned. Maybe I should try the Pho Ga next time?

FOOD - 3 stars...hard to admit that I actually had middling pho at Turtle Tower
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...definitely nicer than their old digs but at what price?
SERVICE - 3 stars...a bit stiff and a scarcity of smiles
TOTAL - 3 stars...this Turtle is hiding in its shell
author: Ed U.

description: I'm not a pho-natic when it comes to this dish, but Turtle Tower just nailed it. Hand-kneeled rice noodles, swimming in a clear beef broth that has been flavored with fat and sings notes of star anise. It is eventually topped with thin tender slices of brisket. I actually thought I was having Korean barbecue soup. Toppings of green onion are mounting, but not over taking the actual star. No need for the hot sauce, it was perfect just the way it was.
author: Monica Colleen D.

description:
Had pho once and didn't think it lived up to all the hype. The soup was just alright and the noodles were the thick kind.

Ordered the chicken rice porridge and all the chicken was at the bottom of the bowl. It was good though, a little bland but good for morning time. But it was also expensive imo $8 for a large.

Turtle tower does accept credit cards.
author: Mimi T.

description:
BEST SPRING ROLLS IN THE WORLD. 

It was here that I learned about Northern style pho -- no bean sprouts, basil, or hoisin sauce. The broth is also more bland but GOOD! The noodles were so different than what I'm used to; they're wide and flat. I enjoyed it! 

Also, really good egg soda. 

It's (almost) right around the corner from Brenda's, so you can grab some crawfish beignets to go after.
author: Elsie W.

description:
Best chicken noodle soup pho I've had. Period. Let's call this the Asian version of the American chicken noodle soup. :)

If you are like me and were never fond of the typical beef pho, you will LOVE the chicken pho here. #9 chicken noodle soup (pho ga) is the way to go. The flat noodles are delicious. The chicken is flavorful and tastes like Hainan Chinese chicken (I wonder if it is?). The broth even has that Hainan chicken taste, which probably means they actually took their time to cook the chicken in their broth a lot longer than other pho places. Prices aren't bad. $6 for a small, $8 for a large.

The imperial rolls are kind of expensive however. $2.25 for each roll, which is only in 3 small bite sized pieces.
author: Vicki L.

description: Came here for the first time and I ordered #2 Pho Tai. The food came out pretty fast and it was good! The servers were really friendly and quick as well. This place does not have hoisin or sriracha sauce. It is different from all the other pho places but I would definitely come back again.
author: Wendy C.

description: My favorite place to go in the city for a bowl of noodle soup and some comfort food. My favorite was the chicken noodle soup with white meat only and sandwich with egg. Delicious!
author: Alice W.

description: There is no better places for a bowl of perfect chicken noodle soup like the one you are looking at right now.
author: Louis Z.

description: Large was a great size. I had the pho gai long. That's the one with the giblets. The meat was decent and the giblets were delicious. My friend ordered the imperial rolls with the vermicelli noodles. He seemed to like it and I have enjoyed it in the past. I do think they could give you more since the price of that dish is the same as the pho and you get much more filled with the pho and other dishes.
author: George F.

description: This is the only vietnamese restaurant I have ever been that make Hanoi-style dishes. I was here 4 years ago and still remembered the strong feelings it gave me when I finally tasted something that is truly home.
author: Trang H.

description:
**Pho Quest Stop #61**

While I've been to Turtle Tower previously, this was my first visit since they moved to a redesigned and expanded space within the Tenderloin.  It's also the first visit I've had since my beloved Pho Ha Noi (San Jose) closed and now Turtle Tower is the solo establishment that I'm aware of that served Northern or Ha Noi style Vietnamese noodle soup characterized by signature wide noodles, milder, ginger tinged broth, and a minced flank steak.  

I'll be honest.  I'm a fan of the larger, much cleaner space and I love the high ceilings and the sunlight that comes in.  It truly transforms the Tenderloin space which can still be a challenge to walk to (the surrounding area can be quite dirty) but that increasingly has food worthy stops such as nearby The Chairman (Bao) that just opened.  

The food is largely the same as I remember, but given now that Pho Ha Noi has been closed almost two years (I used to go several times a year), the version here still brought back memories of how much I really like Northern style pho compared to the Southern style I consume 98% of the time.  

Pho Ga - $7.  Small.  Ordered with giblets and the chicken meat is nice and tender.  The wide noodles are cooked well too.  The broth is tasty but can be a bit mild.  I still like the much stronger and flavorful Pho Ga at Pho Kim Long in San Jose, but the version here is probably good for breakfast like we had here.  

Pho Bo Dac Biet - $7.75.  Small.  I do like that even though the space is expanded and new, they 've kept the small options available and pricing seems fair.  Given their fame, I can see how they could charge more, but don't.  Like the chicken pho, the pho dac biet is a milder ginger tinged broth.  The flank steak and meat is nowhere near as impressive as Pho Ha Noi used to be but given it's all we have I'm not complaining.  The wide noodles are delicious.  Turtle Tower also used to now allow hoisin and sriracha sauce.  It seems there is still no hoisin but at least they jars of sriracha. 

Chicken porridge - $7.  Small.  Another great breakfast food and both tasty and filling.  They use the chicken broth to make this porridge and likely cook it over night as the rice is both well congealed and flavorful.  Hit the spot.

Vietnamese Ice Coffee - great way to wake up.

Overall, I can't help but be happy to have Turtle Tower.  I love Northern style pho and Turtle Tower continues to represent.  The renovated new space looks lovely as well and service was both friendly and efficient.  

Turtle Tower accepts credit cards, including American Express.

My Pho Quest Rankings: [San Jose, unless noted]
============
1) Pho Ha Noi (CLOSED) - BEST EVER Pho (Overall & Northern Style)
2) Pho Cong Ly - BEST Pho (Current Overall & Oxtail) 
3) Pho Y 1 - BEST Beef Pho (Southern Style)
4) Pho Kim Long - BEST Chicken Pho
5) Turtle Tower (SF) - Northern Style
6) Pho Ga Hung - BEST Cau Bun Rau Muong
7) Pho Nguyen (Milpitas) - Pho Nguyen Dac Biet w/ fresh wide noodles
8) Nha Hang Saigon Seafood - Winner: Best Hu Tieu
9) Hai Nam - Pho Ga/Com Ga
10) Pho Wagon - Pho Dac Biet
11) GOGO Pho (Santa Clara) - Filet Mignon Pho
12) Pho 54 - Pho Dac Biet #1
13) Com Ga Nam An - Pho Ga
14) Pho Ga Nha - Pho Ga Dac Biet
15) Kobe Pho (Cupertino) - Kobe Dac Biet
16) Phuong Thao (Sunnyvale) - Pho #12
17) Pho Wagon (Sunnyvale) - Pho Dac Biet
18) Quan Ngon - King Oxtail Pho #6
19) Pho #1 (Sunnyvale) - Pho Dac Biet 
20) Pho 90 Degree - Pho Dac Biet w/ Oxtail
21) Pho Spot - Combo Pho
22) Pho Avenue (MV) - Pho Dac Biet
23) The Sandwich Maker (Los Gatos) - Beef Pho
24) Pho Vi Hoa (Los Altos) - Pho P12
25) Pho Ga An Nam - Pho Ga
26) House of Pho - Pho Dac Biet and Bo Vien
27) Rengstorff Pho (MV) - Special Satay
28) Pho Vy - Egg Noodles with Pork, Chicken, Beef 
29) Saigon Vietnamese Restaurant (Santa Barbara) - Beef Pho
30) Pho Little Saigon (San Mateo) - Beef Pho
31) Pho Pasteur - Pho Ox Tail 
32) Pho Ga Ho Han Kiem - Pho Ga Dac Biet
33) Pho 24 - House Special Pho
34) Pho Minh (Cupertino) - Pho Dac Biet
35) Beef Noodle No 1 - Pho #1
36) Pho Nam (Sunnyvale) - Pho #1
37) Dalat Restaurant - Hu Tieu Dac Biet
38) Pho Little Saigon (Sunnyvale) - Pho #1
39) Pho Nam (Sunnyvale) - Pho #1
40) Pho To Chau - (MV) - Pho 
40-60) see more at rfung8.tumlbr.com
author: Randy F.

description:
I finally decided to try Turtle Tower...it's just been too long.

I ordered their #9, chicken pho w/o the giblets (pho ga), which is what they're known for.

I definitely approve! Very flavorful broth with lots of cilantro to flavor the soup. I also like that they serve it with the thick flat rice noodles (ho fun). A small for $6.75 and large for $8.25, which is very affordable. I finished my small and was very full.

Downside, I felt they could have given a bite more chicken, but it is shredded with no bones. A plus for lazy people like me and prefer to not have to pull bones out of their mouth as they're eating pho. Some of my white meat pieces were a bit dry too.

Overall, delicious chicken pho for just $7! (They're cash only, so make sure you got at least 10 bucks on you)

P.S: Squeeze some lime and add some jalapenos (you'll thank me). It adds a nice tang and a little kick and makes it tastes better, imo.
author: Stephanie L.

description: It's been a while since I've been here, but those mornings after those drunken nights in SF will always be with me.  Always came here for the Pho Ga which is bomb dot com.  The broth is super delicious and NGON LAM!!!  Definitely a cure to those hang overs!!
author: Thuy V.

description: I had the beef pho and imperial rolls, and as northern style pho goes, it was not bad! Prices are great as well as the service. The texture of the beef was a bit grainy. Flavor had the typical clear and light taste. The rolls are more loosely wrapped here and almost remind me of Filipino lumpia. Overall, 3 1/2 stars for me!
author: Sharey V.

description: I definitely recommend this location over the one in the Richmond district! They definitely have a team of staffs here! They were quick our orders today. I usually get #4 Pho Bo Dac Biet or #10 Pho Ga Long.  I would say the broth is flavorful and not too salty for both. I just wish they made their Pho more hot when they bring it out. The soup gets to warm temperature pretty quickly if you're a slow eater. When I'm eating Pho or drinking soup, I expect the broth to be hot to be fulfilling. Another thing is that they always skimp out on giving out jalapeños. They know I always ask for more and always make me ask for more...
author: D H.

description:
"Hot Soup Hot Soup!"
Ordered Rare Steak Pho. 
Clean tasty broth; steak more done than rare, 1 piece, all suited my tastes.
I added a bit of fish sauce lemon and chili sauce for fun Drip coffee fun. Atmosphere great fun too
Service Prompt
An excuse to visit the Tenderloin
author: S S.

description: Turtle tower... what can I say? Wow. Best pho ga ever! I've been coming here to eat/ordering to go for years now and have been craving it since I've moved back. This will always be a go to spot for me for some comfort food when I'm craving noodle soup. The broth is perfect, noodles are great, and the chicken... is cooked to perfection! We usually get no skin on the chicken, but that is just a preference and they can totally do that for you. This place just screams yes.
author: Rebecca Y.

description: This was by far the best pho I ever had! The owner & employees were pretty nice.  It was worth the 15 min.wait.
author: Judy K.

description:
This review is solely for their banh mi's. Yes, yes.. I know. What was I thinking, ordering banh mi at a place known for pho? That'll teach me.

Their banh mi tasted like it was nuked in the microwave after having spent 18 months in the freezer jail. The insides of the baguette was crumbling to pieces and tasted terribly stale. The pate was far from fresh, and there were barely any pickled veggies. I was very disappointed.

If you're coming to Turtle Tower, go with the pho and stay far far away from the banh mis -- no matter how badly you are craving it!
author: Stephanie B.

description:
I'm a big fan of Northern style pho and think this is a good option in the Tenderloin. I'm not a fan of the hoisin and sprouts anyway. I was first introduced to Hanoi style pho in Hanoi, just before the embargo was officially lifted. I was hooked at first sip. 

The different beef options are my go to, depending on the weather and my mood. I usually get the small sized bowl as that suits me perfectly for lunch. The spring rolls are good and the restaurant is always full and busy.
author: Greg O.

description: Oh I like this place! The pho is not the thin pho, more like bun flat style. The broth is quite lovely. Very subtle and light, the chicken is a mix between some mainly white meat with a sprinkle of dark meat and skin. Sketchy area, but worth.
author: Huy D.

description: PHOOOOOO. Im in love with their chicken pho. The broth is tasty and the chicken is very tender. I'm a cilantro lover so the fact that they include a lot of it in the broth, it's perfect for me
author: Sui N.

description: I haven't been back to Turtle Tower since they redecorated the place - and I like it!  It seems warmer, welcoming and more spacious.  The pho ga and those fresh noodles still rock, and if you need to get up the energy to clean your home, drink a Vietnamese iced coffee!  I did and I came home and I wanted to clean for some reason LOL!  Yes, they do have a lot of caffeine so don't drink it too late in the afternoon if you want to sleep decently - take it from me!  It's soo good though.
author: Maile N.

description:
I went there after being sick for about a week, a good hot Pho really helps me. 

I ordered their rare beef and brisket pho.

The base of their pho is chicken stock, which normally i do not like, but theirs is tasty especially with herbs and noodles. Very silky and hit the spot. 

I asked for my Tai (rare beef) on the side, and ordered an extra portion. Their Tai is pounded flat, which caused their beef to break in my bowl and cook into hard small balls of boiled beef. Not a good texture, kept getting stuck in my teeth and a dry powdery taste. 

Their brisket was good, well cooked and tasty. 

I will go back and skip their pounded flat Tai, and see what else they have.
author: Dean N.

description:
Checked this place out the day after Santa Con! My boyfriend and I were in desperate need of some
pho. We got seated right away and ordered a chicken pho and pho tai with chicken broth. Service was friendly and fast, but I thought the food was just okay. I was kind of disappointed because this place is super hyped up, but there was nothing special about it. Not a fan of the big noodles either. It definitely wasn't bad, but I'd go somewhere else if given the choice.
author: Jazzmin B.

description:
I stopped at Turtle Tower for a quick bite while I was in SF this past weekend.

Location/Parking: The restaurant isn't located in the best neighborhood and there's quite a few homeless people wandering around. Fortunately, there's lots of street parking in front of the restaurant so that you won't have to walk too far, but it depends on when you get there. I'd recommend not coming here at night, but they close at 5:00PM anyways.

Food: We ordered the Spring Rolls and the Chicken Pho. The spring rolls were very fresh, decently sized and had plenty of shrimp. The sauce that it came with was also very good. The star of the show was their Chicken Pho though, which had a rich, flavorful, but also light broth. The chicken breasts were very tender and moist. I also like that you get plenty of chicken offal as well, gizzards, hearts, kidney and (my favorite) liver. All were cleaned very well and didn't taste gamey or mineral-y (if that's a word.)

Service: Our server was very attentive, and even though we arrived as they were closing, we never felt rushed. He even got us an extra sauce to take with our extra spring roll.

Overall, I'd recommend coming to Turtle Tower if you're in SF and craving Pho. We're pretty spoiled with the Vietnamese food we have in So Cal, but I think Turtle Tower can rival some of the best places we have in LA.
author: Anthony L.

description:
It's not the same!!

They used to be at the little corner and now they're a the big spot with nice decor and open front like.

The menu got a bit expensive but by much, maybe a quarter or so?

I got my pho ga and took the bf there for his first time.  Service was quick.

The bowl is a bit smaller than what I'm normally used to but it is still filling.  

Broth is clean and yummy, like moms, almost....almost.  Some pho places will give you the ginger green onion dip for the chicken but this place doesn't, so sad face.

Overall, it's still good and I'm happy
author: Laurie W.

description:
The pho ga is divine good here. The broth is beyond flavorful. Add some jalepenos for spice and a squeeze of lime and it's just right. I like to order my bowl with giblets because I love the texture and crunch of giblets.

5 stars for always being delicious, fast, fresh, and cheap!
author: Veronica T.

description: My friend told me about the chicken pho here so we came on a rainy Sunday afternoon ~1pm. There was a wait, and it took our party of three about 15 mins to get seated. I decided to go all out and order a large chicken pho... which I got me feelin proud but miserable after finishing. I also didn't know that the noodles are thicker here so I really didn't know what I was getting myself into when I ordered a large. Definitely not one of those pho places that serve cheap, low quality pho. Would come back for the chicken pho on a cold day when I'm sick.
author: Annie S.

description:
Turtle Tower is the spot to come when you arrive in SF. I would say this is a legit spot that really does have some good food. The wait can be a little bit on the long side but don't worry it isn't that horrible. 

Menu is nice and simple and I loved it all. I would say the chicken taste like it came straight from some farm. The flavor of the soup is amazing and the noodles are perfect. I can't believe it but yes I think this is the best I have had in my entire life. 

I found it but too bad it isn't in LA. So every time that I think about SF I now think only about Turtle Tower. 

If you have room in your stomach also try the chicken porridge if you like porridge this might also be a head turner for some!

Don't forget to bring your cash, it is a cash only legit business. :)
author: Francine L.

description:
One of the unfortunate side-effects of breaking up with my last boyfriend was the realization that I will likely never have amazing homecooked pho again. His dad's pho was made with the best ingredients and cooked for hours so that the broth developed a depth of flavors. 

Everyone in SF had been recommending Turtle Tower to me as it seems to be THE place in the city to get pho, at least the chicken variety. I avoided it for a while due to the sketchy neighborhood and finally got my chance to try it out on a first date. I know what you're thinking - what a cheap guy, right? Well, seeing that there hasn't been a second date, that very well may be the case. Alternatively, I like to believe that because I was sick, he suggested pho as a thoughful gesture. 

I definitely didn't mind the suggestion and I know dating can be expensive for guys. On this date, I was craving beef pho so I ordered a standard, small bowl of pho with flank. I appreciate the use of the wide noodles (which, by the way, seems much more common here than in SoCal) but the broth left a lot to be desired. The soup tasted salty and one-dimensional, lacking in the boldness I am used to. Perhaps it's unfair to rate restaurant pho against homemade pho but to me, this soup was just A-OK.
author: Yi Z.

description:
So my manager introduced me to Turtle Tower maybe 2-3 months ago.
It has since become a weekly ritual for my S.O. and myself.

Get their Pho Ga (Chicken Pho).
They'll give you 2 little dishes, with lime slices and green pepper slices. Put the lime slices in one of the dishes, then pour fish sauce over the green peppers, and you're set to go; the broth is already awesome, but the pepper slices give it an occasional *oomph*.

Finally, towards the end of your meal squeeze a couple of drops of lime into your broth. It changes the flavor from a "hearty" one to a light, refreshing one, so you don't leave feeling bloated.

This is NOT a cash-only establishment: at least not since we've been coming here (around August).
author: Eric V.

description:
This review is only for the food. The place is probably one of the cleanest pho place around here. Service is fast.

Got the bo xao which is dry noodle w beef. The sauce made the noodle extremely slimy yet still flavorless. I dont mind slimy sauce, but it added no flavors. Not only was it flavorless, everything  had a burnt charcoal taste to it. Took 3 bites and had to go elsewhere for food. 

Might come back to try their chicken pho
author: Tera D.

description:
Was in the area and wanted some Pho, as my husband had never tried it. We were at a nearby bar and asked the bartender where he would recommend a good pho to eat. He mentioned the Turtle Tower was a few blocks away and that it was the BEST in San Francisco. We left the bar and headed to the restaurant and walked into a super casual, but clean and friendly place. 

We ordered Pho with a side of the seared pork and a couple of the veggie spring rolls. WOW!!!!!!!! the food is so clean and fresh and tasty! My husband fell in love and said we would definitely plan to come back. The servers were very nice, the service was quick and the food was just amazing. 

Next time we go, I am getting the Chicken Noodle soup. The server said it was their number one sold item and recommended I give it a shot next time. She even stopped by our table to show it to me as she went to deliver it to another customer who had ordered it. Yes, I do agree I shall try it next time we are in. 

GREAT place and its close to everything. See you soon Turtle Tower!
author: Tanya C.

description: So not only is this place very good with good variety , it's fast, it's very clean, service is good.   I was sick and had a delicious chicken soup. huge And very tastes and affordable.  The spring rolls were also great with shrimp and delicious homemade peanut sauce.
author: David C.

description:
Chicken pho was average 
Beef pho #2 was good, but stomach pains later in the day
Service was good
Spring rolls were very fresh
author: Jones T.

description: Chicken pho here has never disappointed me. Very flavorful. Worth the wait. Clean place, nice attentive staff. Fried egg rolls are good too.
author: James L.

description:
Small portions, but place respects their food! I didn't know the difference between northern ans southern style pho, so I ordered a bowl and asked for basil and hoisin sauce. The lady educated me about the difference and denied me both sauce and basil. I was kind of embarrassed but glad to find a place that respects their culture and their food! 

Their broth is really delicious and the taste is light and simple. All the ingredients are very fresh.
author: Rachel C.

description: not good. had it plenty of times and the noodles are always soggy
author: Sam R.

description:
GREAT PHO GA! 

This place is known for its chicken pho and I highly approve. :) 
We walked here on a Sunday morning and Dana and I forgot cash. So we had to trek some time to reach a Chase ATM. This place is cash only, like many places around the area. This area has pretty good vietnamese cuisine (or so I've heard). The waiters seem nice and friendly. The pho ga wasn't PERFECT, but it definitely was enough to satisfy my Pho craving.
author: Ana L.

description: The best ever!! My favorite soup is Pho ga... chicken noodle soup w 2 wedges of lime at small saucer full of jalapeños and fish sauce!! #phonemenal #phoever I  TT! They have other great and amazing food and great customer service
author: Lori D.

description: Is it me?! I swear I can taste the freshness of all the ingredients. From the chicken, to the noodles, even the soybean drinks seem freshly made. Tbh, I was disappointed there were no bean sprouts or leaves but the broth was fine without it. Very clear and not oily nor msg drowned. Service is also very friendly. The only iffy thing was my Vietnamese coffee because less than half the cup dripped out! Without the ice, the drink wouldn't definitely be as full.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Best Pho Ga in town.  I usually also start with a fresh Spring Roll, which is well made here with plenty of greens and vermicelli wrapped so it won't fall apart without being too dry or rigid.  Peanut sauce is also excellent without being too sweet.  I like to add a dollop of red hot sauce for some extra kick.

*Tip - the Iced Coffee is so good! But it takes a while to drip so order it right when seated.
author: Jenn L.

description: Good traditional Pho, no reason to not to give 5 stars. Good on the simple flavors and no hair in my food lol.
author: Jamal S.

description:
I only get 3 things here, and they are as close to perfection as perfection goes: 
1) Fried imperial roll with dipping fish sauce--light, crispy with perfect amount of filling but a tad pricey at $2.95/ea
2) Chicken noodle soup--fresh pho noodles in a flavorful clear chicken broth with tender pieces of chicken and sprinkles of cilantro and green onion...so good for my tummy.
3) Vietnamese coffee--let it drip, stir to mix the condensed milk, pour into tall glass of ice...aahhh

Noodle soups don't come with side sprouts, mint leaves, basil, etc., only jalapeño or serrano peppers and lemon wedges.
Parking can be a challenge during lunch.
Long queue during peak lunch, but wait time goes fast.
Beware of hours...not open for dinner (when you think they should) and closed Thursday.
Service with a smile, mostly.
author: Lil D.

description:
TT's brand new space opened (or relocated) on Saturday June 1. Yay! I'd say that everything about the new place is better than the grungy old corner location. TT's flagship shop is larger, cleaner and brighter than their other 3 locations, therefore I have to give them 5 stars. The outdoor signage is still under construction, so it might go unnoticed until u see the menu posted on the window.

Both the front patio and metal staircase of the former tattoo shop were torn down, to have more space for the main dining room, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-san-francisco-6?select=5wDD6DuB5Fk2GkAeshnyBA#zDdKz9eeo8gfIFDXElQDnQ plus stairs to the new 2nd floor space was added (not used yet, don't know seat capacity. Also don't know if u can book private parties upstairs in the future). http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-san-francisco-6?select=5wDD6DuB5Fk2GkAeshnyBA#IVVtPpgE8ftFh_JFFBBkEw Even the 2 individual unisex bathrooms are huge (bigger than some multi-person restrooms elsewhere). And any newbies will be glad to see that condiments are clearly labeled (vinegar, fish sauce, chili sauce). http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-san-francisco-6?select=5wDD6DuB5Fk2GkAeshnyBA#MrykrYnaEEcp85123KpzGg

The current setup has 40 seats (10 tables), but can hold more by adding chairs on the sides of the 4-person tables. In contrast, the old space could only hold up to 20-29 (9 from the staff's 5-chair round table and 4-chair prep area table) customers closely seated.

TT's old LCD screen (it was turned off) hangs above the cash register. The counter also displays new blue "I love TT PHOever" shopping bags for purchase (remember that the city's plastic bag ban applies to all restaurants starting in October 2013).
 
The new laminated menu now includes banh mi ($4.50), matching their other locations. But I was told that sandwiches weren't available yet, so I couldn't try it.

It was a cold day when I visited this week, so instead of my favorite Pho Ga (#9), this time I opted for a chicken rice porridge (#21). The shredded chicken in the bottom of my bowl was tender and delicious, as good as always. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-san-francisco-6?select=5wDD6DuB5Fk2GkAeshnyBA#5wDD6DuB5Fk2GkAeshnyBA
