I really don't know if the new modest kitchen will be able to cope when this restaurant gets packed with customers. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-san-francisco-6?select=5wDD6DuB5Fk2GkAeshnyBA#hFnNF3y6VV70AZSmZiLDDQ

No reservations. Cash only.
Temporary hours: 8am-5pm, closed Thursdays.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-san-francisco-6?select=L8vXjwanEyJ6oxv3_yYleQ#L8vXjwanEyJ6oxv3_yYleQ
author: Luis C.

description: Northern pho, it was good! But I rather have southern pho. The place was definitely clean and good quality meats
author: Charles Z.

description:
Pho ga is the perfect cure for a cold!
Get the large... and save the rest for later ;) The savory broth will do wonders!

The spring rolls are tasty too. Plump shrimp with the satisfying crunch of the bean sprouts and the kick from the mint leaves! 

You can order for pickup!
author: Michelle L.

description: The best Vietnamese restaurant with really accommodating and clean service IMHO. They also open hella early for those of you rolling out of bed from a fun night out and need that fuel to get your day started
author: Marie P.

description: Lives very fully up to the hype. Some people don't like the northern style slippery noodles, but the broths here are hands down the best of any pho in America I've ever tasted. My pho snob friends always tell me try some secret place that's better than TT, but it's never as good as this.
author: Ken H.

description:
I understand a lot of people like this place because it's very different from your typical pho. But sometimes when you're hungover, you just want a steamy bowl of normal, dirty rare steak and tendon pho. It's supposed to cure your hangover and make you feel like you might be able to function again. 

I went with the highly suggested chicken pho (large because they didn't have a medium option) and also ordered the che ba mau just because they had it. Che ba mau is a three colored dessert (mung bean, red bean, pandan jelly immersed in a sweet and delicious coconut milk) and it was really tasty here. I definitely enjoyed it. The service here is extremely fast and we got our food within 5 minutes of ordering them. At first glance, the broth looked very clear and everything looked very clean. The noodles aren't your typical pho noodles but rather they are wide rice noodles. This place is also not your typical pho place because it didn't have sriracha or hoisin sauce (what?!) and people said you don't really need them because the broth is good enough on its own. However the broth to me was very like chinese herbal like so very bland and not savory enough. I added the hot sauce they provided but it still didn't add to the flavor. Also the large size is way too big and they should have a medium option. I can see the appeal of this pho over normal phos but I still personally enjoy a typical bowl of steak and tendon pho. Also this didn't cure the hangover =(
author: Anna Z.

description: Turtle tower is one of my favorite places to go. Their northern style pho is different than most pho places you might think of. Their pho ga is their specialty and my favorite. The soup hits just the right spot. I also always get a side of fresh spring rolls which are also simple and tasty
author: Erika N.

description:
My first time trying Northern Viet pho.  No sprouts, no basil, no hoison, NO PROBLEM.

Known for their delicious chicken broth, I did the logical thing and got the beef. (my friends all got chicken broth so I figured I'd just steal a sip of theirs).  There was something special about the unadultered broths with only noodles, meat, scallion/cilantro.  I became a fan instantly.

#Ph St Vang: Beef stewed in wine sauce noodle soup.  This was the single best pho I've had anywhere.  The wine sauce was rich, red, and flavorful til the last bite.  The beef (I think brisket? was the best meat I've had in a pho.  So tender and moist.

#Spring rolls: these are the rice paper sort.  Simple ingredients, but fresh and put together perfectly.  (I actually meant to order the fried rolls which are called Imperial rolls since those looked really good in photos, but was not in the least disappointed by the spring rolls)

**I had a sip of my friend's chicken broth, and tho pretty good, I'm biased myself as I always favor beef/pork over chicken without exception.  

OVERALL: excellent and lives up to the hype.  Service seems like its variable as this place can be busy and crowded at times.  But food seems consistently phenomenal.
author: George T.

description: You know that mean that says "you know when you are at a legit viet restaurant when you leave emotionally scarred"? That's pretty much turtle tower. LOL. But if you don't care for the sub-par service and just want some dank food, turtle tower is the place! The pho ga, chicken noodle soup, is....so good it almost made me want to cry of joy.
author: Jessica J.

description:
I only ever get the chicken pho here so my rating speaks for that only. 

My dad and I frequently go here to grab lunch and it really hits the spot. I love how the noodles are wide and the broth tastes "clean," if that makes sense. I also love how they give you green peppers on the side! Drown them in fish sauce and eat with it the pho - its magical..
author: Grace P.

description:
I hate chicken pho.  25 years in the pho game and would immediately put my hand up and say "please" chicken pho is abysmal compared to the beef option:  today I have lifted that thought completely.  Turtle tower renewed and rekindled a spark I never knew existed in Chicken pho.

[ 3 factors in why Turtle Tower's chicken pho is successful ]

1. Chicken.  Normally, Vietnamese restaurants would give you chicken breasts and drums on the bone.  Bones are awful and with rough chops, you usually find particles occasionally throughout your soup.  The chicken secondly is so dry. You would think cooking it on the bone would keep it moist, but it's far from that.  Boiled to oblivion and unloved chicken. It tastes like eating 3 day old drought-inducing / bland turkey that's been stowed in the bottom draw of your refrigerator.  

Turtle tower is the polar opposite.  The chicken is so flavorful, moist, the meat is cut evenly, there are no bones, and smiles gleam across the room.  "Chicken noodle soup, chicken noodle soup, chicken noodle soup and some hot sauce on the side~" So-da licious!!

2.  Noodle.  Normally Vietnamese restaurants serve vermicelli rice noodles.  It's okay, but fails to hold flavor as successfully.  It's worse when the chicken is God awfully dry and the dense rice noodles do little to save the pho dish.  "Hey... Let's just give boiled / dry chicken parts and hard vermicelli noodles cause we're pho-king awful human beings!"

Turtle tower on the other hand uses flat rice noodles. So soft.  So buttery.  So velvety and delicious as it slides against the chicken -- a match made in heaven. A beautifully choreographed dance routine in your mouth.  It's a luscious consistency.  You literally feel comfort without needing to chew meticulously through hard rice noodles or fiddling with bones.  It's one of the most seamless experiences I've surprisingly had.  As a UI designer, I would say it was very "user pho-riendly."

3.  Soup.  The broth is true both normally and here.  Clear, flavorful, maybe a tad bit too salty for my taste, but I absolutely don't mind.  It's a minor preference.  The ability to create such harmonious and high joy out ways a little salt idiosyncrasies for me.

[ Takeaway ]
It's literally 2 am and I'm writing about chicken noodle soup.  The world must try Turtle Tower's chicken noodle soup.  3 main ingredients create a 5 star tasting experience.  If you were against chicken pho prior to this review, there might be a beautiful, new and prosperous horizon ahead at Turtle Tower.
author: Edison G.

description:
I've been trying to find a decent pho place in SF, but still not satisfied.  Made my way to Turtle Tower, passing some seriously grimy and gritty streets (this city is a cesspool, almost like NY in the 90s), and ordered the chicken pho.

It was a decent chicken pho, but nothing to write home about.  Why don't they serve some bean sprouts and basil along with it?  That could have helped.
author: S K.

description:
YAAAAS.

Chicken pho does a body good. I thought I wouldn't like the noodles but hot damn. yum. Now I want turtle tower again.  Parking can be annoying though.  My vietnamese coffee was decent. Service was fine. Remember they don't have all the sauces and leaves and stuff you put in, just lemon, which is fine because it was soooo good. I wouldn't have minded hot sauce though, but...sriracha runs though my veins so it's okay. ;)
author: Meena N.

description:
UGH. So freaking good. Best pho I've had in a restaurant.

My mother makes the BEST pho ever, so I rarely ever go out for pho. It's pretty much always a disappointment whenever I go to Vietnamese restaurants. This is the one place my parents recommend in SF, and I finally made it out here! Can't believe it took me almost 2 years to try this place. 

Most pho restaurants in California are Southern style, and that's just not my taste. Northern pho is all about the broth - you don't need to add any herbs or bean sprouts, and ESPECIALLY not hoisin sauce. The first time I went out for pho with my boyfriend, he added like 3 tablespoons of hoisin sauce to his broth. I was absolutely mortified.

I got the Pho Dac Biet. The broth here is delicious and the meat is really tender. We got the spring rolls to share but they were nothing special. The Vietnamese iced coffee was good, but of course, really strong.

I will definitely be back!
author: Lisa N.

description: Northern style pho! Sooooo good. Different that what we are used to wherein you add the bean sprouts, basil leaves jalopeno and squeeze the lime.  They use more fish sauce compared to the southern style pho wherein you mix hoisin and sriracha. Also, you can put some white pepper in the soup. Very tasty broth as well but not quite the same as the southern style which they boil more and taste more beefy. I always go back! Yum!
author: Miguel Y.

description:
Two words... Absolutely Delicious. 

Simple, honest Northern Vietnamese noodles. Can't go wrong.
author: Denny C.

description:
I went in the morning one day with 4 other people and we were quickly seated in the worst possible spot in the entire restaurant. It was like 60 degrees and windy af that morning and the doors do not even shut completely. Whole time I was eating I was shivering simultaneously... Not very ideal -_- We did ask to change tables but apparently NO OTHER TABLE would fit the 5 of us... I would have waited just to be seated somewhere where I would not be freezing.

Very very generic Pho Ga. My family can easily make this same flavor at home; we have actually done it so I am not just throwing out random claims haha.

I wanted to really talk about the chicken. Not very juicy and they do not have any sauce to give me :( No hoisin?? I get that they wanna stay traditional to the region that the dish is from but do they really not use any sauce? I think if the chicken was juicy this sauce dilemma would not be as much of an issue.

Service was just average, they were quick which is nice.

Over all I would probably not come back again just because San Francisco is a far-ish drive and coming all the over here just for this generic Pho Ga with some dry chicken breast doesn't  seem very smart.
author: Megan L.

description: Went to this place while visiting SF for the day because I had seen it on Fungs Bro and thought I would give it a try. Great service but the food was just simply good, no big wows or surprises here.
author: Grace N.

description: Five star for the chicken noodle soup "pho ga" but other stuff on the menu is like four star max. most known for the balanced flavor chicken noodle soup. There's something about it that makes it so tasteful and addicting. $8.50 a bowl will cure your worst hangovers and hunger...!! I've been to many pho places in San Jose and nothing has chicken noodle soup/ pho the way turtle tower has it. Definately gonna keep my monthly visit tradition for this one. Oh but parking can be difficult to find in the day as it is metered and limited.
author: Auden W.

description:
Came here since I was lil' and I'd always get pho ga.  This time I tried the bun thang.  

The food: Soup was good still same tasting chicken although a lot less, diff noodles, and a diff type of meet and egg in there.  Personally,  there wasn't enough greens especially at the cost and markup of the ingredients of course my mom makes the stuff way better.  The only item they have that surpasses is the soup.  Hehehe must be the msg.

The service:  at entrance immediately we were greeted by a huge smile from a waiter who's quick to serve.  He seems nice, flamboyant, energized, young, and looks like he could be sassy off work....  He gave us our tea which made me laugh because b/c whoever the owner is... Must be stingy... why is the kettle so small and tiny??!!  Looks like it'll be empty after filling 2 cups!! Isn't that inefficient if we have to flag down the waiter a million times to get more tea?  If its a table of 6 would they have a bigger kettle or bring out 3 tiny kettles? Haha. 
Everything was great until the end when my dad was asked if he wanted the change.  My dads like what?  "First time in my life I've been asked that."  I thought it was weird too but i guess they wanted more tips if someone were to be feeling uncomfortable they might just say no I don't need change and leave.. but not my dad!  my dad said to me "you wish boy muahahhaa" hahaha and then he took his 1 dollar to feed the meter hehehe.. besides that the waiter was great and still said bye to us even tho he probably knows we only tipped 10% for breakfast time.  Waiter gets A for effort!  

Ambiance: Great interior and clean decor, but the bum hanging outside is terrible!!! He chased me down the block speaking in Vietnamese (according to my mom)..  I can't understand a thing he said, but she said he mumbled some words but mostly mumble jumbles.  These bums gotta start realizing that not everyone has freaking change!!! I only use credit card.  All I have is my card.. and that's it!!!  Bad location i know... so even if I come back I might hit up another location of turtle tower.. maybe 6th street by the freeway or something.  

3 stars bc the cost doesn't feel justified from the food somehow.  & Stingy small tea kettle..   *TeeheE*
author: Juila L.

description:
I love their Pho Ga a.k.a #9. You should definitely be into it too.
From the first time I had one 4 years ago, I'm a regular for them. I had been kind of worried that its taste would go down after it's moved and remodeled, but surprisingly it became better than great one. So impressive.
Their Beef Pho(#1) is also good, and you should try Spring Roll if you're really hungry.
Although they are cash-only, I'm always having cash only for them!
author: Takeshi O.

description: Great place for lunch,  but come early there is always a line.  They have the best chicken noodle soup. It is comfort food at its best.
author: Philip N.

description: Let me start with saying Ewwwww. There are nothing special in this place and i really dont get who the hell gives them 4 stars. Dont get me wrong I love Pho and have been searching for the best place in the city. This place was neat and more "americanized" but definetly not the place to get Pho. Me and my husband both got the beef pho and apparently it has only 3 slices of beef in the soup. Broth had no taste and even instant noodle would taste better than their broth. If you are searching for good Pho dont go this place. Waste of time and money
author: Solongo B.

description:
Best noodle hands down. Steve the owner and chef takes great pride in his creations. The noodles are fresh daily or even twice daily and are perfectly not too thick or thin, not to soft or sticky. Multiple awards and reviews in the wall attest to the quality. Large sizes all items are clean and fresh.

The restaurant is named after the sacred turtle tower in the lake in Hanoi.
author: Jay G.

description: A bowl of their chicken pho was perfect on a rainy SF day. Their beef broth is also so herbaceous and unique compared to your typical pho spot.
author: Megan H.

description:
We came in for lunch and we didn't finish our food. It was not good. The flavors of the broth was not clean and the food lacked flavor and oomph. I realize this is suppose to be a regional style of serving pho but my Vietnamese dining partner and I were not fans. We looked around and saw people of many ethnic background but few Asians. 

We had to have pho again for dinner to right things with our taste buds and brains. We had to erase the memory of Turtle Tower from our palates.
author: Oulie T.

description:
Miracle hangova food, yes indeed. At least that's how everyone looks like on any given Sunday afternoon =P (myself included) I was introduced to this joint just a few years back, in their old location down the block. The new location is bigger but you still have to wait in line. Staff are always smiley tho! 
You will fall in love with the soup immediately. Super fresh and tasty. Always order the large bowl of pho-ga and ask for more green onion/cilantro, extra fried egg on top, lemon sauce/black pepper for dipping of the chicken and whatever innards swimming in the bowl. Slurp it all in!
author: Vee V.

description: Personally thought the broth was too greasy. And def realized I enjoy southern Vietnamese pho noodles more
author: sungheui u.

description: Simple but perfect. Definitely a great place for northern pho ga with wide noodles and no hoisin sauce or veggies. It's the Vietnamese version of the chicken noodle soup- simple yet comforting & satisfying. Loved the crunchy imperial rolls too.
author: Roly H.

description:
Up until visiting this restaurant I was unaware of that there existed another style of pho, the Northern style. 

Being used to a southern style of pho with thin vermicelli noodles and a generous platter of sprouts and basil I was a little thrown off by the wide, thick rice noodles and lack of accoutrements. 

There is no hoisin sauce, just sriracha. It is also served with a small dish of lime and thinly sliced jalapeño. 

I ordered the large no. 3 which comes with well done and rare beef. I recommend ordering the small unless you're a big fan of the thick noodles as the noodle to beef ratio was a little skewed. 

The broth was good, but being partial to the southern style I wasn't a fan of the noodles. 

3.5/5 for the good broth.
author: Elizabeth R.

description:
My strongly recommendation is choking pho. That one is really really nice. 

Staffs are very friendly. 
Actually I wanna have it every week!!
author: Roots R.

description:
Come here for #9 or #10 pho ga/chicken pho
Nice on a cold day or when your hung over. 
Only thing is some days the broth has no taste. 
One of the better crispy rolls in the city. 
Street parking is easy.
author: Dub C.

description:
The best chicken pho in the Bay. Though, having been to multiple locations multiple times, their Geary (Richmond district) location is still tastier for some reason. I think the broth isn't as sweet or something. This Tenderloin location is still pretty good, and if you like chicken pho, it's a must go to.

The chicken or chicken + gibblets (intestines and other parts) is nice, with thick ho fun style rice noodle and a tasty chicken broth. Also, it's dirt cheap for SF at $7 or $8 a bowl. The small is pretty small, so get the large.

The beef pho is very plain, don't get it here. Go next door to the other beef pho spots.

Cafe Sua Da (Vietnamese Iced Coffee) is really popular here too. They also take credit card.
author: Chuck N.

description: Not sure how this place is rated so high. Broth is bland and pho is served luke warm with overcooked noodles. I ordered my rare steak on the side and it did not cook when I put it in my soup. The pho here doesnt have onion (just green onions and cilantro) when I asked for some onions they gave me more green onions & cilantro. The broth is also very oily- have to wipe my lips after every 2 bites oily. Sriracha and fish sauce available at the table but no hoison sauce. They have square set up so they do take card. Service is fast & friendly but both their beef and chicken pho are very meh. If this is 4 star pho in SF I'm concerned for the standards in this city ..
author: Jessica K.

description: I had a piping hot bowl of pho with leeks and carrots and onions - a little off the beaten path, but very welcomed. I definitely recommend sticking to their pho. I had a pork rice plate the other day that wasn't super great, but my friend ordered the chicken pho and I really wished that I had gone with that instead. You live, you learn.
author: Natasha P.

description:
Here with bro and sis. Yummmm :p
Possibly the best pho I've eaten. 
If you want hoisin sauce, I suggest you bring your own because they do NOT have it here. 
They also have a clean bathroom and its pretty big.
author: Kirby L.

description: Excellent porridge with chicken and the Beef flank pho is very tasty with plenty of noodles and flavor. They also feature iced fresh brewed coffee and  Thai iced tea.
author: Helen M.

description:
We wanted a Saturday hangover lunch, so we went searching for Vietnamese. Decided on this place over the other popular options in the area (Pho 2000 and Hai Ky Mi Gia) purely based on the cleanliness and natural lighting that the place seemed to have.

The wait was reasonable, and the service was quick. We ordered the Large #4 Pho (Combination of Rare Beef, Tripe, Well-done Beef Noodle Soup), as well as #13 Vermicelli (Fried Imperial Rolls with Vermicelli Noodle, Lettuce, Mint and Cilantro). We had pretty high expectations due to the Yelp reviews.

For whatever reason, they used their CHICKEN broth for the BEEF pho. We were appalled by this. Now apparently these guys are known for their chicken pho which may be why they used it. The broth itself was alright, though we felt like it had little flavor. The clashing taste was likely due to it being for the wrong meat. Note that they use thick noodles, which was also pretty surprising.

What was even more disappointing was the tiny portions provided for the vermicelli dish. In other typical vietnamese restaurants, the vermicelli dishes come as a giant bowl, with a ton of vermicelli, a decent amount of imperial rolls, as well as grilled pork, carrots, and of course the fish sauce on the side for $9 or less.  At Turtle Tower, the vermicelli was a small plate filled with mostly large pieces of lettuce, a bit of vermicelli (literally a fist full), a normal amount of imperial rolls, and very light fish sauce on the side. They priced this at $8.50. Ridiculous. I was almost going to have this as my only dish, but luckily we shared the vermicelli and pho dishes. As a petite female weighing approx. 100 lbs, I walked out still hungry. I am sure an average sized visitor would have a similar or worse experience. 

The imperial rolls were pretty good but did not add up to enough calories to be considered a real meal (since the vermicelli and lettuce were probably 20 calories in total).

Severely disappointed by what happened in there, definitely not going again.

Edit: We finally went again to give the chicken pho a chance. It didn't change our opinions much - the broth was very light and bland, and the chicken had no flavour. I suppose it is a good option if you want to have a healthy meal.. I am still shocked that people are willing to line up for this place.
author: Elisa L.

description:
Located in the heart of Little Saigon of SF. 

For quite a boozy weekend, I was surprised that this was the only Pho place we went to. It was all right. Kinda pricey, but all right. I like the broth. First time having Pho without a plate full of basil, bean sprouts, and onions. I guess that's their style? I don't care. We were kinda in a hurry, we saw that there was a ton of people here, can't go wrong when you gotta wait to get in right? Yep, this place ain't half bad. Decent service, and it's very clean.

I would come back, but only if I was in the area and need a fast helping of Pho. Did I mention that I don't really care for Pho?
author: Jackson Y.

description: I dream about this pho ga. It's so much more than chicken noodle soup. It will cure you of whatever ails you!
author: Lisa O.

description: Coming from Orange County and close to Westminster I tend to eat pho quite a bit. Me and my wife actually prefer pho 2000 which is right next door, just because its a no frills place and you get what you come for, piping hot, good tasting pho.  We saw a huge line at turtle tower so the next day we tried it. To me it was just a different take on classic pho, wider noodles, broth was not as flavorful. I honestly did not see why people love this place. It is unique in their style, but the flavor just wasn't there for me.  Maybe we'll try again someday and see if my tastes change.
author: Lawrence R.

description: I'm convinced that the people who rated this high do not know what pho should taste like. It's bland and doesn't quite have the right flavors nor sides. Definitely not worth the wait to get in either.
author: Trang H.

description:
Turtle Tower is a great way to warm up on a cold day. They are known for their chicken pho, which is the one I tried.

I ordered a small, and it was the perfect size for me for lunch. The chicken was very tender and the broth was chicken soupy and light. I also shared 1 single imperial roll with a friend. That was a slightly bad idea. The roll was super small, and they cut it into 3 pieces (does not divide evenly!). 

Overall, great experience. Cafe style interior with a different kind of pho. I give it 4 stars, but I thhink I'm still a bigger fan of beef pho.
author: Cynthia X.

description:
I love this place! It serves Hanoi style pho. The noodles are wider than typical pho noodles, and they don't provide bean sprouts. Just lemon and jalapeños. Prices are reasonable- about $6.75 for a small bowl and $8.25 for a large. 

The chicken pho is really good. The chicken is really tender. I've also tried the rare steak pho and I really like the meat as well. Also very tender. Turtle Tower is my favorite pho place! I usually don't eat out alone, but I am willing to for Turtle Tower!
author: Josephine L.

description:
I've been going to turtle tower since they first opened about 15 years ago and their pho has never disappointed. They are still my number 1 pho place in the city.

This isn't the typical pho place people are use to with hoisin sauce or veggies on the side. Everything is already complete in one bowl.

What people fail to understand is that it's the authentic way of serving pho. Many people are use to another style where noodles are thin and vegetables and sauce are served on the side.

But why would you need sauces on the side when everything is already flavorful.

My favorite is the pho tai: rare beef noodle and their famous pho ga: chicken noodle soup. It's perfect on warm days and even better for cold days or when you're just feeling sick. The noodles are thicker than what most people are use to and that's what makes them so unique. 

Tips: when sharing with kids they provide a small bowl with scissors to cut the noodles (every parent understands how much easier that is for their child to eat especially since children don't know how to use chopsticks or fork to eat their noodles)

Turtle tower is perfect for any day! 

Check out their other locations on geary in the Richmond district and on 6th street near the courthouse
author: Joanne K.

description:
After a night of drinking, you wake up feeling kind of nasty.  Your stomach is queasy, yet it screams "feed me"!  You don't want to get out of bed, but then your friends suggest, "let's go to Turtle Tower!"

So, you get dressed, or stay in last night's clothing (whatever), trudge out of your apartment  and walk (or Uber/ Lyft/ etc) to the dirtiest part of San Francisco proper - the Tenderloin.  As you walk through the streets, you look down at your feet, avoiding wet spots - potential pee puddles - and brown stains - because you never know if it's animal or human.  (But honestly, does it make a difference? Poop is poop!)  You cleverly dodge the homeless and crackheads screaming nonsensical words at you from the sidewalk.  You hurry past the whiffs of BO and dried piss, willing yourself not to gag - either from the smell or the hangover or both.  

And finally, you make it!  The wait list might be long, but you know it goes by fast.  The moment you get seated, the waiter comes through and asks for your order, because they know that everyone, you included, is "ready" as soon as they are seated.  You order a large pho ga (#9), because "go big or go home", "yolo", etc.  And when your bowl of pho comes, it's like the first rain of the year in California during the drought - it is a miracle!

Anyway, you gorge your bowl, you pay, you go home, and you take a nap because the adventure to Turtle Tower wore you out.

We've all been there.  And if you haven't, what are you waiting for?
author: Joyce C.

description:
Stop #2 on our petite adventure

Ever since I moved to the city Turtle Tower has always been on my radar. Again, my friend knows me all too well and took us here after our snack at B Patisserie. 

Chicken Pho-broth was super flavorful, packed with a great chicken essence and hints of ginger. There was also a nice viscous consistency to the broth that enveloped my palate. 

Noodles were fresh, done well and a good portion 

Chicken meat was tender and just as flavorful

Cash only

Overall Thoughts

Best chicken pho I have had so far in the city
author: Eddie W.

description:
This is for the Larkin location. 
Turtle Tower sets the standard for Hanoi style pho. Their chicken pho is well known, but I like beef pho, and it is so good here!! The meat is minced with fresh ginger... true to HaNoi style, they do not offer bean sprouts or herbs here. And since I love Thai basil with my pho....
The pho bò xào, the sautéed beef with noodles and vegetables, is excellent here too. 
They must be doing something right, they have 3 locations now...
Very friendly and fast service! 
Parking might be a problem, only street parking here, and it's in the tenderloin...
author: lovetoeat a.

description:
Pretty much the most overrated Pho place I've ever been to.  Broth is super oily and price is a bit high for chicken pho.  Generates a lot of hype and seems to be Vietnamese mecca for non vietnamese people.  Expect long waits and long lines.

Go to Oakland or San Jose if you're looking for good Vietnamese food.
author: Andy V.

description: Turtle tower lover, their chicken pho is similar to the chicken pho in Vietnam. Very authentic. Sometimes there is a wait but you can get seated in 10min no problem. I also love the Geary location!
author: Ming N.

description:
If you're looking for true, authentic Hanoi style pho, this is the place to get it. Don't come here expecting bean sprouts and basil leaves with your pho; you get limes and jalapenos and quick, super friendly service. The noodles are thicker than your typical SF vermicelli too.

The rare beef pho is probably the best rare beef I've had in awhile. It came out actually still pink and was so tender. The pho ga also has incredible flavor as others have said. The perfect thing to eat on a cold day or if you're sick!
author: Amy Y.

description:
CASH ONLY!!!! But there is an ATM machine across the street. 

OKAY...so the boyfriend and I had partied a bit TOO hard the night before. The whole morning I was HUNGOVER. Let's just say, the boyfriend was raving about how great the chicken pho was and man was I in for a treat. 

Driving through this area in SF...is a bit scary...for real. And walking from where we parked the car to the restaurant was smelly and a bit seedy...BUT WORTH IT...SO WORTH IT.

Alright, we put our names down and we didn't wait that long to get a table. Looking over the menu, the boyfriend and I both ordered LARGE chicken phos and he also ordered a large chicken congee. Looking around at everyone else's orders it was nice to see that a majority of the people ordered the chicken pho and some ordered the normal pho tai (rare beef)...I was super tempted to order that but alas peer pressure from other yelp reviews...made me decide on the chicken. 

Our food came reasonably fast. :) I WAS SO IMPRESSED. Unlike the normal pho places, this place uses northern Vietnamese style noodles which are thicker and larger and softer and to me...MORE DELICIOUS. That right there made me love the pho even more. The portions were a great size and let's just say it cured my hangover. The chicken congee on the other hand...err we both kind of regretted ordering that 1. because we were already too full from the pho and 2. it wasn't the best. 

To this day...I crave turtle tower...especially when i'm hungover. SIGH...next time San Francisco...NEXT TIME!!!!
author: Connie M.

description:
Ok just had the pho ga and it's definitely the dish to get on a nice cold SF day! I was also feeling a bit under the weather and this makes for a really nice chicken soup to soothe your belly and appetite! The place is still super busy and cash only but I'd definitely come again for their pho ga! 

I just hope I don't lose my appetite next time from walking past a pile of human excrement like I did today....oh yes! Gotta love the TL!
author: Sam L.

description:
Came here for lunch after volunteering at Glide. They accommodated our group of 20 in their upstairs dining room. Service was with a smile and even though we were the ones upstairs, we weren't neglected. 

Food wise- northern Vietnamese noodle is unlike the normal pho you get. Doesn't come with the sprouts or basil leaves you normally through into your bowl. It does come with lemon and peppers. The broth is a lot clearer and the taste is definitely different. It's not bad but I'm not blown away. When you get a small bowl, it's definitely small. I'd suggest getting the rare beef on the side. Sandwiches is definitely a Bânh Mi I would order again. You get to pick 3 items for your sandwich but it lacks in all areas including the size. Skip it. 

Bottom line, it cures my fix for a bowl of noodle soup but not wouldn't be my go-to for pho.
author: Meshell C.

description:
Not your typical PHO! And it's in ghetto neighborhood of TL = smelly, dirty everything 

PHO doesn't come with any vegetables! ZERO! NONE-- 
Some slice jalapeños and a few pieces of lime, that's it!

Water- You get a small kids glass of 6oz that you would need to ask for refill and it would take the server 10 minutes to notice you! That same goes with how many pieces of napkins they provide to you!

Broth is salty! Everything but the noodle would be ok! If you ask for no skin on your chicken, you are also asking to pay more because apparently they hand shreds their chicken and separate out skin vs. some skins, and although it's the same chicken, they fee that it's justifiable to charge you EXTRAS 

Last but not least, like all businesses, especially restaurant- all would not report cash sale to the exact! So if the manager is so obvious with the process of being selective with using certain machine or tablets to process the transaction, isn't it a little not so smart! Just saying, if I were the BOE or IRS I would've busted them already! 

Eat on Yelpers! I've had my share of thoughts and opinions!
author: Kaitlyn C.

description:
Turtle Tower is getting skimpier skimper with their pho by the day.

Only order the chicken pho (pho ga) at Turtle Tower. That is what it is known for and that is what you should stick to! Anything else is just mediocre. I use to love the chicken pho here and particularly at this location only. They also have a few locations around in the city, but it doesn't taste as good as the one in TL. 

I love drenching my pho ga with lemon and a few peppers. However, this time I saw that there wasn't as much chicken in my pho. Even my boyfriend was asking where was his cilantro and green onions. He ordered the large and my small had more green onions than his. 

Parking still sucks in this area and will always suck. Probably, should accept that by now. And there are also weirdos lurking around TL anytime of the day or night. The wait to get seated various on the time of day you go to, but usually there is a wait.

Maybe I have more higher standards because I'm Vietnamese or maybe I've been eating Turtle Tower too frequently that I expect certain things. However, the pho ga is still bomb dot com.
author: Kathleen U.

description:
First thing that stood out was the cash only sign. Had to look into my wallet to make sure I had cash! It was worth coming here after the watching World Cup at Civic Center. 

Had the chicken noodle pho, #9! It was so yummy. This is actually the first time I even drank the soup for any pho place. It was so delicious I just couldn't resist!

Ordered the thai ice tea and shared it with my boyfriend.

He ordered #2. This place is definitely for the food!
author: Corie L.

description:
Oh my pho ... how I love thee!

I am a huge fan of Vietnamese food and living in the San Gabriel Valley I have tons to pick from but there has been one thing that I have not been able to find that I found in the Bay...Northern Vietnamese style pho ga.  

I don't know if many of you all know the difference between the Southern and Northern styles so I will share a bit.  In the South you will usually find a lighter colored and a slightly lighter flavored broth.  Usually you can distinguish the different styles by looking at the clarity of soup.  The Northern region tend to use less ingredients and that's why it's actually lighter and clearer.   Another difference is in the noodle.  In the North they use a thicker and a bit shorter noodle than those you will find in the South [Hope that didn't bore you all too much]

Ok so Turtle Tower serves food from Northern Vietnam which is harder to find than one would think.  The pho ga here is amazing! It is everything you would expect and want from a Northern Pho Ga bowl of noodles.  The noodles are thick and the broth is light in color, clear and absolutely tasty! It is not too sweet or too salty.  The portion or noodles to soup is perfect and the portion over all leaves you well fed.  This has to be the only bowl of pho I continually crave and it breaks my heart that I live so very far away!

The Vietnamese coffee is the standard delicious Vietnamese coffee which, in my opinion, must be had when having Vietnamese food.  

Happy eating everyone!
author: Kimberly L.

description:
I know this is supposed to be a Vietnamese establishment, but the flavors taste more Chinese.  This is my first time having chicken pho.  The broth is very flavorful and I like how Turtle Tower allows you to have extra green onions and cilantro ("extra greens").  As you sip the soup, it feels very comforting.  If you are sick, this is the place to go for a nice bowl of soup!  Just don't touch anything else there to infect anyone.

1 star off: I want more meat in my pho!
author: Ally W.

description:
Pho is supposed to be a fast, comfort food that the restaurant is able to whip out in a few minutes because the broth has been brewing and the bowls are already prepped. Like dishes should be served in 5 minutes max. I understand this place is popular but it is basically unacceptable to wait 45 minutes and another 20 minutes for a simple pho tai. 

Maybe I should've tried the chicken pho because the beef in my bowl wasn't very good. The broth was light and didn't have very much flavor. Also the service was subpar. I didn't think this place lived up to its hype.
author: Steven V.

description: Good chicken noodle soup and imperial rolls. Number 9 is the best sometimes number 10 with the intestines instead
author: Cm Tú Đ.

description:
Came on a beautiful Saturday morning and had a great meal.

Pluses:
+ large portions
+ fast service
+ large open space with clean open feeling and high ceilings
+ reasonable prices

Minuses:
- not a lot of options for vegetarians; there is a leek broth soup as well as a few tofu options but the bulk of the food has meat

Enjoy!
author: Grace Y.

description: WORST SERVICE EVER and what do you mean you don't serve bean sprouts or basil. And what the hell are these noodles. I gotta ask for Vermicelli? What kinda ish is that?! Needless to say, I won't back.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
I've eaten here about 40 times now. The first time I went it was ok. I flipped out when I didn't see any Sriracha bottles or basil leaves. No hoisin or sprouts either. I know, how could a pho restaurant be in business without these essentials. I threw in the jalepeno pieces and was relieved when I found Sriracha sauce was in a round container instead. I got used to the wider thicker noodles but immediately loved their delicious broth. I wanted a t-shirt on my 2nd visit.

A week later, I went back to my favorite pho place, Golden Star and then realized I wanted Turtle Tower. This is how I knew I was converted.

Their broth is carefully made. I asked about the popularity of their 2 broths. They usually make 2 vats of chicken and 1 vat of beef. Obviously their chicken pho is more popular but I still think their beef broth is better. Once, I sat next to the kitchen window and watched every bowl has the noodles individually boiled in a ramen style strainer and then shaken hard to get the water out. This is why I've never had any noodles stick together.

This is a must eat for pho lovers. Northern Style is where it's at.
author: Yohan K.

description:
Never have I ever been more disappointed in Vietnamese food than I have here( and I've had viet food in Paris, bleh).

First off, I'm Vietnamese, so yes I've had pho before, and I know what good pho tastes like.
I really wanted to like Turtle Tower, as they are one of the top pho places in SF and they have four stars, but can't say I liked it one bit.

The wait wasn't very long as we got seated within 10 mins. When we sat down, our waiter promptly took our order and after we did not see him or any of the other staff the entire time we were there except for when we needed our check. It was hard to get anyone's attention to refill water. I ordered #1 Small, and was very dismayed at what I ate. There was no flavor to the broth and tasted like I was eating noodles in water. Seriously, what a disappointment. There wasn't that many noodles,although it was a small, I've gotten full at other places for less with that size. I had to squirt sriracha into my noodles because the soup did not taste like anything and after I finished, I felt like I literally ate nothing. So my friend and I went to get banh mi right after. 

I've had better pho at home when my dad makes it and at other Vietnamese restaurants. Do yourself a favor and go somewhere else to get Pho. If you like good pho, this is not the place for you! Not worth the hype !!
author: C H.

description:
Overdue review:

FYI: this review is based solely on pho, not their other dishes. 

Overrated. Not a fan of Turtle Tower at all. Probably because it was overhyped and northern style pho does not suit me. I grew up eating southern style so the pho I had here did not impress me. Others may disagree, but it's my personal opinion and I'm just telling you what my taste buds are telling me. 

If I end up coming back for any reason, I will try their other dishes instead of pho.
author: Richard T.

description: Tried the pho ga since they seem to be known for it, and was satisfied with that decision. It's northern style pho (= sans bean sprouts, leafy greens, sauces, etc), which I don't mind as long as the flavor is there. The noodles were thicker than normal, tasty nonetheless. Broth was clear, flavorful; generous enough amount of chicken and ample amounts of chopped scallions and cilantro in the broth. Went during lunch and it was crowded as expected, even more so in this rather cramped interior. Overall happy with our lunch here.
author: Will H.

description: Order was super quick and something about the noodles here is extremely unique. Not sure how they do it but it's really soft and perfect. I was really confused about no sprout and basil but I got over it fairly quickly. Location is not the best and service could be a tad better, but it's an Asian restaurant so never mind. Cheap af and lots of seating!
author: Juliana P.

description:
I've never had northern Vietnamese (Ha Noi) food. Thanks to fellow yelpers and some food critics I ordered their famous chicken noodle soup. It was AMAZING! I felt that I had never had anything so smooth and so tender before. The place is on a dirty block but inside it's very nice, bright, and clean. 

Notes:
1. I ordered the chicken soup with Giblets (#10). I liked some parts of it but thought the part with liver was a bit too strong. I would probably just order the normal Pho Ga (#9) next time. 
2. I ordered the large bowl and it was too big for me! All the surrounding ladies ordered small bowls which made me look like a pig. In the end I couldn't finish my food.
author: Wendy K.

description:
I rarely have Northern Style Pho, so when I first heard about this place from a couple of college friends, I made it a point to come here on the first chance I got. 
That chance came last Saturday. 

When in doubt over what parts of beef you would like to order, just get a mix of all or most of them. That has always been my approach at any pho restaurant, including this place when I got their special ($9.00 for a large). 

For those who have always had southern style pho, you'll be immediately taken aback from the absence of garnishments. No bean sprouts, basil leaves, razor leaves, etc. Sriracha nor hoisin sauce were available as well. I think the idea is to enjoy what is readily available in the bowl: the beef, the onion, the flat noodles, etc., without other outside influences. While it was radically different to me, who has grown up eating exclusively southern style pho, it was delightful. Even without all the garnishments, it still has that familiar taste I expect in any bowl of pho, and I enjoyed it nonetheless.
author: Viet N.

description: Fresh and compact little spring rolls (like that everyone gets their own individual peanut sauce, so I could double dip to my heart's content!) and fantastic chicken pho - comforting, smack dab full of flavor, and packed with noodles.
author: Peg S.

description:
Darn good pho. Usually pick up from this location or the one on 6th St, but we found a pakring spot and dined in at Larkin. After the wait, we were seated and our orders taken right away, food followed a few minutes after that.

Knocked off one star because my pho was not burn-my-mouth hot, but the waitress was super sweet and reheated it, even if just in the microwave, making my noodles a little soggy, but whatever, I'm here for the meat, jalepenos, and broth anyway.

Large portions, clean place, good service, reasonable prices. I will be taking my mom here for her birthday since she's never had Nothern pho.
author: Crystal C.

description: Best fried chicken I've had in long time! Thank you!! Had the soup and it was good as well.
author: Melanie Rose R.

description: Unless you are having a Vietnamese grandmother make you a homemade Pho, I'm giving TT a 5 stars, this is about as good as you will get at a restaurant, but homemade, or a real one in Vietnam will always taste more authentic. With that said, this is one of the more authentic and higher quality places in SF. They also have northern style flat noodles, try them out. I suggest the beef combo, I get it without tripe (not my thing) and the rare beef on the side because i like mixing it myself :D I go here on rainy days, its a few blocks from my work!
author: Zack D.

description: The pho ga was light and tasty, a comfort food perfect for sick days or during cold, gloomy weather. The regular beef pho, however, did not taste very good. The broth was very bland.
author: Betty T.

description:
Turtle tower is the place that you want to go if you want a cleaner taste to the 'normal' pho you are used to. I go for a large bowl of the Pho Ga most times I visit, and have not been disappointed. The soup base taste much less fatty (thus the earlier comment on the cleaner taste). The staff is pretty good about getting customers in and out, and I have not had too much trouble getting a table in under 30 minutes (even for a table of 9 the other day).

Also notable are (1) the ice coffee and (2) the fried imperial rolls. Try them out and you will not regret it!
author: Jeff M.

description:
$heeeeeeeeeeeeeeeit. 

What took me so freckin long to get me arse over here?

Was it because of the raves by 7x7 and all sorts of hipsters and Yelpers? :-o

Or maybe for a number of years I immersed myself deep inside the Sushi Sam bar (and other places like it)  and didn't come up for appropriate amounts of FOBenese air. All this while Sammy saved up eventually for a James Bondmobile and maybe a Batmobile in the garage, and I'm not talking about the Hot Toys versions ($r$ly the guy has a set of wheels like Jay Leno). Bad creature of habit I was...

Well better late than never. In scanning some of the reviews, it's pretty interesting that not everyone understands the difference between Northern style pho (i.e. Turtle Tower) and Southern style which is way more predominant. Unfortunately way too many Southern style pho shops are heavily polluted by M$G, thus making you think you are drinking magic broth, when you are just dealing with shortcut diluted solutions....kind of like your favorite tapioca milk tea sucka MC remix drink (really you are drinking WATTE, like water with a shot of tea).

Northern style pho (and thus TT) uses fresh rice noodles that closely resemble Cantonese ho fun, yet I think these are slightly superior in terms of texture and smoothness and slipperiness. Obviously the climate to the North differs vastly from the South, and thus the differences in crops suited for local cuisine (including spices, herbs, etc)....and quite possibly more historic Chinese influence from the North (than the South).

Pretty much a no brainer that TT's signature is Pho Ga, or if you are hardcore FOB of any kind, the chicken with giblets (ie chicken parts) might be the way to go. Plus it has been forever since I had those chicken "ovaries" with the non fully formed eggs that are quite delicious (better than balut I'm sure). Plus it doesn't hurt the fact they use free range chicken for original flavor, original taste. It's like they are talking to my deep inner FOB. And I also love the fact that even after you put in the order, it takes a while to come out (especially in a packed house). None of that that "order comes within 5 minutes" McPho BS. Totally worth the wait.

The Chao Ga, or chicken congee, is of a similar principle. It's of a different texture than the Chao I had at Trieu Chau in Santa Ana (which was more Vietnamese Chinese Chiu Chow) where that texture was more like watery broken up rice...and the rice grains were not fully "exploded". Chao Ga here has a texture similar to that of Cantonese congee, but not as creamy, yet the crisp and clean chicken flavors were there, unaided by the BS known as M$G. Sure you can season it further to your liking with the limited sucka MC condiments at the table, but you really don't need it.

Sometimes a restaurant doesn't need to screw around. Focus on a handful (or less) of signatures and freckin nail that to the ground, and hit it hard and deep.
Keep it as consistent as possible, and deliver as promised (or under promise and over deliver) and that's a formula for eternal success and delighting the customer.
The problem is that Asian Americans and some FOBs like variety like a Jack in the Dennys or HK café...and that's when it gets messy. Until a place comes that pulls off a Cooking Papa where 85% of the menu is brilliant and above average, and fairly consistent, it's risky to have a big and broad menu unless you can Jiro Dreams Of Pho out of everything (yeah sure, the pursuit of perfection yet never reaching the top, until Jiro discovers M$G for his pho recipe).
author: Ken K.

description:
I've been coming to Turtle Tower for years when it was at its older (smaller) location just down the street.  I'm not sure if I'm just imagining it, but I've been to the new location twice and it's been a bit disappointing.  Still good pho, just not as amazing as I remembered.  Ordered the pho ga (no skin) and it was really mostly just noodles with very little chicken (along with some skin still floating around the soup).   One benefit is that the wait is shorter at least. 

Cash only.
author: Vivian W.

description:
I used to love badly.
First, during their remodel, I drove by more than 5 times to see if they are open. 
I'm so happy for this new bright, clean, huge dinning area. Staff are nice, but need more training and experience. 
My dear pho ga chicken pho is still light tasty but yet full of chicken flavor. Just the way I love.

Ever since I found the Pho Ga on Noriega, I rarely visit here. 

After months, here I am again with all colleagues. Chicken pho is the same. Service hasn't been improve at all. 
The lady was kinda cute, ask what we like without writing them down first. When she try to write down our orders, she forgot. She asks us all over again.... And still cannot get the order right. 

For the spring roll and calamari cake, OMG... $2.25 for ONE single small piece of spring roll? $2.50 for ONE calamari cake. Are you serious!? We don't taste anything special. Compare the value and quality, it a 100%  rip off. If you could afford this, go for Yank Sing. 

Sorry turtle towel... I lost the faith in you.
author: JustinE Y.

description:
Pho Ga (with skinless chicken) is always winner! Again, I try not to let myself consume "heavy carbs" so I only come here occasionally.. mostly when I'm feeling a little under the weather. Turtle Tower never fails me! Thank the Lord they have another location in the Richmond District so I don't have to trek all the way to the TL every time! 

My mommy isn't a huge fan though because she says they use a lot of MSG here.. I'm just going to pretend like I didn't hear what she said!
author: Michelle L.

description:
love turtle tower. only been here and to the one on Geary Street. just simple delicious Northern pho. this is not the Saigon southern pho so don't expect basil and bean sprouts as your side garnish. 

I always get #10 with the chicken and intestines. soup is very tasty but light at the same time. comes in two sizes but the large is too large for me. small is a good size and plenty enough to fill you. Occasionally I would get the rare beef pho. Beef on the side and beef is pretty soft. 

good spring rolls with shrimps and BBQ pork fillings. 

friendly service and I saw this waitress who really took her time to explain Hanoi pho to this one customer. and offer to help him take pictures with his food that he ordered. she was quick to note to wish us happy sleeping when we were leaving. very on point since we went around 8am and we were in our work scrubs. we gotten off work at 7:30am and drove there for breakfast. the breakfast of champion! so comforting too. and not too heavy before sleep!
author: Jules L.

description:
someone needs to sharpie under their egg roll vermicelli description:

======  APPETIZER (we WILL rip you off)  =======

explains why nobody else ordered the dish when i looked around

this will be my first & last time there. 

This place will forever be associated with hunger for me.  If anyone ever suggests it, my response will be "f8ck THAT place"
author: Samantha W.

description:
Turtle Tower is one of my favorite restaurants. Their ingredients are high quality and you can taste how fresh everything is. I've been to the Richmond and SOMA locations, but my favorite is the TL location as I think the broth there is the best. I go there at least once a week and usually order the chicken noodle soup (#9) with extra greens. This is great on a foggy SF day and is my go-to remedy for any malady, including hang-overs, colds, breakups (they have take-out) or generally feeling down. Don't get me wrong, I also go there when I'm in a good mood.

My other favorites on the menu are the chicken porridge (#21) and stir fried beef with celery, carrot, onion, and leek pan-fried noodle (#7, no soup). The chicken porridge has the same flavors as the chicken noodle soup with similar ingredients and is a nice, warming breakfast. The pan-fried noodle has a delicious wok flavor with a light, flavorful gravy for those rare days I'm not in the mood for soup.

Don't be turned off by the TL location, it is worth the trip.
author: Jessie L.

description:
A neat little establishment that serves a very strict northern tradition vietnamese cuisine. 

With that being said, they will NOT serve you bean sprouts or hoisen sauce. Even if you ask for it. Their broth is different, but can't be explained by an amatuer like me. Their noodles are different. They're the flat and wide kind.

It wasn't bad, but I wouldn't come back. I suppose I like southern pho.
author: Mimi N.

description:
I don't usually rate restaurants, but was exceptionally disappointed.    The noodles were overcooked and gummy, and the Pho was flavorless.  
Imperial rolls were a tiny sad attempt.
The waiter was diffident.   With so much good Pho in the neighborhood,will not return.
author: Karen S.

description:
Came here for my first meal of 2014 at 130pm and they were packed!  Tried the Pho Ga because people raved about it on Yelp.  While the broth itself was clear and good, I prefer something more flavorful and complex.  I do like that they put a lot of cilantro and green onion in there though.  

Apparently, this is the place to be because the lines outside were long.  We had to wait about 40 minutes even though we came after lunch hours.  Thankfully, Quickly is next door and we could grab a cup of bubble tea to hold us over until our meal!  

I would come back if it wasn't so busy next time and try the other things on the menu.
author: Jenny L.

description: The restaurant was clean and staff were accommodating. But the food was bland. We ordered #4 pho bo. The noodles were over cooked. The soup had no taste. We also ordered the grilled pork. It could have been juicier.
author: Katy L.

description:
Food is good...Even though it is peasant Northern Vietnamese food (yes I'm a South Vietnamese.....what about it)  ;-)

A little pricey and half of the clientele are not Vietnamese.....typically a sign of a good restaurant...(to elaborate:  you go to a Thai restaurant if most of the clientele are Thai)

Nevertheless the pho is tasty, the cafe su da was not as strong as I like it but still good.

I'd go back....begrudgingly...all my friends I've taken here like it.  Guess it's okay for peasant Northern Vietnamese.  LoL
author: Edward M.

description: I appreciate the idea of 'focusing on their broth' but it's not that great. Need hoisin, which they don't give you.
author: Joshua B.

description: Great place to eat at. I always order the Pho Ga (Chicken noodle soup). I even ordered a banh mi to go for later.
author: Frank L.

description: Got delivery from here this morning, when we opened the soup it smelt so foul like rotten meat. The rare beef I asked for on the side was also a grey blue color, not red. It smelt old and rotten. Chicken was ok, but still couldn't eat it because of the foul smell of the broth.
author: Sara U.

description: Best Northern Vietnamese restaurant in town. Chicken pho with giblets and sticky rice with Vietnamese sausages are my most favorite!
author: Chi L.

description: on cold days, their pho ga or chicken noodle soup is great and always hits the spot. they have several locations and always a good go to!
author: Calvin C.

description: Chicken pho is a must! This place is know for its chicken pho, so my friends and I never get anything else. We always crave Turtle Tower after a night of clubbing. The best hang over cure. The staff are always friends. Great pho. I just wish there was sriracha sauce at the place.
author: Michelle O.

description:
They are making money, not foods.

I went to this restaurant with my friend this afternoon, We ordered No 1 and 7. No 1 is beef soup noodle, No 7 is fried beef noodle. (I dont remember the menu title).

No 1 didn't taste like Vietnamese soup at all, the soup noodle didnt have side beansprots or Vietnamese herb leaves, it just tasted like water with some salt and msg.

No 7 was even worse, I guess they didn't wash the pan before they saute another dish, so the fried noodle seemed darker and oily, and tasted greasy and a little bitter. After I tried one bite, I didn't touch it at all.

I don't understand why there was a long line in front of this kind of bad restaurant, I won't recommend it to anyone, it tasted totally garbage for me, and it destoryed my good mood today. In my opinion, it is the worst Vietnamese Restaurant I've ever tried before!

By the way, from their open kitchen, i found out that all kitchen staff including the chef are Mexican. I am not a racism，I mention that only to prove they are not selling authentic Vietnamese food.

I am kind lazy person and I am not interested in writing comments at all. You may find out how much I hate it. And I am not a English speaker!!!
author: Jessie Z.

description: This was hands down, the best pho ga I've ever had.  I came here with my girlfriend yesterday relatively early for lunch around 10:30 AM.  There was no line at the time, but it did get busier while we were there.  We both ordered a small bowl of pho ga.  The noodles were a bit thicker than your traditional pho noodles.  The broth was absolutely delicious.  The only thing I wished I would have done differently was order a larger size bowl.  My girlfriend doesn't usually finish a whole bowl of pho, but today she did.  The only downside is parking, but that's given in SF.  I would highly recommend coming here.
author: Andrew N.

description:
If you're Vietnamese like me and expecting traditional Saigon pho , you will make a rare trek to the Tenderloin only to tease your pho cravings  and leave unsatisfied  

No meatballs (bo vien), noodles too wide, bland broth, no hoisin sauce, no basil or bean sprouts or cilantro, lime instead of lemon (?!). The carrots in the banh mi sammich wasn't pickled as it should be. The banh me had an egg  in it which I'm usually supportive of in my sammich/burger but it was just strange . The spring roles and cafe sua da were so-so. Le sigh all around. 
 
Minimal people watching . Although that's not what you come here for... lol. I had good company so it wasn't a total waste.
author: Kimmy P.

description:
I think they do the best pho ga in SF. I'm aware of the differences between Northern and Southern style pho, but I prefer Northern style pho ga over its Southern counterpart. 

Turtle Tower makes some really great food. I almost always order the pho ga when I'm here, but the beef ones aren't bad either. I've tried the bun, but for me, I come here for the pho ga. People say there are differences between this location, the one in the Outer Richmond, and the one in SoMa, but they're all equally good to me. The che ba mau (three color bean dessert) isn't bad either. 

I don't know if there's MSG or not in the broth, but when I've eaten here, I haven't had severe post-MSG consumption effects. That's a definite plus.
author: Jared L.

description:
Stopped here for a quick bite for lunch. It was very busy but we were seated pretty quickly. I had to chicken pho and the egg rolls. It was all very fresh, flavorful, and affordable.

Highly recommend.
author: Bernadette T.

description:
Menu seems nearly the same. Price point went up a bit. Still the same good ole pho ga but in a nicer setting. 

Expect more of a wait. Staff seems different than the old location down the block and are a bit slower.
author: Susy C.

description:
Recommend getting Pho Ga. I usually prefer beef pho over chicken pho, but TT's Pho Ga broth is way better than the beef Pho broth, which I was a little disappointed by. 

However, I believe their have the best noodles out of the all the pho places I've been to (i've been to many) - fresh and fat pearly looking noodles! The meats in beef pho are also fresh and delicious, and they give you plenty.

Aside from the food, their interior is nice and clean and the service is good - they even asked us if we wanted more water after we had paid!
author: Ying Ying S.

description:
.. Seriously, maybe cuz i am from northern vietnam so I had better (pho)! OMG their beef pho is like hot water, there is no taste to them. NEVER want to try pho here again.

The chicken pho have  more taste to it. However, I had it better from some where else. sigh... Disappointed in this place.

Well I guess, I least their spring rolls is yummy. I would come back just for springs rolls!!
author: Lala B.

description:
Why on earth did it take me so long to try this place out? .... Oh right, cuz they close at 5. Other than their weird hours, everything was great. Well, service was mediocre at best, but it's an asian restaurant... what do you expect?

Everyone I know says their #9 and #10- the chicken pho, is the best. This will be my go-to if I'm ever sick. It tastes soooooo good. It's like homemade chicken noodle soup, but asian style. Can't beat that. 

Oh ya, cash only. :P
author: Mandi W.

description:
Yum! Really fantastic & fresh Vietnamese food! I love that they have Hanoi specials, like bun cha, which I can never find anywhere in Sacramento where I live. In fact, I've never even seen this dish on a menu since my trip to Vietnam! Their Pho is really good, both beef & chicken, & the portion sizes are quite large. They also have other Vietnamese dishes that I grew up eating, like porridge & other noodle dishes. It's very comforting & reminds me of home! 

The only reason I docked a star is because parking can be a pain on the crowded streets (mostly metered parking) & the wait time can be SUPER long! Even though they moved to a bigger location, that only seems to fuel the flame & more people show up. 

All in all, this is a solid Vietnamese restaurant & I'd gladly return when I'm in the city!
author: Lori N.

description:
The Chicken Pho is on-point. TT is actually the only place I will order chicken pho (Pho Gai). However, the service was poor and it's quite expensive for a pho place. 

This isn't to say I won't come back, but I'll defs make sure I am craving Pho Gai. 

Oh! It's so expensive that an, just one, Imperial Roll is $2.25. TWO DOLLARS AND TWENTY-FIVE CENTS. 

WHAT?
author: Stephanie W.

description: Great location! I had gone to other ones but not this one and was please to see how big, clean, new, and etc it was. The soups and noodles were good and the sizes were perfect. The summer rolls were refreshing and I wish the fried rolls were 1. cheaper 2. came in a larger quantity. I got the chick soup this time and my friend got the noodle bowl. The pho also looked good and i've gone to the other location for that. Google kept on telling me the location *probably the old one* is closed but it def is open and busy!
author: Lily P.

description:
The stir-fried beef pho was extremely flavorful! The beef and noodles are stir-fried BEFORE being thrown into the soup with noodles and veggies. 

The imperial rolls, rice paper thin skin stuffed with veggies and meat, were delicious but teeny tiny. It's very pricey for the portion size.
author: Jenn S.

description:
YES. IT'S BACK. I remember talking to my friend a while back about how I wanted to try out Turtle Tower -- we ended up at the SoMA one, and boy, I was disappointed. However, this one! Excitement! The only thing is that this place closes at 5 PM, so make sure you go at lunch (perfect for a "working from home day")

I went with my coworker and her brother around noon time. Already a line was built up, and there was a longer line afterward.

I had myself the combination pho, which is filled with all the types of beef (haha). I quickly devoured it. All was gone.

We also had the chicken giblets, which were amazing -- and great to dip into the lemon dip that they had.

Service was great as well. They were always checking up on us to see if everything was fine, which is absolutely different from all the other pho places that I've been to in Toronto. 

I heard the chicken pho is delish as well.. So I guess I will have to come back sooner or later. ;)
author: Joanne W.

description:
There is only one thing I order every time I come here with my family, Pho Chicken Noodle or Number 9 on the Menu, Large size. Honestly, the price difference between Regular and Large is negligible for the delicious noodle and broth. I always add lemon and Jalepeno Spice into my broth to add more flavor, and I soon find myself drowning in the taste like a judge from the manga series Food Wars: Shokugeki no Soma. 

The wait time might be difficult, considering the location ain't exactly prime for parking, but I can guarantee that this place is worth coming to. 

Its a shame my family and I moved to the East Bay; we still return to San Francisco to visit the family and when we do, we always come here. One of my favorite places growing up in San Francisco and it hasn't disappointed me yet!. We need a location in the East Bay eventually!
author: Kenneth T.

description:
I've had pho in a lot of places - in Texas, in San Diego, in Vietnam. & Turtle Tower is simply the best. I always feel bad eating here since my family is from Southern Vietnam (& I assume the family that runs this place are northerners) but I can't help it,  it's one of the best (if not the best) pho I've ever had. They say they make their own noodles and that the chicken is free range, not sure if that's true but it sure tastes like it is. 

My roommate and I use to live around the corner in the 'loin and go here every Sunday when we were hungover or feeling sluggish. They are super fast because most people just order the chicken pho. It's amazing when you're sick. We moved away a good handful of months ago and I remember us just really regretting that decision because Turtle Tower was no longer accessible by 2 minute walk. 

Pro-tip, grab some pho in the morning and then stop by the AMC on Van Ness for an afternoon matinee...Sunday traditions never die. Ever since I moved out of San Francisco, I miss this place so much.
author: Connie P.

description: CHICKEN PHO. That's all you need to know. I was apprehensive because I don't like trying new things when I get the same thing at every pho place.. but thank God I took a leap of faith. JUST DO IT. You can also request all dark meat, or all white meat depending on your preference. The noodles are the thicker glass noodles. CASH ONLY.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Enjoyed vermicelli with bbq pork and bf had bbq pork with rice. Also had the fresh spring roll- you could really taste the mint and it was yummy!

Good service, clean and friendly staff. Oh, and close to Asian Art museum, and across Chairman. Convenient!
author: Nathalie C.

description: Nicer, cleaner, and more modern than their old digs which used to be located just a half block down the street. Even more crowded, however, with the increased space. Their pho tai is still awesome and is, quite frankly, the only thing I ever want to order. Still my favorite place for Northern Vietnamese-style pho.
author: Erich D.

description:
I was visiting SF for a week, and I was at Turtle Tower 3 times! Cannot get enough of the chicken pho! This soup is light and very flavorful, lots of greens (cilantro and green onions), served with flat wide rice noodles, yummmmm!! If you are looking for some extra flavor, you can always ask for some lemon salt dipping sauce for your chicken. A small bowl is more than enough, at a very affordable price!

Cash only, please! And be prepared for a wait during a busy lunch time!
author: Ziyu W.

description:
Love the new place they moved into. The new place is less scarier than the other place haha. 

The food is always good and staff are always as nice as usual. 

The wait can be a bit long. About a 10 minute wait or so.
author: Vernice T.

description: This is all around great pho and bun and fast service. If you work nearby you can easily make it in and out on your lunch hour. If you love Vietnamese food you will love this place. The prices for a small are reasonable, and I think most people would be satisfied with a small.
author: Paloma N.

description: food is ok there, friendly staff also but it's just too much hype. I came all the way down to Tenderloin but it's just ok...
author: Roy O.

description: The server is also the buss person, unsanitary. He uses bare hand to scrape the food out of the plates then he go pick up orders to deliver food with out washing his hands. So i just ordered iced coffee, my mom had the hot soup. Not coming here again.
author: J C.

description:
I came here because my friend LOVES this place but I was really underwhelmed when I tried it ):

I ordered the chicken pho and I was so sad because it didn't satisfy my pho craving at ALL. The soup was not flavorful enough and a little too bland -- probably better with more salt. The meat tasted old and there was way too much fatty skin given. I would have liked more actual meat. I like the thick noodles that they used though!

Just a note: this place doesn't give you bean sprouts or basil/mint leaves with your pho. They only give you lime and jalapeños. And no hoisin sauce or sriracha at the table either. They have fish sauce on the condiment stand though, which is uncommon but pretty awesome that they do that!

I probably wouldn't come back but I'm glad I got to try it.
author: Kelly T.

description: Great food ok service. The area is a lil ruff and very smelly watch your surroundings. I have been here many of times and keep forgetting to leave a review
author: Rebecca F.

description:
There's only one traditional vietnamese joint of note in this godforsaken city: Turtle Tower in little saigon; and not because its delicious (which it is) but because its true to form, true to its specific offering from a region in vietnam. every last other viet joint is a hodge podge of vietnamese food with little to no focus, like an american diner representing american food as opposed to a cajun restaurant or a texas bbq. 

Fresh homemade noodles, get the beef or chicken pho; the chicken is their specialty.
author: jacob m.

description: Service is horrible. Found a roach and told the manager about it. He didnt replace the soup but gave me free eggrolls. 4stars is because they really do make the best chicken noodles in town, minus the roach.
author: Meng L.

description:
I haven't been here since their last location closed, but I just remember this was the go-to pho place of my childhood whenever I was in the Bay. Having said that, I came in with high expectations. 

The pho ga was just ok. It wasn't really anything special like what I remembered. I did like the consistency of the pho noodles though. I tried some of my dad's pho tai bam and that was a little better (still not as good as what I remembered it to be?). The broth was more flavorful and the tai bam was really good. 

My mom ordered goi cuon and it was also just a-ok... nothing special. The rolls were super skinny and did not really warrant a five dollar price tag, but I liked how they had shrimp and thit nuong. 

If I'm ever in the area again, I'll probably hit up this place but I wouldn't drive to their neighborhood to purposely go there.
author: Crystal H.

description:
Although many like the chicken pho, my fav is the brisket one. Friendly service, expect a fairly long wait weekends and prime lunch hours. New location is much nicer than the previous one a few doors down.

Only bummer is that this location is only open until 5p (others open later, but we prefer this one :)
author: steve c.

description: This is by far the best place that serves Pho. The noodles are so delicious. The owners are wonderful people as well. If you are ever in the city, this place is a must.
author: Absolute V.

description:
Really confused with this place. Everyone said it was so good and then I tried it... It has to be the top 3 worst phos Ive ever had. I even came back again because my friends said I actually had to try the chicken pho (not the normal pho). This was a few inches better but also very disappointing. It is filled with chicken fat and msg.

I don't understand how they got such high reviews.
author: Christopher N.

description: I had the #3 Pho bowl with rare beef and the spring rolls. The spring rolls had a lot of flavor with the perfect amount of mint. As for the pho; honestly I found the broth quite bland and flavorless. But after some considerable doctoring with condiments, it was pretty tasty. I have eaten pho many times in Southern California but I think it is a different style because the broth is much richer and they give you bean sprouts and other veggies to put on your soup. That being said, the service was excellent and the food came out very fast. I would come back again and try something else on the menu.
author: Tracey P.

description:
Came here for a simmr.co event where the owner showed us his kitchen and allowed us to customize our pho. I got the beef broth with chicken and beef. it was sooo delicious! I loved the soup. The owner was also very friendly and he told us some little tips and tricks. 

1. instead of using the lemon wedges, try using the vinegar instead
2. instead of using siracha, use the homemade hot sauce! (be careful though! that hot sauce is extremely hot! looks can be deceiving :O) 

enjoy!
author: Annie Z.

description: Yes, another great pho spot.. Neighborhood a little on the sketchy side, but sometimes you have to take these little risks to get what you want and you will definitely want this.  Friendly service and supper fast is a bonus!  Normally, beef is my go to but yelpers say chicken is the way to go and it paid off.  Super clean, tasty broth and all fresh ingredients.  A must for any pho craving.
author: Ric C.

description: I love Turtle Tower's Pho Ga! The broth is unique and very flavorful. It's nothing like the typical pho broth I've encountered but it's delicious. I love that it's wider noodles too. I'm tired of the typical pho vermicelli noodles lol
author: Jasmine N.

description:
I've never been to the old location so can't compare but was pleasantly surprised today to walk into a clean spacious restaurant that wouldn't be out of place in the basement food court of the Westfield. The young folks working there were cheerful and quick about everything. It was only a few minutes - like literally less than 5 minutes - after I ordered the Pho Ga when it arrived at my table. Of course as it's become my new habit to eat lunch at 3 PM it shouldn't have been so surprising. And as a late weekday lunch person I noticed once again that I'm not the only one. Quite a few other tables were also occupied. 

The Pho Ga is very lightly flavored. Some people may consider it bland. The noodles are wider than other pho places. The chicken reminds me of Chinese steamed chicken. And the broth is just the thing for when you're feeling down. Like really good home made chicken broth. It's both light and comforting at the same time.
author: Jean K.

description:
I like it. 

Good and inexpensive chicken soup.
