The service is a little unfriendly and they really don't need your business. Our server brought our bill to the table and not two minutes later the woman behind the cash register was waving me over to come up to her to pay even though there were no others waiting to pay and she was standing no more than two steps from our table doing nothing.

You need to try the Pho here. It is better than most.
author: Justin S.

description:
If you're expecting hoisin sauce, sriracha, bean sprouts, and all that jazz - keep in mind this place is Northern Vietnamese cuisine, which doesn't have any of that! That said, I was really impressed, even though I was at first skeptical!

The place was super crowded even for a Sunday at 1pm, but we didn't have to wait long for a table. The service was excellent! Everyone was very friendly and we were greeted by a waiter almost right after we sat down. The time from ordering to serving the food was blazing fast! Maybe around 5 minutes or less, even though it was busy! 

And I've gotta say, the pho was incredible; light yet flavorful yet filling. I've always been one to add tons of hoisin and sriracha sauce to my pho, but this pho really didn't need any at all! It was just the right balance of meat, veggies, and noodles!

Definitely coming back again!
author: Michael T.

description:
This was my very first Pho experience, and it was delicious. However, because I'm a Pho noob, I'll keep the review to the restaurant experience.

The short of it: the space was clean, the service quick and the environment was bustling but friendly. The portions are giant and the food comes out quickly. Parking seemed easy enough to find on the street. Give it a go.
author: Morgan A.

description:
Vietnamese fare is my favorite. If I had to pick one genre to have for the rest of my life, it would be Vietnamese food. Therefore, I eat a lot of it.

Hands down: TURTLE TOWER IS THE BEST PHO I'VE EVER HAD. While unverified, a friend said it was Northern Vietnamese style. It certainly isn't like other pho I've had - where they serve a dish of mint, cilantro, beans sprouts, and jalapenos alongside. That pho "salad" isn't a part of this. The noodle is also wide and flat when compared to other pho. But beyond those differences, it's pretty much the same in terms of broth, ingredients, etc. But that broth... you couldn't get a more concentrated, full-flavored broth. Just perfect.

The service is great. Sometimes there's a wait - and while I'm not one to wait at a restaurant - I will here.

My only complaint - which is why I only gave them 4/5 stars:  They don't take credit card. C'mon... it's 2015. If it's the fees they don't want to deal with - their food is so cheap they could bump the price to cover fees and it would still be a steal.
author: Warren P.

description: The food is great, tho only open til 5 so you have to come on the weekends. Really fresh
author: Robert H.

description: Northern style pho~  i love the thick noodles!!!  I wish they would still give you sprouts and onions tho~  chicken pho was very delish~ the broth was clean yet savory.. I miss it already~
author: Isabelle H.

description:
The cleanest bowl of pho in SF.  When I'm feeling sick I eat here twice a day.  I could eat here everyday and not grow tired of it...sick or not. The set up is bare bones and simple the soup is ideal. The line at the door can be annoying and they have an entire upstairs that they never seem to use? If you can't deal with the wait hit golden lotus at the old TT location. Slightly more hearty but very acceptable bowl of pho. 
4.5 stars
author: tim s.

description:
Service is unbelievably rude toward us ( we are Vietnamese American ) by the bald head host . But we observed his service toward Caucasian is totally opposite? Weird but we're not here to complaint about their service . The pho ga ( chicken pho) was so bland we asked for hoysin sauce . The mean waitress told us no sauce no veggies , wow they really think their pho soup is the best . 


Wake up people these guys don't have the best pho , I have tasted Northern Pho in Paris in the Asian district and it is way better than this mediocre joke of a pho restaurant.
author: Khoa N.

description:
The tower of tastelessness attended by the ultimate in unskilled so-called service. We were served completely unadorned, unseasoned, over-cooked mealy chicken along with overcooked, unseasoned, sticky rice that was more like elmer's glue rice.

Most questions to the waiter were met with a stone faced "no" without his ever truly considering any way of giving us any options. Even when I asked about a nearby ATM as I realized it was cash only, and asked about the closest ATM, he directed me to Market Street, several blocks away. I happened to look out the window, saw a big neon ATM sign directly across the street. When I pointed this out to him, he didn't acknowledge his error. He stared blankly at me and walked away.

This experience was like being served prison food by zombies.

And our bill for two beverages and tasteless food was thirty-five bucks. Really, I'd rather have had a pedicure and drank the dirty foot water. Better tasting and at least when it's done you have something to show for it.

squinka sez: dat was nasssty, and not in the good way.
author: Squinka C.

description:
Cash only! And come before 11, the lunch rush starts then.

Damn, turtle tower is no joke. I've been wanting to try this place for so long, and it definitely lives up to ALL the hype that you see in these reviews, and the wait is worth it! We saw a couple people standing outside and were worried that we'd have to wait a long time, but we were seated within 5 minutes of putting our name down.

Be aware that this pho is different because it's northern style pho. The pho you normally get at pho restaurants is southern style. Northern style pho features wider rice noodles, and there are no garnishes like mint and bean sprouts - nor do they have sriracha and hoisin (not that I saw, anyways). They do add some green onion and cilantro to the pho, which is all I tend to do anyways, so as not to take away too much focus from the broth.

I know that the pho ga (chicken pho) is supposed to be the best item on the menu, but I'm definitely more of a rare steak kind of girl, so I went with my usual pho tai. I always get the rare steak on the side, marinate it in lemon/lime juice for several minutes, and then cook it for a couple of seconds in the hot broth before eating. The meat could have been better - it wasn't thinly sliced pho tai like I'm used to, but it was still delicious. The broth and noodles were AMAZING - so hearty and flavorful, but didn't feel heavy like many pho places that add msg to their bro.

My friend and I also shared the chicken porridge which was just as, if not more, incredible. I may just have to get two entrees every time I frequent this place, because I couldn't tell which one I liked more. The chicken in the porridge isn't dry or overcooked at all - quite the opposite, and flavored lightly with ginger.

Just wish this place was closer for those painful Sunday mornings when my body is screaming for chicken porridge and pho tai... but honestly, it was so damn good that I would make the venture into the TL again!!
author: Chrystal Z.

description: Don't bother getting the sticky rice with chicken and sausage. It's not even good. The rice was alright and the meat was not mixed in with the rice. It was relatively small portion for the price. I might've as well gotten pho. However, afterwards, I was not feeling so well. So probably not a good idea to order that again...
author: Ann L.

description:
I used to go here twice a week!  The chicken pho is the best.  The soup is very flavorful, its clean and light, and the service is pretty good when its not too busy.

I like everything here.  This is Hanoi Style pho.  When i first came here I was pretty confused because they didn't have hoisin sauce, but then i soon figured out why.

Since there soup is so good!  you dont need it!

This is where i would take anyone, at any time.  It's so awesome I mention it in my choose your own adventure 1 day all day trip guide to san francisco which you can read here.

http://www.thealldayblog.com/the-choose-your-own-adventure-1-day-all-day-trip-guide-to-san-francisco/

Enjoy the pho, especially on a cold rainy day!

Thank you turtle tower!
author: Michael L.

description: This place has great pho and chicken noodle soup! Granted this is the only place I've ever had the Northern style of the vietnamese pho but it really impresses. The soup for both the pho and the chicken noodle soup is beautifully savory and not too oily. I would also recommend the iced filtered coffee with condensed milk. Overall, it's a great restaurant with amazing food and not too bad of a wait.
author: Amanda N.

description:
Omg, why so GOOD?? I wanted to smuggle a sample of the broth so my mom can make something similar. Between you and I, she probably can't. But don't tell my momma that. Okay??? Shh.

Get the Pho Ga its Pho Crack.
author: Cin H.

description: The best pho around. Fantastic homemade noodles!
author: R S.

description: I ordered a large #4: Combination rare beef, tripe, well done beef noodle soup. Biggest complaints were the cuts of meat and the banh pho flat noodles used in the soup. The meat wasn't anything special, and ended up with the texture and taste of lean ground beef. I don't think there was anything rare, or any tripe in my bowl. The broth was alright, but the thicker banh pho noodles made a big difference in how the rest of the soup tasted since you were essentially getting 2x-4x more noodle per spoonful than if the typical noodle were used. They brought out a tiny plate with jalapeños, lemons (instead of limes), and no bean sprouts or herbs. You sort of just got the feeling that they were trying to be different here, and somehow this turned to hype by word of mouth. For the price, and the location, I would have rather picked up a few cold-cut sandwiches from Saigon Sandwich.
author: Andrew L.

description: I go there for chicken pho ( pho ga)! It wasn't the best but it was good! I enjoyed it! i usually paired it up chicken meat side, so the pho would be more meaty! :)
author: Sophia L.

description:
This is a review for their new place, it's so big and so clean, love it.  

The food is the same as it's always been. Over the past year I've grown to like it, it's definitely different than real pho but it's not bad at all.

I tried the beef pho for the first time though and I'd have to say I'll be sticking with the chicken from here on out.  Not a fan of the steak they put in there, it was a little too chopped.

The prices seem to have gone up a bit too.
author: Tu T.

description:
I used to come here a lot but this visit is a disappointment experience.
Service worth 4 stars but food is not as tasty as before kind of sloppy put together. Just another chicken pho place make me missed the old place with the home cooking touch.
author: Cocoa W.

description:
My Chicken noodle soup had dish soap taste to it. I am not picky when it comes to food, but the soap taste just simply ruined my appetite. I had few tries and couldn't eat it anymore.

But what was annoying was that the lady who I complained to literally raised her voice in front of my face trying to prove that the dish is fine. A classy thing would be to either bring a new dish, or give me at least a partial refund for the food that I just could not eat. 

Horrible customer service experience. Will never go there again.
author: Brian C.

description: I loved the old Turtle Tower. When the quality was actually good... Soup is now just full of MSG, the chicken isn't even juicy anymore, and the service went way down. I rather drive out to Oakland to have Pho Ga' now.
author: Crystal C.

description: Finally made it here! After several years, the stars aligned and I found myself at 3pm on a weekday craving pho. Went straight to Turtle Tower and it did not disappoint. Heavenly broth, perfect noodles and generous meat and toppings. Great meal. So happy.
author: Maya S.

description:
Love their chicken pho. Perfect meal when you're sick, when it's rainy, or whenever. It's like a big bear hug in a bowl of yummy broth brightened with lemon and herbs. 

The stir fried beef pho is good as well. Cash only. But I'd walk to 10 ATM's for this place.
author: Kris L.

description: Great food, cheap mimosas with fresh squeezed orange juice... what's not to like?! Better get here well before you are hungry though because it tends to get busy early and there can be a line out the door!
author: Aaron H.

description: Would not recommend coming here if you are a vegetarian! The only substantial option for vegetarians is a very mediocre bahn mi sandwich with egg. I was very disappointed because I wanted pho, but all of the options contain meat. With that said, if you eat meat, the pho looked and smelled great!
author: Kerry R.

description: My go-to for chicken pho in the city. The broth tastes clean and there's a good amount of chicken. Fairly priced and good service. Perfect for a chilly day. I went here on a Sunday afternoon and liked that they were playing Sunday NFL on the TVs.
author: Elissa S.

description:
Still the gold standard for me for Pho Ga...  Broth is top notch, chicken is plentiful, tasty, and not dry.  And the they only serve the most basic veggies, hot peppers and lemon, that's it.  Been here many times, but waited for the new place on Larkin St. to open up before writing a review.  I've been to the one on Geary and 6th/Bryant, but prefer this one.  Parking can be a challenge.

Besides being new, what we found impeccable was the service.  Even better than before.  Even on a busy Sunday, with a line out the door, the owner checks every table to make sure it's clean.  We even watched him look under tables and on the floor before seating a customer.  These guys get it and being in the Tenderloin, sometimes expectations aren't quite as high, but they clearly take it seriously which is why I'd wait for a table here.

We also had spring rolls which were fresh and the shrimp were pretty good sized.  I liked that the sauce was on the thick side.  I know some folks like it watery, but not me.

As others have said, it would be great if they opened late.  And they are a bit pricey for a bowl of Pho, but man it's good.  But the bonus, they open everyday at 8:00am if you need your fix.  Enjoy!
author: Gerry T.

description:
Wow!  Turtle Tower is so much nicer and not as dark and scary looking as the OG location from years ago!  If you're looking for a steaming bowl of deliciousness, try the chicken pho (pho ga).  I prefer the chicken pho because it's has a lighter taste than the beef.  Although, when I'm in a beef mood, I'll totally order the beef pho!  

Note that this is Northern style pho and it doesn't come with bean sprouts, basil, or hoisin sauce.  Also, the noodles are wider than the thin pho noodles most of the restaurants use.  Try adding a squeeze of lemon to add another later of flavor and also the sliced jalapeño for extra heat.  I only use the sriracha to dip pieces of chicken, since I love the original flavor and don't like to taint the broth by adding any additional sauces.
author: Wendy S.

description: I had been told that Turtle Tower had great pho, so I went last week in the late afternoon. I ordered the Pho Ga, and have to say I wasn't terribly impressed. As a bowl of - essentially - chicken noodle soup goes, it was good. But it didn't distinguish itself at all from anything else out there. Perhaps I should try some of their beef options, with different ingredient/sauce combos. But based on the pho ga, it's certainly filling and satisfying but likely not any different or better than what can be found in many other spots in SF.
author: David B.

description:
This review is solely for their service.

I went to this restaurant for the first time yesterday with a friend and ordered the chicken noodle soup and it tasted great. I've had good vietnamese chicken noodle soups elsewhere as well. I asked one of the waiters for hoisin sauce. The waiter responds very quickly and goes (i'm paraphrasing), "sorry, you're not supposed to eat chicken noodle soup with hoisin sauce." ....uh...and I responded, "so...uh...are you not going to give it to me?" To my surprise, he responds, "*shakes head* No." with those robotic expressionless faces. I honestly didn't know how to respond and so I just responded in the typical dumbfounded way, "uh......ummm...ok..." and he walks away.

...wth??? I honestly still don't know what to make of this, but I was very upset. Did he really restrict me in the way I want to eat my dish? Maybe it isn't the "authentic way" of eating the vietnamese chicken noodle soup, but I like it with hoisin sauce because that's just how I like it. Telling a customer how they should eat a certain dish is the worst. I've tried the dish the authentic way. it tastes good. and now, I want my hoisin sauce.

If the restaurant is so anal about people eating their food the "authentic way," then they should put a note in the menu in advance. 

Suffice to say I won't be coming back here because of the service. I don't care if the food is fantastic. If the service is like this, count me out. 

If it weren't for the food, I would've given only one star.
author: Pamela P.

description:
Out of all the locations, this one has the best flavors. Mainly cuz this is the original location. 

We always get the #9 w/ dark meat, no skin and add liver. BOMB whether it's a hot or cold day. Speaking of which, that's another perk - you can specify which type of meat you want without being charged extra. 

Egg rolls are also one of the best. They're not your typical egg rolls w/ hella taro and skin. These are super light, crunchy and delish. You gotta get 'em.
author: Julie L.

description:
Cash only- 
Waited for my table for 45 minutes during busy lunch.
Waited to be served for 20 minutes. 
Waited for my food for 30 minutes, only got half, got the other half in another 30 minutes.
Ain't nobody got time

The patè in the sandwich smelled of and tasted like what I imagine was cat food. Soup was small and expensive for the insignificant amount of meat I got.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Cleaned up location with new tables.  Not the same as the old place.  
Served the pho with lemons, not limes this time.     
I really like limes with pho, the way I'd had it at the previous location.
Broth was still very good. 
Sad that the Tenderloin area where this place is an awful section of SF.  Really a shame.  Go during the day and be safe.
author: Kev M.

description:
I get a small rare beef pho with extra onions about once a week from here.

It is intrinsic to my happiness.

Love the staff. 

Go to Lee's next door and get a Chinese donut to dip in your soup.

Pho ga is great too but generally reserve it for when I have a cold.

This is northern style, there are no herbs or hoisin.

Add a little fish sauce, some of the jalapenos, and a bit of lime or vinegar.  Put your face over the bowl and take a deep breath.
author: Peter M.

description: I went here recently for lunch and the place was pretty empty. We were seated quickly and I ended up ordering Bún Ch Hà Ni (#12 on the menu). It is "Grilled Pork Patty & Sliced Pork with Vermicelli Noodle, Lettuce, Mint and Cilantro." The grilled pork patties were served in a bowl topped with pickled veggies. They were very flavored and delicious. In fact, I probably would have preferred to have eaten the dish with rice instead of vermicelli noodles. Anyway, the dish didn't need any other condiments like fish sauce which I appreciated. The dish was good on it's own and was very fulfilling. If you're not looking to eat any of their pho dishes, try this one!
author: Krystal C.

description:
The Turtle is a subtle place.  I would never have elected to go here on my own just from viewing it from the outside.  Two friends toured me through the area (which is lovely if you like open heroine use) before heading into the Turtle. 

I was a smidge disappointed to learn they do not in fact serve Turtle.  In fact, no turtles in site.  A tank of turtles I think would have been appropriate but the decorations were sparse and simple.  So I appreciate there low maintenance interior design that strips the frills that I'm used to seeing at more authentic places such as PF Changs.

The food was exotic.  But it was good.  If you are not a fish eater, this place is not for you.  I found the one thing on the menu that lacked a fish component - pork over rice.  It somehow came with a fried egg over it - that was perplexing, but I simply immediately shoved it to the side and the problem was solved. 

Service was great and it was quick as could be.
author: Joel Z.

description:
*sees 20+ people bitching about lack of garnishes, condiments, and noodles in their pho*

. . . 

Looks like some of us should go educate ourselves on the differences between the Southern style pho (the pho that most people are probably familiar with and perhaps think is the ONLY kind, hah) and the Northern style, Hanoi "the original" pho before come in dissing and spewing shit...

Turtle Tower does pho bac pretty well. Nothing is wrong or bad about this style of pho. It's just different from Saigon pho. The key element of pho bac is simplicity. Yes, the broth IS supposed to taste like that. No, there really aren't many garnishes, just lots of scallions and sliced green chile (soaked in vinegar?) if anything. And no, this version of pho does NOT call for Hoisin sauce and all that shebang. All you need for this pho is some fish sauce, vinegar, and a squirt of lemon/lime which are all provided at the table/brought by the server. And lastly, there's nothing messed up about the noodles, it's supposed to be flat and wide like that! 

Overall I had a very enjoyable experience. I like the new location much better. The servers were attentive and made sure my teacup was filled.

My dining companion had an order of spring rolls and a beef stir-fry noodle dish and he enjoyed his meal as well.

Turtle Tower is pretty damn cheap considering their portions. They do take credit cards now. I will definitely be back to try their Chicken noodle soup, the egg yolk soda and other dishes they had to offer. I'm so sold!

This establishment is pretty much the only reason for me to foray into Tenderloin, lol.
author: Clare Y.

description:
Pretty good Pho and at a good price. I got the small and I could barely finish it. Well I don't have a big apetite but still. The large is huge and only for 9 bucks. 

Tried the chicken pho and the vietnamese iced coffee. Both were pretty good. They don't take reservations. But walk-ins don't have much of a wait. We were a party of 5 and arrive and noon and were immediately seated.
author: Priyanka P.

description:
It must have been 3 years since I last ate at Turtle Tower. The last location was a corner shop that was dingy and old but has that hole-in-the-wall feel I really like. The food was amazing, I fondly remembered. Great noodles and most of all, subtle delicate broth for its pho ga.

This time around I was less impressed, almost disappointed. The decor was more polished and the service was unbelievably friendly. They still serve the best and softest noodles but the chicken pho was not the same. I tasted an intense MSG-like flavour that left me wanting more ... water that is. I could still taste the chicken in there but why not let it shine instead of the MSG saltiness?

I crave the subtlety of the broth that I had three years ago. I hope they didn't change the recipe to appease customers who complained about the broth being bland. Please bring the old broth back.

Note: Vegetarians might want to consider other places as there is a lack of options for you.
author: Kwoky L.

description:
My sister bought a groupon offer ($18) for this place. She purchased it at 11am, and we were there at 11:45am :) 
She kept telling me there would be a line. We should go as early as possible. I didn't believe her, but she was right! There was a line! It wasn't too bad. We put our name down. Waited for about 15 minutes. So, we just checked out some places around there. 
The groupon was for $23 lunch, which includes 2 entrees (up to $9 value each) and 2 drinks (up to $3.50 value each). So, we got 2 large pho ga (the chicken noodle soup that most yelpers recommend) and 2 iced Vietnamese coffee. 1 large pho ga is $8.25 while the Vietnamese coffee is $3.25. The prices are not bad at all. 
The noodle they use (at least in the pho we ordered) is the flat rice noodle, not the wide one though. A narrower version. We both loved the noodle. The broth was pretty good and tasty too. They put a lot of chopped spring onion and cilantro in it. As for the chicken, it's the steamed pieces of chicken with skin on it. We both are never a fan of chicken with skin, so we picked out the skin. The chicken meat itself is not bad. 
The pho comes with slices of lemon and sliced jalapeños. No bean sprout, basil, or anything else (just like what they mention on their menu). 
Now, the Vietnamese coffee is not bad at all. The coffee is pretty strong. I had been awake all day. So, be careful if you have it for dinner. The coffee is serious :)
As for the staff, the waiters are pretty nice. There's a guy who handles the name list and take people to their table. I am not sure if that's the owner or a manager, but he is a serious guy. He didn't really smile, but he did say 'thank you' when we left. 
Our bill came out to be a dollar something (yeah, the tax). 
Try this place out at least once and be the judge for their pho ga :)
author: Ervi L.

description:
I'm a Sacramento native and I understand that SF Vietnamese food is not the greatest, but this place just sucks balls. I'm Vietnamese myself and have come here twice for pho. My first visit, I would give the place 2 stars and on my second visit (which is the one that I am rating), 1 star it is. I ordered the Pho Ga with the gizzards and eggs on both comings. On my second visit, I ate about 1/3 of my bowl and then I noticed that there were a bunch of small pieces of hair in my pho. So I showed the waiter and they took my bowl, and he came back and had told me that, "Oh your bowl has hair in it because you ordered the chicken pho with the skin, next time say you want no skin." I giggled in my head because this guy must be retarded. First of all, chicken have feathers, and second, that still isn't an excuse to have about 20 pieces of hair in my bowl. Everyone at my table lost their appetite after seeing the pieces of hair in my bowl and stopped eating.

I would rate the food a 1.5/5. Giving them 1 star because of the hair and their lame excuse. Would give them 0 if I could.

Oh and don't try the pho place next door to them other, I tried the pho there, and it tastes even worse than here. Do yourself a favor and drive to San Jose or just go get some clam chowder.
author: My T.

description: Nasty, flavorless, bland, and there was a bug on one of my friend's greens. When we showed our waiter the bug he said oh and cleaned the table. No I'm sorry or even offer to comp that meal. This place is lame and I have no idea why it's so popular. Never again as there are much better spots next door.
author: Matthew B.

description:
Wow turtle tower finally got a face lift. It feels kinda uncomfortably clean and fancy now haha. The pho is still delicious and the perfect hangover food. The place is bigger now with the same delicious menu. It really is the best chicken pho I ever had. 

Two thumbs up!
author: Cynthia C.

description: Ordered the chicken noodle soup. The soup is good but hardly any meat. The 3 color drink is not fresh with a funny taste. We won't come back
author: Ying C.

description: i can't believe after all these years, i've never written a review for turtle tower.  what do i need to say about the chicken pho that hasn't been said already.  it really hits the spot on a rainy day!  my friend called to order it, and it was ready by the time i got there to pick it up.  service here is quick and friendly.
author: Helen T.

description:
Nothing beats a hot bowl of pho ga on a dreary grey day!  The last time I dined here was at the old location, but I recently visited the new restaurant after buying a Groupon deal ($18 for two bowls of noodles and two drinks). My friend and I ordered the pho ga and an iced coffee. The broth is amazing! You won't even miss the sriracha and basil, and I love sriracha and basil. The regular bowl is just right, but I probably could've gone for the large.

The waitlist moved quickly and service was efficient. The new space is roomy and clean. Definitely recommend!
author: Bella L.

description:
Came here on a Saturday for a "late lunch" with two other friends. We ordered the chicken pho as well as the beef brisket and rare beef pho. I've heard many great reviews about this place and.. soo.. ordering the chicken pho was a must. When the food came, I immediately started to devour the chicken pho and I must've been super hungry at the time but it was defs appetizing. The beef pho was aight too. We also ordered two Vietnamese coffees to share, both of which were really strong, but.. no complaints here!

If I was in the city and was craving chicken pho, I would defs try to make it back to TT.
author: Krystal O.

description:
Northern style pho, aka chicken pho.

Solid chicken broth (if its too salty, squeeze in a lime!), wide rice noodles (but you can get egg noodles if you'd like), big portions.

Cash only!
author: Andy J.

description:
This place is literally as good as it gets. Amazing quality, fast service, cheap price, and the wait staff have such great attitudes! The only thing that I can complain about is their actual hours of operations, 8 am to 5 pm, which makes it difficult for me to come here more often! Despite this huge, first world problem that I have, I still make an effort to visit weekly. It's now my Sunday tradition, instead of a a Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, addiction.

I've tried both their chicken and beef pho, and while sometimes I crave a heavier taste, their chicken pho is by far the best on the menu. It's loaded with cilantro, shredded chicken, and a fantastically light yet flavorful chicken broth. It's the epitome of what chicken noodle soup should be. I'd almost feign a cold just to eat it everyday. 

I'm one of those people who really enjoy a restaurant that does a simple food perfectly. No fuss, great service, I'm going to be a regular here.

Oh, and I almost forgot to mention, you obviously also need a Vietnamese coffee while you're here! Best part - they always give me a to-go cup for my coffee so I can take it and drink it after I eat :)
author: Emmie Y.

description: Seems pretty good. Got the chicken broth soup and it was pretty good. Would like to return to try other dishes
author: Silver T.

description:
Love this place.
I get their #9 chicken noodle soup with lemon sauce on the side.
their spring rolls are pretty yum too.

I also tried the pork with rice which was also not bad.
author: Heejin L.

description:
Quick service and good Pho. Their small is definitely filling and large enough for a solo. The fresh coconut juice is AHUMAZING!! Its refreshing with large chunks of coconut in it, so it comes with a spoon you usually get for ice cream sundaes so you can scoop out the chunky coconut. Id come back just for that! 

Pho Ga was good- I would like more veggies next time.

Cash only!
author: Manu M.

description:
We discovered this place is a northern style
Pho restaurant after asking for pickled onions and hoison sauce which they did not have. So just FYI = no bean sprouts, thicker noodles, no hoison sauce. Still yummy!
author: Monica M.

description:
Delicious pho! I've eaten pho many times and have always ordered it with beef broth. This time, I went for the pho ga (chicken). The broth was delicious and the chicken was oh so tender. SO good that I will be ordering pho ga instead of beef in the future. I'm sold!

The spring rolls were just OK, and the fish cakes were dry (overcooked?). Stick with the pho and you will leave happy :)
author: Jen Z.

description: My husband likes the pho very much but I think it tastes ok. Just remember not to order the cuttlefish cake. It  costs $5 for a size of a butterfly shrimp. I felt it was a ripped off. And for the egg rolls, it costs $2.95 for one egg roll that is like a size of your finger.
author: Kitty S.

description:
The constant tug and pull in the battle for noodle soup dominance occurs every time I sit down to a good bowl of one. Whether it's a laksa, duck leg and wonton noodle, or tsukune ramen, I'm always torn as to which flavor and texture profile I adore more.  Then I eat turtle Towers pho ga. Over. Done. Vietnamese rules supreme in my humble overweight decision. 

Prepared in the northern tradition with none of those accoutrements (hoisin, sambal, cilantro and basil). Just chicken (moist and tender), broth (clear and grease free) and noodles (house made). You can order some ginger and fish sauce to dip your chicken in but that's it. Just clean flavors. 

The call.  I get a bowl of the chicken noodle soup with no skin and a plate of the sweet sticky rice with more chicken, Chinese sausage and two fried eggs. Dope. Whatever broth that is left in the bowl can be used to add the sticky rice to. Get it all in your mouth just like your in Hanoi, except with more crackheads. 

That's the thing about "Little Saigon" in SF.  It's nasty. Two maybe three blocks of an area that has no cultural significance to its namesake other then being "little" and having the best Vietnamese restaurants in the city (bodega bistro, new mi hai ky, pagolac). 

True Saigon/HCM city is pretty stanky in some parts, but not Larkin and Ellis stanky.  Oh the things we do for a cheap bowl of amazing. Just mind the human fecal matter.
author: Chris K.

description:
There's always a wait whenever we're here. One thing I noticed is the pho ga broth is inconsistent, one day the flavors were on point. The broth flavors were perfect as there was no need to add spice to balance out the flavors. Everything worked perfectly. However, the next day or two, we went back and the broth flavors were a little bland. I was disappointed. On the other hand, the chicken with my soup was very moist and fresh. 

The customer service was good. Cash only.
author: Ames D.

description:
This new location opened up 1 year ago.  It's still on Larkin but it's more modern. Hours are 8am-5pm.  

Totally love the broth for the Pho Ga. Cured my aching stomach
author: Jboogie L.

description: I honestly don't understand how this restaurant is Zagat rated and the reviews are so good from past customers claiming the best pho?? Food should be rated for the style of cuisine and this was epic fail. We were misguided by the ratings so imagine the disappointment when some sort of chicken noodle soup was placed in front of us. This was a bad imitation and nowhere close to Vietnamese Pho. I know because this is my nationality. I grew up with it and make it often for my family. This was chicken stock lacking pho seasonings and the chicken was gamey or old. Even worse, you SHOULD NEVER serve pho without hoisin sauce, bean sprouts, and Vietnamese basil. Clean establishment and the food doesnt taste bad, if you're not looking for authentic food.
author: Terry C.

description:
This place was interesting. I came here with a friend thinking it was a typical pho place that is talked about a lot. After eating here, I don't feel like what they call "pho" was really pho. The broth, the noodles and the veggies for the pho were all different from typical pho. However, it was pretty good! More like a fusion or a spin off of pho.

I ordered a rare beef, flank and brisket pho, however, looking around the place it seems most people come here for pho ga (chicken pho). I will definitely come back sometime to try that instead. I also got the egg rolls and they were TINY and nothing special. I would skip on that.

The service was pretty slow for a vietnamese restaurant, they seem to be very busy and a bit short on staff? Not atypical to other vietnamese restaurants I guess.

Overall a decent place to eat, I will have to come back to try a few other things on their menu.
author: Seliya G.

description: their rare beef soup is awesome. Drank up all the soup
author: Lanxing L.

description:
Best pho in the city. I didn't think I liked Vietnamese food in general, and then Turtle Tower opened near my work. I love everything I've tried. This is Northern Vietnamese food "Hanoi style." Instead of basil, expect cilantro. Instead of bean sprouts, expect carrots, celery, and leeks. 

The difference in their pho as compared to most others I've had is night and day. The pale, clear broth is misleading. It packs an umami wallop without the lightness or sweetness of southern-style pho. For me, this is a plus but some might find it greasy or salty tasting if you're used to the usual pho out there. All the pho dishes come with lime and jalapeno on the side, which balance the umami flavors perfectly.

They're rightfully known for their Ph Gà (chicken noodle soup - #9) but I am an ardent fan of the beef pho dishes, particularly the Ph Bò Áp Cho Nc (#6), which features stir fried beef and pan-fried noodles. This adds even MORE umami punch, so beware! 

Don't come here for the ambiance - this is about the food. And I like picking it up to go and assembling the soup at home. A large pho lasts for two entire meals for one person easily. A DEAL!
author: Brooke B.

description:
I was really excited to check this place out after all the hype I'd heard about it. I'm sad to say that it didn't live up to the hype, though part of it may be my fault on choosing the wrong item on the menu...

Environment: 4/5
The restaurant is pretty clean for a Vietnamese restaurant. The neighborhood is sketchy, but you gotta get through the Tenderloin to get some of the better Viet food in SF!

Food: 3/5
Instead of ordering the famous pho ga, I ordered the beef option. It was very different from other pho restaurants I've had. There weren't any bean sprouts, the soup was more bland, and the noodles weren't the "perfect texture" of soft chewiness pho enthusiasts are used to. It wasn't cheap either--$10 or $11 for just a bowl of pho after tax and tip. Just a great disappointment overall.

Service: 4/5
Nothing out of the ordinary. They weren't especially quick or friendly, but that's not too abnormal at a Vietnamese joint.

I'll be back for the pho ga one day, but I'll never come back for the beef option!
author: Joseph T.

description:
Love their chicken noodle soup with giblets aka Pho Ga Long. If it's your first time, I don't recommend ordering anything else! You can skip on the giblets though, if that's not your thing. 

The pho here is Northern Vietnamese style pho, so the broth is more clear and has a thinner consistency. I love that their chicken pho comes with steamed chicken by default, whereas most other places only give you dry white meat chicken. I also love the thick noodles they use. 

My only complaint:
I wish they provided a dish full of herbs we could add to our pho (i.e. mint leaves, bean sprouts, etc.) This is the only pho restaurant I've ever been to that does not provide this, which makes me think the pho here must have some major Chinese influence. Also, true Northern Vietnamese chicken pho should come with a small bowl of fish sauce/ginger/chili dip, so you can dip your chicken, but they don't do that here either. 

Nonetheless, the pho here is still great. And it is my go-to breakfast joint after a night of drinking if I'm in SF.
author: Linda N.

description: Visiting from New York, and all my previous conceptions of pho have went to shit, and nothing will be the same. Tried their pho ga, which the personable waiter said is their signature dish, and the food here is Hanoi style. The small was definitely plenty, the flavors filling and savory but clean and light, noodles were thick, chicken and herbs were impeccably fresh to the bite.  Charming interior with ample space. Will definitely visit whenever I drop by SF.
author: Sarah L.

description:
The beef red wine stew was 75% fat and other unidentifiable beef parts, hardly any real meat. Gross.

Rude service. If I hold out my hand to recieve my change, don't set it on the counter and then look at me like o.O.  Also noticed the workers huddled together and smack talked about patrons within earshot. Had 4 different ppl ask to take my order within one minute, but no one to refill my empty water cup until I flagged someone down.
author: Neeners H.

description:
I've never been let down more in my life.. Seriously.. what kind of name is Turtle Tower? ....

...

...

a FUN one! I've been bugging people for several weeks now to try to get them to take me to Turtle Tower. Seriously.. just say it to yourself... Turtle Tower... Turtle Tower... Turtle Tower!! Say it in an obnoxious voice! Annoy your friends with it! Turtle Tower... One star for the fun name.

The other star is for the cheap prices. I think it's about $6 for a small bowl. That price would not fly in Socal/Westminster/Garden Grove/Viet Central... but for San Francisco? It's amazing... You can fill yourself up for about $6?? Heck yeah!

The food itself was not that great. Maybe it's overhyped.. maybe it's overrated... Who knows. All I know is that I didn't like it. I've had better Chicken Pho in places that didn't specialize in Chicken Pho. The broth is really salty too. It's great if you love salt. But I'd skip it. 

I had to walk 15 minutes in the rain in the Tenderloin (EEEEK) to get to this place. I had to dodge all these crazy people just to finally satiate my turtle tower bone. I was soaking wet by the time I got to the restaurant.

And.. I am only sorry that I had to drag my friend through that crazy mess to taste salty mediocre food...

So sorry....

I will never be bothering my friends by saying the word Turtle Tower again...
author: Stephanie W.

description: I am giving this place 5 stars based solely on their chicken soup pho. The broth is very tasty and seems like it took a while to make. Best thing to cure you after a night of debauchery. ;)
author: Lasha O.

description:
Severely overrated. I have never waited in line for Pho before and this time I wanted to try out turtle tower. The wait was about 20-30 minutes and the service was quite speedy. Waiter had no attitude but no vigor to help out. 

Food was was a meh. The pho noodles is the best Ive ever had but the broth was bland and the meat smelled old and of wet towel. The place was quite clean with several TVs to watch. Also i hate street parking.

Everything was ehhhh. Nothing special at all. I don't know why they have had the praises for so long
author: Peter T.

description:
Crap service..  

if you want to feel like a step child while eating here.
author: Taye N.

description:
The server said he couldn't finish a small bowl of pho, but the large left me hungry.  I'm not a fan of being outside in the Civic Center area, but I came in for lunch with some coworkers.  The new place is nice.  It's clean, big, and well lit.  Oddly enough, a new pho place opened in the old location down the block.  

I got the beef stew noodles, and I got maybe 5 pieces of meat.  Maybe it's just me, but I definitely could've gone for two large bowls.  Do people these days just not eat?!  The donut shop down the street saved me after this.
author: ROB L.

description: Long waits for this place and it isn't even amazing. It's more northern style vietnamese pho where they don't offer hoise  sauce. The pho was ok. I expected more for the wait. Also I enjoy going to a vietnamese restaurant where I can speak vietnamese to the staff but apparently everyone there was chinese.
author: Nam V.

description: Pho is great. Needless to say they get busy. This is a very popular pho joint and I am one of their repeat customers. Service is fast and friendly. Busy during lunch time. Fresh spring roll is also my personal favorite. Quick tip: Chicken pho is especially great for when you are sick. You'll be feeling great in no time.
author: J C.

description:
Atmosphere: 3.5 stars, your typical pho place, but probably a little cleaner than others.

Food: 5 stars. Best chicken pho (pho ga) there is.
-Pho ga (chicken pho): when I go get pho, I always, always get pho with rare steak + beef balls....except at Turtle Tower. You can't come to Turtle Tower and not try the Pho Ga. The chicken is tender, and the broth is sooo flavourful without being too salty. The noodles are different from the thin noodles you get at most other pho places; instead, they're thicker, but every bit as delicious--perhaps more, even!
-Imperial rolls: standard/typical fried egg rolls
-Spring rolls: mediocre, wouldn't really order it again

Service: 4 stars. Surprisingly enough, the service here is really good. The waiters are always attentive, and I've never had to wait very long for anything.

Price: 4 stars. It's pho, so of course it's cheap. Cash only though!

Parking: 3 stars. Street parking in SF, 'nough said.

Overall: 5 stars! Definitely my go-to spot for pho when I'm in need of a hangover cure :)

Pro tip: for coffee buffs, Philz is also right around the corner :) Unlike some other restaurants, Turtle Tower doesn't care if you bring in outside drinks.
author: Krystal M.

description: This place used to be my "go to" place for Ha Noi style pho! I haven't been here for ages, but my friend placed a big order to go! Overall, the noodles were enjoyable.  However, the broth was quite oily, and it was difficult to slurp it all up! They did a good job at packaging everything to-go though!
author: Tramy V.

description: Had this pho like noodle dish which had stir fried beef as the topping... yeah stir-fried beef noodle soup... blew my mind away when accompanied with cuttlefish  fritters.  Can't wait to go back
author: James L.

description: Oh turtle tower you never disappoint! I got my regular #10 with extra peppers on the side and Vietnamese coffee. My only complaint is the wait is really long even at 1:30pm, but it is worth it. Love you turtle tower!! :)
author: Steph D.

description:
I have been going to Turtle Tower for about 9 years. Turtle tower is small family owned business and locally raised here in SF, at least their children have been. They have done very well for themselves providing authentic Ha Noi style or Northern style pho in San Francisco. No basil, no bean sprouts, no jokes. Northern style is all about the clear clean broth and thicker fresh cut noodles. I believe to be far superior to southern style pho, which often has far too much going on with the broth and all the add ins. TT is amazing and unique in a city full with southern pho. I'm so happy that the family has been doing so well that they are opening up multiple restaurants with the same quality food in different parts of the city for all to enjoy. 

As far as customer service, it just depends on who is working. Usually everyone who works at their restaurants speaks English as their second language, so they are often not Chatty Cathy and have different cultural customs of how much they like to "talk to the customers." Once you start going in and becoming a familiar face they start to remember your order, ask how you are, and become more comfortable asking questions and "providing customer services." No one is ever rude I think just shy around language barriers. Anyhow, BRING ME THE BEST PHO IN TOWN, TT FOR SURE!
author: .Strapped ..

description:
Excellent Northern style pho.  If you're used to the Southern style, the lack of sprouts and basil leaves is a little disconcerting.  But the broth is so good, you'll forget about that.  They also serve some rice dishes, but I don't see why anyone would go to Turtle Tower for a rice dish. 

The service is very efficient, though not particularly friendly.  You'll want to try to go either before or after the lunch rush, otherwise you may have to wait for a table. 

The new building is a vast improvement over the old one.  But the neighborhood is just as sketchy as ever.
author: Robert L.

description:
I should really just listen to my friend, Susy C. HAHAHA - never...

This place is different from other pho places. Noodles are thicker and wider. There are no additional vegetables to add into the soup. The broth is killer.

Killer.

As people have mentioned, this is probably the best chicken pho I have ever eaten.

Place looks cleaner, which I hate. I want to eat in a hole-in-the-wall place. Alas, gentrification.
author: Jason S.

description: Obviously the chicken noodle soup is the thing to get here. Beef pho is good too; everything else is kind of overpriced and you can get better vermicelli, bahn mi, spring rolls etc elsewhere for less. That said, the pho ga is very legit. It's all about simple, clean flavors. Keep in mind that this is north Vietnamese, so you don't get all the fixins you may be used to with the more typical southern style pho.
author: Chumley S.

description: I think the northern Vietnam approach is sorta of a cop out. I just got back from Vietnam, and the northern pho soups are served in small bowls with sweet, small citrus. The bowls we get here are big, like in the south, but still lack of basil and any veggies. Seems like more of a cost-saving tactic then an take on authentic soup. It's quite annoying really. The flavor is good, but as this is turning into a chain, I'll go elsewhere and support smaller, more generous folks.
author: Brian J.

description:
Traditional northern style Vietnamese pho, but the owners are stingy on the innards.
Also, they stopped serving chicken egg in the pho ga.  But for the virgin pho foodie, they will probably love it.
author: Xu D.

description:
Love this place! For some reason out of all the TT's in the city this one is by far my favorite! 

Food is delicious and always consistent. Service is great. And it's the perfect meal for SF weather all year round!
author: Kristen C.

description:
I think they should pay me for direct marketing  or some kind of royalties for every friend I bring there. LOVE it so much that my friends think I have an addiction. 
But only this location is the best, others not so much...
author: Zarina M.

description:
The new location is a lot more spacious and modern, thus attracts more tourists. I actually miss the old hole in a wall location where I can literally roll out of bed and head straight here for a nice piping hot bowl of chicken pho with giblets. I'm in and out in less than 30 min and it was my best hangover remedy. 

But thank god the pho broth here is still amazing...clear and light but packed with fresh flavors and topped with lots of green onions and cilantro.  This is the one and only place where I will slurp up all the broth to the last drop and eat the chicken skin from the chicken.  Yes it's that fresh and good! 

Northern style pho so it's served with fresh wide (ho fun) noodles. But I do keep my fingers crossed and hope that it's not overcooked.  No hoisin or siracha--use the fish sauce and sliced peppers provided. 

The beef noodle soup is also good. They use hand sliced beef and pound it so it's very tender and juicy. Try it if you want something diff :)
author: Cathy M.

description:
I nearly cried when I took my first sip of pho ga. I was jet-lagged, cold-sick, and a little home-sick, but this pho - this pho tasted just like home. 

 Yelp and others have led me astray on pho, but this has my wholehearted Vietnamese stamp of approval. It's rare to find a place (even in Westminster!) that excels at both chicken and beef pho, so I'd give them 6 stars if I could.
author: Lan T.

description:
Must have had a staff meeting about customer service but TT is no longer a . Order.eat.pay.leave place!

They ask about how your meal is, refill your water, give you napkins(I KNOW)

yay! I'm so much happier..I use to bite my tongue about the customer because the Pho was so good, but now it's a win win!!
author: Selina W.

description: Beautiful new space for Turtle Tower.  What an improvement.  The pho ga is still superb.  A small bowl is large.  A large bowl is massive...
author: Bleep S.

description: This location is pretty big, with a upstairs and downstairs, yet the line still gets long, so come early to beat the lunch crowd! Since it's still fairly new, it's very clean. As always, the #9 pho ga hits the spot. It is simply delicious. I also appreciate that they de-seed the green peppers. The pepper and lemon add-ins are always fresh. The broth is always clear. The noodles are always silky. The chicken is always tender. Their banh mi was tasty also. You choose three fillings per sandwich and they are generous with the pate, but overall, the sandwich is not very stuffed. Service moves briskly.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
OH MY GUT! 
SO GOOOOT!

I'm from Seattle and we have plenty of Vietnamese/Pho restuarants but nothing compares to the Pho Ga (chicken) from Turtle Tower. 

Oh...yes... those fat perfect noodles, the broth and chicken... I wish they can just live in my belly forever and never digest.... heh... but for real...it was very satisfying. 

I even liked it better than my mom's Pho Ga (don't tell her I said that).
author: Amy L.

description: Their chicken noodle soup is always my go to for comfort food!! decent portion and the soup is very flavorful, not to mention their chicken is really fresh. the only down side is cash only, and no close atm around so be sure to have you cash ready.
author: Monica L.

description: Don't normally like pho that much but I got the pho ga here and it was delicious! Perfect comfort food for a blustery day. Imperial roll was not that good though... could do without next time
author: Amanda L.

description:
The widely-acclaimed Pho Ga was tasty, but for those of you who know how to make chicken soup from scratch, you won't be as impressed. It's a good soupy meal for a cold rainy day. But nothing to write home about. 

The imperial rolls were small and $2.25 each, shikes!

The service was fast and friendly. That's certainly a plus. 

Cash only.
author: Min L.

description:
Delicious spring roles for a better price than I've seen at other Vietnamese joints- $5.25 for 4 shrimp/roast pork rolls. 

I went with the sandwich...not a bad choice especially given the inexpensiveness; however, it's never easy to pass up on a nice bowl of pho, which looked fantastically pho-y. 

Only negative was the staff failed to return our change assuming the leftover was tip (which it was, but c'mon). Remember cash only!
author: Max R.

description:
I really don't know how I went the past 4 years living in San Francisco without trying out Turtle Tower. The moment I tried the pho here, I immediately understood what everyone was raving about with regards to this restaurant. 

The broth is flavorful, light and soothing. Perfect for after a night of drinking. The ingredients taste fresh. What's interesting is that this restaurant is different from other pho restaurants in that it carries after the Northern tradition. No soy sauce or hoison sauce for dipping the meat but siratcha sauce. Also, the meat is slightly different but tasty.

I recommend the pho ga or chicken pho. The regular pho sach is good too. 

The spring rolls here are standard and not any better than your regular restaurant. 

Be prepared for a wait on the weekends. Everyone loves this spot so you can expect 20-30 minute wait sometimes when it's busy.
author: Tran N.

description: I have been going here for pho for a long time. It was my goto place for pho.  Have not been there for a while due to work.  Was in the area a month ago. Dropped by for a bowl of beef pho.   It was terrible   The broth was bland and no flavor.  Tasted just like water.  So disappointed.  So went back home and told my friend about it.  So we decided to go there again to prove it to my friend that it was like water.   We went earlier this week.  I ordered a chicken pho this time and my friend ordered the beef pho.  My chicken pho was no better, no flavor and again like water.  My friend did not finish her pho.  She couldn't eat it.  It's NOT Pho.  The noodles are over cooked and super soft.  The same owners were there so I think they changed it by design. What a shame.  Compromised the food to make extra profit.  They definitely cheapened the pho.  They are stepping over a dollar to make an extra penny   We will never come back.  Now they are the worst pho place in the Bay Area.   Good job!
author: Hank C.

description: We think that this is one of the best pho restaurants in San Francisco. It's especially good for the chicken pho. The menu is super simple which tells you that they know exactly what they're good at and that they're not trying to be something other than what they are. Expect super nutritious broth.
author: Chad H.

description: Food is 4 stars (chicken pho only), service is horrible and my fried chicken leg rice plate was so dry, it probably tasted like chicken jerky.
author: Christopher L.

description: Great value, great good, clean/open dining space. Service is on point as well. Can't go wrong at Turtle Tower - whether for breakfast, lunch or dinner.
author: Seth S.

description:
Warning: The 5 star rating is based solely off of Pho Ga (ChickenPho #9) and Pho Ga only!!!  Readers discretions has been advised. LOL.

Turtle Tower is my goto favorite restaurant for Chicken Pho aka Pho Ga, in San Francisco.  What I love about Turtle Tower is their broth, it's so tasty.  TT is one of the few places where I know I don't have to mess with the flavor of the soup (usually by adding fish sauce, sirancha/oyster sauce, salt, etc...).  

I'm sure they have some added preservatives (msg) in their soup, to make it extra yummy, but whatever... name one pho joint that you know of that doesn't use msg?  I love their noodles too, thick small rice noodles.  I believe the family that runs TT informed me that their noodles soup are served like in the northern part of Vietnam (Hanoi).  

I've also had their rice plates and other noodle soups but they are okay (average).  What's going to stand out, and what TT is best known for, is the Pho Ga (#9, #10 if you like chicken giblets).  Stick with the game plan and save the other stuff on the menu for another visit.  Otherwise you're going to end up giving TT a low rating of 1 or 2... which I've seen some yelpers do already, smh.
author: yusai g.

description:
We found this place after discovering the place we were looking for was closed. Situated in a part of the city where there a quite a few pho restaurants, this was one of the ones that happens to be open on Sunday. We were able to find metered parking that required about a 2 minute walk to the restaurant. 

Service was prompt and friendly. We were greeted and seated quickly and our orders were taken just as fast. We got here just before closing time and didn't leave until after the restaurant closed and staff was friendly the entire time, never rushing us as some restaurants will do in similar situations. We came here to eat pho ordered accordingly. I ordered a beef and my wife ordered chicken. We were given the choice of a few different types of noodles and we both chose rice noodles.

While waiting for my pho to come I squeezed in a few yelp reviews which is when I learned their pho was different than most as it is "Northern Vietnam" style. This got me excited as almost every pho I have tried up to this point has been essentially the same.
When my dish came it didn't come with basil, cilantro, or sprouts on the side. In fact, nothing came on the side. This was the 2nd time I experienced this in SF. The rice noodles that came with it were the flat variety which is different than the round type that I'm used to.  The broth was light and had a nice flavor to it.  It wasn't overly salty, fatty, or loaded with MSG but it did lack in depth of flavor. What I really liked was the rare beef that was served with my pho which was extremely tender, was served as one large piece on top of my soup, and appeared to have a texture as if it had been pounded with a meat hammer. The other slices of well-done beef were equally tender and tasty as well.

All in all, the pho here was different and even though it was good it wasn't so good that I'd come back here again. The main reason for this is because I do not live in the city and there are quite a few other pho places that look good in SF that I still want to try so I will most likely be giving one of those places my business if and when I return.
author: Alan T.

description: After a night of Jack Daniels and dancing, this place is a Godsend. Usual patrons include everyone's favorite viet grandpa, your tendernob yuppsters, and your usual San Francisco Asians, myself included. The broth is perfectly seasoned. I've had both the chicken ga, and the beef and Am completely satisfied with both. The noodles are the flat rice noodle, not the typical vermicelli. It's simple and to the point. Hangover cure!!! A different style of Pho from what most Pho goers are used to. They don't believe in Hoisin sauce and with their broth, that's perfectly fine. Sure it's on a sketchy part of Larkin, but it's sooooo worth it.
author: Jen M.

description: Quality went down hill. The once fragrant soup,  which was the soul of the noodle soup is now boring and plain and similar to its outer Richmond twin. This bowl of noodle just goes through the motions of pho GA,  a shadow of what it once was. I guess the plus side is now they accept credit card.
author: Lars B.

description: Maybe we're spoiled when it comes to Vietnamese food, but pho here did not impress both of us. The flavors are not very strong, mine mostly had a burnt flavor. The waiter was very nice, but the food did not satisfy at all. I don't think we'll be coming back and will have to keep looking for better pho experience in SF.
author: Olga A.

description:
I gotta come to this place at least a few times a month.  #9 Pho-Ga is amazing, the noodles are soft, broth doesn't need too much added to it.  

Most Pho joints require me to douse the entire bowl in Sriracha and Hosin sauce to add taste to it but here I eat it straight up and it never disappoints.  Cash only though so keep that in mind.
author: Eric C.

description:
Perfection and by that i mean Pho Ga. 
This is no thrill, no frill kinda place.
You sit down on a plain table, you look outside the lovely tenderloin neighborhood, order your food within 5 min of sitting down, eat for 15 min, get your check and leave. 

It;s the kind of food you crave when you miss home, when you want something that not only satisfies one's palate but the soul. You don't ask for special sauces or adjustments to perfection. You order what they have and you will enjoy every morsel and mouthful of the perfected chicken pho that they are known for here.
author: Youna K.

description:
645 Larkin St. is the new location for the old Turtle Tower Restaurant.  It is on the same block, just a few buildings down.  The new spot is beautiful, with a very warm atmosphere.  They have seating downstairs for small parties of 4 or less and upstairs for bigger parties.  

The food, of course, is as good as ever!!  I always get the number 10, chicken pho with giblets.  You can also add a side of beef to the chicken pho, and it makes it a lot better.  Their fried egg rolls are mouthwatering and their Bun Cha is legit!!  I also discovered a new item on the menu - which is the egg noodles with beef infused with red wine.  It has a very nice flavor to it with the saltiness of the beef and a slightly tart finish from the red wine.  I would like to order both the chicken pho and the egg noodles with beef when I go there next time, I just have to figure out how I can eat it all in one sitting.  

The staff at the Turtle Tower on Larkin are all very nice.  They always smile and greet you when you enter the restaurant and are always very attentive.  Hands down, the best Pho in SF :)  Whenever I need a good, hot bowl of pho or whenever I think of comfort food, Turtle Tower is definitely on top of my list!!
author: Jes D.

description:
Newly opened locaton to replace the old one in TL.  

The place was much bigger and cleaner than the old location.  

Definitely still the best Pho Ga in the city.
author: Liza T.

description:
Best pho ga in town!  I come here about once a week, and all of their soups are amazing, but the pho ga is definitely the star of the show.

Sometimes I crave TT but am too lazy to walk all the way down there.  I use postmates for those times, even though i know its a waste of money.  The pho is so worth it, though!
author: CC C.

description:
The Dish: My co-worker recommended this place and praised it so highly that I decided it would be worth the trip through Tenderloin. If you're a pho fan, you're going to like this place. BEST CHICKEN PHO EVER! It's clean and healthy (doesn't have all the grease that the typical beef pho places have). The chicken is really tender and they have two options - small or large. Personally, small is enough if you're not starving. Get the Pho Ga!

Ambiance: The only downside about this place is the location. Only redeeming factor of walking through Tenderloin. Also, the service was TERRIBLE that day. The waitress sat us, and then told us to wait, and then told us one of the tables were ready and then changed her mind, and then finally seated us at the original table. After we were seated, she handed us a menu, dropped the menu, and struggled to pick it up for 20 seconds. She didn't apologize and just kept laughing. It was the most awkward experience I've ever had with a waitress, but the pho made up for it.
author: Gina T.

description:
Still super awesome. I love the new location. It's so much bigger (cleaner), and not as drafty as before. If it means that my wait is shorter, I am supportive! 

I order the usual Pho Ga (chicken noodle) and Fresh Spring Rolls. The only issue I have is that the portion of chicken to noodle to broth ratio is less than I remember. I don't believe they raised their prices (they could have, but I can't remember). But their chicken portions are definitely reduced. I guess they needed to recoup the renovations and move costs. 

I also can't believe they have I love TT tote bags. LOL
author: Winny F.

description:
I liked this place when it was at its old location on the corner on Larkin and Willow. Yes it was small, but I liked the homey atmosphere and authentic feeling of old grandmas serving you. Now it feels commercialized with its Turtle Tower merchandise hanging on the wall. 

The quality of the food seems to be going down too, with increased quantity of people they are serving, as if they are taking on more than they can handle. Don't get me wrong, this is still some of the best Pho Ga (I get it with the giblets- yummy hearts, gizzards, liver, and other visceral organs!) I've ever had, but it's no longer a 5 star place it once was. 

PRO TIP: Like all the other reviews state, this is NORTHERN Pho so it has a simpler broth, less garnishes, and larger noodles than the Pho you are probably used to. Go early or during non-peak hours to avoid the massive lines.
author: Sophia V.

description: I've heard good things about Turtle Tower, but I didn't realize it was Northern Vietnamese food. This is the first time I tried it. I was able to try #2. Ph Tái (Rare Beef Noodle Soup) and #18. Cm Tht Gà Luc (Steamed Chicken over Steamed Rice). The broth was a little salty for my taste, but it wasn't horrible. Overall, the food was just okay.
author: John D.

description: They deserve 5 stars for the chicken noodle with ok service. I found myself addicted to the noodle. Always my to go place every time visited the city.
author: Jacky T.

description: I can never turn down Turtle Tower -- hungover or not. The items on their menu runs a recipe for awesome-ness. My own combination: chicken noodle soup (with or without intestines), imperial rolls and a Thai iced tea. SCHWING.
author: Allison C.

description: This place was interesting because it wasn't your traditional pho. I got the chicken pho, and it was good. The chicken is cut into skinny strips and the broth was very good. What makes it different wasn't the chicken, but the fact that the noodles were fat rice noodles. Also, there are no customary sides like bean sprouts, cliantro, basil, hoison sauce. What you get in the bowl is really all you get and I must say it is pretty good. I tried the beef soup and I thought it was a bit sweet for some reason. It definitely caught me off guard. I also got the chicken and sausage sticky rice. It was as the name states...nothing special. Not worth getting imo.
author: Victor D.

description:
Oh I loveeee this place.  LOVE it. 

Only wish it were open later for dinner.
author: Mister G.

description:
Came to the new location for the first time last Friday. This is definitely nicer than the old one. It's split level and, unlike the previous location, you don't have to go the back dining area via the alley (if that was needed).

Having gone to their three different restaurant locations (excluding the one at SF State which is more of a food stand), this original one still seem to be the best. It could be they have to step things up with much nearby competition in this part of City called Little Saigon. My top choices are the beef stew with wine and the chicken pho with the intestines and other parts.
author: H K.

description:
It's unfortunate this place takes cash only. The restaurant itself looks nice and sleek. I'm sure they have a ton of cash behind the scene - Walter White style. 

However, the pho was really good. I enjoyed it a lot. And the red chili sauce has some kick to it!
author: Ken C.

description:
I was in the mood for Pho and I'm new to city living here in SF - so my sis took me here. I ordered #4 the beef noodle soup with all the goodies you would normally find in a combination pho dish. (tripe, beef brisket, etc...) The only difference was that the rice noodles were slim and flat and I really liked the change from traditional pho noodles. The beef broth was really good. Although they are known for their chicken noodle soup I was not mad about getting the beef noodle soup. 

One note is that this place is in the tenderloin and there was human pee, feces and blood on the sidewalks as I came over here. So if you're adventurous enough - come during daylight would be my recommendation.
author: Richie C.

description:
The pho ga was good. Lots of herbs and green onions floating, not too much chicken skin or funky bits and the broth was a-ok, not super flavorful. Rice noodles were wider than I'm used to and really soft- I liked that. 

The hot sauce on the table wasn't super hot so I had to load up to get a good burn going. The jalapeno slivers they offered were meager and kinda wilty. 

The coffee was awesome, but no different than others I've had. Not sure what all the hype is about, did I order the wrong thing?
author: Catherine R.

description:
*** food poisoning alert *** 
if you would not like to get food poisoning, then don't come here. there beef is under-cooked and they use what seems to be like left-overs. they charge 15% tip too. yet, when i ask for napkins, the lady gives me 2. 2. 2 napkins!!!! 2 napkins and you want a 15% tip??? not to mention the service was sub-par and it wasn't even that great. trust me when i say, i will never come back here again! i suggest whoever doesn't want to have food poisoning and a bad experience to do the same. i would give negative stars if i could but yelp doesn't have that option yet. (i will update this when yelp adds negative stars)
author: Jonathan H.

description:
I went here for lunch yesterday and was totally unimpressed. My friend ordered a tasty-sounding chicken & rice dish. (Sorry, forgot the name.) It arrived and we both burst out laughing and saying that's it? It was a mound of rice with boiled chicken strips on top. All I could think of was that it looked like a dish you'd be served in the hospital if you were relegated to a "bland diet." After the laughing stopped, she sadly dived into her entirely flavorless lump of food. 

I ordered the imperial rolls & vermicelli noodles. Every time I've ordered this off the entree (not appetizer) part of the menu, I'd get a big bowl of noodles w veggies, sauce, and the rolls on top. Instead, I got what I consider an appetizer -just the rolls, small pile if noodles on the side, lettuce, and dipping sauce. The flavor was nice, it just wasn't what I thought I was getting. Especially for $9. 

In summary, my friend and I were both surprised, unpleasantly so. On one hand though, it's our fault. Clearly this is the place for Pho. We were in error by straying into other parts of the menu. I *will* return. And I will only order the soup. I suggest you do the same.
author: Fran C.

description:
They need to step up their game. The broth was just rather warm, not hot. I was not too upset about this because the meat in my bowl was cooked (Pho ga, add beef).  However, another guy at the table ordered rare beef on the side and the soup was not hot enough to cook his beef. It looked kind of disgusting - especially because after he fished the beef out of the bowl and asked for a side of hot water to cook the beef it again was not hot enough. Third time was the charm, but that just shouldn't be an issue in the first place.

Otherwise it was relatively clean and the pho ga would have been awesome if everything just came out a little hotter.
author: Jeff L.

description:
Good but Pho tai broth watery lackin flavor.

I'd rank pho a sen and Ben tre's pho higher
author: Ellen H.

description:
Ever since I came back from Vietnam I've appreciated Vietnamese food so much more. Guys! Vietnamese food is more than just pho! Just give the other dishes a shot.

I came here knowing what I wanted: BUN CHA. A famous dish loved by the locals in the capital of Vietnam, it consists of dry vermicelli noodles, grilled pork, dipping sauce that's sweet and salty, and a nice serving of vegetables. Turtle Tower's version of the dish did not disappoint and the taste was actually quite comparable to that Hanoi's bun cha restaurants. However, similar dishes from other Vietnamese restaurants in the Bay Area seemed to yield more than what I got on my plate.

Wait time can be about 20-30 minutes for 3-4 people for lunch on a weekend.
author: Jason T.

description:
Not the best pho I've ever had. Never had chicken pho either (I've grown up eating beef/steak/cow/non-chicken pho). But! Their chicken pho was delicious! The broth was very tasty, chicken was tender. Weird how they don't have sprouts OR hoisin. My boyfriend got the beef pho, he said that the meat was smushy and no texture in the soup. 

But kudos on the best (really, and only) chicken pho soup I've had!
author: Kimmy D.

description: There was a funky smell that was really bothering me... But the food was good. Pho is much store than some of the other places you'll see but the bahnmi with the fried egg?? Legit.
author: Alex S.

description:
New location is clean and inviting.  It's still a little too cozy, but if you're a fan of noodle houses, you're used to tight quarters, right?  They do have many four top tables that offer relative privacy (if you're a party of two lucky enough to score one).  The chicken IS a better chicken soup than the beef is as a beef soup.  Does that make sense?  They serve their noodles a little too soft for my taste, but it's consistent, so at least i know what to expect.  Broth is decent.  Three stars easily.  

The biggest positive TT's got going for them at this location is their service and staff.  This should be a given, but at 95% of the noodle houses, it's not.  Most service at other restaurants is marginal at best.  It's a step better here; which doesn't say a lot, BUT it's great compared to the others!  Extra star.  

My last rant is just a general peeve of mine at all pho houses.  Sorry to single out Turtle Tower here.  I think pho should always be served with lime, not lemon--ever.  (even the best places have given me lemon at one time or another) But that's just me.  Most of time I have received lime here, so honorary star for TT!
author: Stephen F.

description:
After a grand old time of partying in the city on new years eve. We decided soup might be the best remedy for the hangover our party of 7 had. The reviews seemed excellent and this restaurant received high praise from our friends. 

So we decided to try it out. Specifically the Pho Ga. The wait time seemed quite long but given that this restaurant wasn't overly large we continued waiting. Eventually we were seated and almost everyone ordered Pho Ga. 

The Pho Ga had a nice light broth with a surprising amount of flavor. The noodles tasted really good. They were wider noodles than those that normally come with Beef Pho. No hoisin  sauce at the table but the soup was pretty good. It didn't have too much oil in it. Which is usually why I do not order Pho Ga.I also tried to order a sandwich which they were out of.

The service was just okay. The restaurant was pretty busy but I felt the service could of been a lot better. I would rate it 3.5 stars.
author: Jeff D.

description:
Right from day 1, this location was very good.  The family who owns the chain of Turtle Towers (Geary, 7th and Bryant) have really perfected their craft.  

Food is piping hot and is made to order.  I forgot to mention quick as well.  This new location really showcases the progress. It is a beautifully designed and clean restaurant in the Tenderloin.  

The server who has served me the three times I've went, Anne has been very helpful.  She even checks on you before, during and after the meal to make sure everything is fine.
author: Brandon Y.

description: I was there today for some lunch. Heard great things and I wanted an authentic experience so I tried turtle tower out. They serve traditional ha noi region food and I heard from my girlfriends mom that this region of Vietnam is very stuck up (she's from Vietnam so I trust her). The pho with rare beef was delicious only thing disappointing was no bean sprouts or sides with the pho. I guess this region of Vietnam doesn't do that. Good food though and great service.
author: Eric M.

description:
Came here to try out the famous Pho Ga; and they were spot on! They serve it Ha Noi style, which means no bean sprouts and hoisin sauce. Honestly, it didn't need it. The soup was super flavorful, and the hubby who is normally a beef (broth) person, was won over with the chicken! Not too oily and tastes like the broth has been stewing with chicken for hours.

The staff is friendly and very attentive. We came early in the morning so no line yet with plenty of seating.

The fresh soy milk really does taste like fresh soy milk, not something they pour out of a can.

I'm not giving it 5 stars as we didn't try their beef broth or their other foods. Will next time we're in town with a side of pho ga, of course! Their prices are super reasonable as well!
author: Alice L.

description: Pretty poor food. Tastes like broth is made from canned chicken broth. Looks like meat is ground chuck formed into meat patties. Had two bites, paid and left
author: C.Edward K.
